questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient presented to the OPD with complaints of blurring of vision, severe headache, and ringing in the ears for 4 months. CT scan was done, and meningioma was diagnosed. While doing surgery for meningioma, the left paracentral lobule got injured. This will lead to paresis of?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Right leg and perineum:

  • The paracentral lobule presents near the midline encroaching upon the medial surface of the hemisphere and is the continuation of the precentral and postcentral gyri.

  • The paracentral lobule is involved in controlling the motor and sensory innervations of the contralateral lower limb and part of the perineal region. It is involved in the control of the bladder and bowel (defecation and urination) function.
  • It also includes parts of the frontal and parietal lobes.
  • The anterior part of the paracentral lobule is a portion of the frontal lobe and contains a portion of Brodmann's area 6.
  • The posterior part is considered a portion of the parietal lobe and deals with the somatosensory of the distal limbs.
  • Cerebral homunculus is a map along the cerebral cortex of where each part of the body is processed. The sensations occur all along the body. The impulses from the body will be sent into the spinal cord and eventually back to the brain to be processed.
  • Sensory Motor Homunculus: Representation of body on the cerebrum.
  • Upside-down representation in an oblique fashion [along the central sulcus].
  • Both motor & sensory.
  • Hand & face has more representation.
  • Lower & lateral: Face area.
  • Higher: Upper limb area.
  • Still higher: Pelvis perineum area.
  • On the medial surface: Lower limb area, part of pelvis & perineum.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Left face:

  • The paracentral lobule governs sensory and motor sensations of the right limb and perineum.

Option B - Right neck and scapular region:

  • The paracentral lobule governs sensory and motor sensations of the right limb and perineum.

Option C - Right shoulder and trunk:

  • The paracentral lobule governs sensory and motor sensations of the right limb and perineum.

questions.text: A 6-day-old newborn is brought to the physician because he has become increasingly irritable and restless over the past 2 days. During this period, he has had 12 bowel movements. He feeds 10 to 12 times a day. He was born at 38 weeks gestation and weighed 1800 g. He currently weighs 1700 g. His mother has Graves’ disease and received propylthiouracil during the last trimester of pregnancy. She has a history of intravenous heroin use. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), his pulse is 180/min, and his respirations are 50/min. Examination shows mild diaphoresis and a firm 2-cm midline neck swelling. The actively secreting follicles of the structure involved in the patient's pathology are lined by one of the following?
questions.solution:
Option A: Columnar epithelium

  • This is a case of Hyperthyroidism.
  • Thyroid follicles store thyroglobulin, an iodinated glycoprotein.
  • Normally a thyroid follicle is mostly lined by cuboidal epithelium (central spherical nucleus, with a height of the cell equal to breath)
  • Since the question asked is regarding the secretary follicle, the answer is a columnar epithelium.
  • Secreting active thyroid follicles are lined by a columnar type of epithelium.

Option B: Cuboidal epithelium

  • The thyroid follicle epithelial lining depends on the cells' activity in the secretion of thyroxine.
  • Normally a thyroid follicle is mostly lined by cuboidal epithelium (central spherical nucleus, with a height of the cell equal to breath).
  • Secreting active thyroid follicles are lined by a columnar type of epithelium.

Option C: Squamous epithelium

  • Simple Squamous: Thin rim of cytoplasm above flat /globular nucleus
  • Scanty (resting follicle): Simple squamous

Option D: Pseudostratified squamous

  • The pseudostratified epithelium is very rare in cuboidal and squamous cells. It is seen in columnar form and lines the respiratory tract, male genital tract etc.
  • Normally a thyroid follicle is mostly lined by cuboidal epithelium(not pseudostratified).

questions.text: A 31-year-old male presents with progressive weakness and dysfunction of his right arm following a previous radial bone fracture from a road traffic accident. X-ray shows healed fracture with decreased width and atrophy of the right arm. The symptoms are likely due to compression of neurovascular bundles passing through which structure?

choices.text: Both A and B are correct

questions.solution:
Option B: Haversian canal

  • Haversian canal (run longitudinal to the length of bone) is the central canal of the osteon that carries blood vessels and nerves while Volkmann's canal (run perpendicular to the long axis of the cortex) is the perforating canal that connects Haversian canals with each other and with the periosteum. 
  • Neuromuscular bundle is present in its center
    • Osteocytes are present in lacunae
    • CANALICULI processes of osteocytes
    • CENTRAL CANAL consists of blood vessels
  • In, the context of the given scenario, the compression of the neurovascular bundle within the bone is more commonly associated with Haversian canals, as they contain blood vessels and nerves directly within the bone tissue. While Volkman's canals can also play a role in blood supply to bone, they are less likely to directly contribute to compression-related symptoms such as weakness and dysfunction in the arm. 

Option A and C: Volkman's canal and both 

  •  Refer to option B explanation

questions.text: A 14-year-old female presenting to the emergency department with severe sudden-onset headache for the last hour, brain MRI reveals a lesion on the surface of the Sylvian fissure, comparable to the superficial Sylvian vein. Where does Sylvian's vein drain into?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Cavernous sinus:

  • The Sylvain’s vein is the superficial middle cerebral vein that drains numerous small tributaries from the opercular areas around the lateral sulcus.
  • This vein courses along the Sylvian fissure posteroanterior. Sylvian fissure is also known as insular cisterna. It is present between the temporal and the frontal lobes of the cerebrum. A superficial middle cerebral vein drains into the cavernous sinus. Cavernous sinuses drain the blood from the orbits via ophthalmic veins and the base of the brain through the sphenoparietal sinus and the middle cerebral veins. They drain into the superior and inferior petrosal sinuses and eventually into the internal jugular veins.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Great cerebral vein of Galen:

  • The right and left internal cerebral veins (joins behind the brain stem) form the great vein of Galen. It also receives the basal vein of Rosenthal, which receives the internal cerebral vein.
  • Sylvain’s vein does not drain into Great cerebral vein of Galen.

Option B - Straight sinus:

  • The straight sinus drains into the confluence of the sinus. The confluence of sinuses drains into the transverse sinus. Transverse sinus drains into the sigmoid sinus. The sigmoid sinus drains into the internal jugular vein.

Option C - Internal cerebral vein:

  • Internal cerebral veins are around the brain stem and run behind to join Galen's great cerebral vein. The cavernous sinus drains into the petrosal sinus. The superior petrosal sinus drains into the transverse sinus. Inferior petrosal sinus drains into the internal jugular vein.

questions.text: A 45-year-old obese male presents to the hospital with a complaint of not being able to feel the bitter and sweet taste for 1 month. He has a past medical history of diabetes and hypertension for the last 6 months A medical consultant questioned a postgraduate resident that the taste pathway lies under which neural column?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Special Visceral Afferent:

  • A Special visceral afferent fiber (SVA) is an afferent fiber that develops together with the GIT tract.
  • They carry the senses of smell (olfaction) and taste (gustation).
  • The cranial nerves with SVA fibers are the olfactory, facial, glossopharyngeal, and vagus nerves.
  • The facial nerve receives taste sensation from the anterior 2/3rd of the tongue, the glossopharyngeal from the posterior 1/3rd, and the vagus nerve from the epiglottis.
  • The sensory processes send projections to the medulla, from which they travel in the tractus solitarius, ending at the rostral nucleus solitarius.
  • Transmits information regarding smell and taste.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A, B & D are incorrect

questions.text: A 63-year-old presents to the emergency department with headache, vomiting, blurred vision, and drowsiness after a fall. The suspected cause is raised intracranial pressure. Which cranial nerve is most commonly affected?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Abducent nerve:

  • The abducent nerve is most commonly involved in intracranial hypertension
  • Reasons
    • Longest intradural course
    • Taking a sharp bend over the apex of the petrous part of the temporal bone.
    • Passing through the cavernous sinus, not supported laterally by any dura mater.
  • Its palsy causes loss of abduction of the affected eye.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Oculomotor nerve:

  • The oculomotor nerve is most commonly affected intracranially due to an aneurysm of the posterior communicating artery.

Option B - Trochlear nerve:

  • The trochlear nerve has the longest intracranial route, but it is not most commonly affected due to increased intracranial pressure.
  • It supplies the superior oblique muscle.

Option C - Trigeminal nerve:

  • Trigeminal nerve is not commonly affected in intracranial hypertension.
  • Penetrating wounds and facial fractures cause damage to peripheral branches of the trigeminal nerve.

questions.text: Which part of the lung is most likely affected in a 68-year-old male with severe emphysema and esophageal achalasia, admitted to the intensive care unit with chronic hypercapnic respiratory failure and right lower lobe pneumonia, where dullness on percussion is observed in the area medial to the medial border of the scapula upon arm elevation?
questions.solution:
Option A: Right superior Bronchopulmonary Segment

  • The dullness on percussion in the area medial to the medial border of the scapula upon elevation of the arm indicates an area of consolidation or fluid accumulation within the lung.
  • The right superior bronchopulmonary segment is located in the upper lobe of the right lung. This segment extends from the apex of the lung to the horizontal fissure. The dullness described in the patient's examination suggests involvement of the right upper lobe, which is consistent with the location of the right superior bronchopulmonary segment.
  • Given the history of emphysema and pneumonia involving the right lower lobe in this patient, it's not uncommon for pneumonia to spread to adjacent lung segments. The right upper lobe can be affected due to aspiration or secondary spread of infection, especially in patients with compromised respiratory function.
  • The right lung, characterized by a larger diameter and a more vertical orientation, coupled with the wider, shorter, and more vertical right principal bronchus, is particularly susceptible to aspiration of foreign bodies or gastric contents.
  • Typically, in an erect position, aspiration occurs in the most dependent areas of the lung, primarily the posterior basal bronchopulmonary segment (BPS) of the right lower lobe. However, when patients are supine, aspiration tends to occur in different locations. The most common sites for aspiration in supine patients are the posterior basal BPS of the right upper lobe and the apical-basal BPS of the right lower lobe.

Options B: Right posterior Bronchopulmonary Segment 

  • The most dependent part of the right lung in an erect position is the posterior basal bronchopulmonary segment (BPS) of the right lower lobe.
  • Preferred answer - Apical basal BPS of the lower lobe of right lung >> Posterior BPS of the right upper lobe

Option C: Left superior Broncho-pulmonary Segment

  • As right primary bronchus is shorter in length, has a wider lumen, and is more vertical hence more prone to aspiration and leading to aspiration pneumonitis compared to the left superior broncho-pulmonary segments.

Option D: Right medial basal Bronchopulmonary Segment

  • Upon elevation of the arm, the medial border of the scapula corresponds to the oblique fissure of the lung on the posterior thorax.
  • So, the right medial basal border is not affected.

questions.text: Which of the following arteriesgives the branch called recurrent interosseous artery?
questions.solution:
Option B: Posterior interosseous artery

  • The ulnar artery is a common interosseous artery, which is divided into anterior and posterior interosseous arteries.
  • The posterior interosseous artery gives the recurrent interosseous artery.
  • The recurrent interosseous artery is also called the interosseous recurrent artery; it moves upward between the lateral epicondyle and the olecranon process.
  • Recurrent interosseous artery anastomoses with the branch of the deep brachial artery to provide enhanced anastomosis around the elbow.
  • Posterior interosseous and recurrent interosseous arteries provide fasciocutaneous flaps used in post-traumatic reconstruction surgeries.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Anterior interosseous artery passes through the anterior compartment of the forearm.

  • It branches off the common interosseous artery.
  • It doesn't give recurrent interosseous artery.

Option C: Common interosseous artery

  • A common interaction artery is a branch of the ulnar artery originating at the proximal end of the radius; it gives anterior and posterior interosseous arteries (not recurrent interested artery).

Option D: Radial artery

  • The radial artery is a branch of the brachial artery that divides into the ulnar artery and radial artery at the elbow joint.
  • The radial artery gives the radial recurrent artery, palmar carpal branch, and dorsal carpal branch.

questions.text: Which of the following is the deepest and smallest muscle of the anterior abdominal wall?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Transversalis:

  • The transversalis or the transversus abdominis muscle is a broad, paired, and the deepest muscle of all 6 muscles of the abdomen.
  • Its origin is from internal surfaces of costal cartilages of ribs 7 to 12, thoracolumbar fascia, anterior 2/3rd of the iliac crest and iliopectineal arch, and its inserted at the linea alba, aponeurosis of internal oblique, pubic crest and pectineal line of the pubis.
  • Its bilateral contraction causes compression of abdominal viscera, helps in the expiration, and its unilateral contraction causes ipsilateral trunk rotation.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - External oblique:

  •  The external oblique muscle is the largest and the most superficial muscle of the abdominal wall.

Option - Internal oblique:

  •   The internal oblique lies deep to external oblique muscle.

Option D - Rectus abdominis:

  •  It is the muscle of the anterior abdominal wall and is neither the smallest nor the deepest muscle of the abdominal wall.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male presents to OPD with c/o left leg pain that radiates to below the knee. He also c/o numbness in the lower part of the same leg. On performing straight leg test the pain increases.   Which specific dermatome is likely involved in sciatica?
questions.solution:
Option D: S2

  • S2 dermatome belongs to the posterior cutaneous nerve of the thigh. 
  • Root value- S-1,2,3 (majorly S2)
  • Sciatic is condition characterized by severe pain along the distribution of the sciatic nerve. 
  • The pain is experienced in the posterior aspect of the thigh, the posterior and lateral side of the leg and the lateral part of the foot.
  • S2 dermatome extends from the buttocks to the posteromedial aspect of the thigh, popliteal region, calf region and a part of the perineal region. Anteriorly includes the penis and scrotum 
  • The dermatomes of the lower limbs are innervated by the spinal nerves L1-S5. Back pain caused by sciatica can radiate into any of these dermatomes but most commonly S2

Option A: L4

  • L4  dermatome anteriorly curves from the lateral aspect of the thigh to the medial aspect of the leg and foot.
  • Includes the knee, medial surface of the big toe, and medial malleolus. It does not cover the posterior calf and posterior thigh region

Option B: L5

  • L5 dermatome covers the posterolateral aspect of the thigh, wrapping anteriorly at the knee level to cover the leg's anterolateral aspect.
  • Includes the dorsal and plantar aspects of the foot, lateral surface of the big toe, and toes 2, 3, and 4. It does not cover the posterior thigh and posterior calf

Option C: S1

  • S1 dermatome extends to the posterolateral aspect of the thigh, popliteal region, and posterior aspect of the leg, lateral malleolus, lateral margin of foot, heel, and little toe. It does not cover the posterior thigh and calf

questions.text: The patient who visited the outpatient department (OPD) displayed an irregular way of walking. During the examination, it was noticed that when the patient was instructed to balance on their left foot, there was a drop in their right hip. Which muscles are affected by paralysis in this particular patient?

choices.text: Right gluteus maximus and gluteus medius
Right gluteus medius and gluteus minimus
Left gluteus maximus and gluteus medius
Left gluteus medius and gluteus minimus

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Left gluteus medius and gluteus minimus:  

  • The left gluteus medius and gluteus minimus stabilize the pelvis during a single-leg stance on the left side. 
  • If these muscles were paralyzed, it would result in difficulty stabilizing the pelvis, causing a right-sided hip drop when standing on the left foot. 
  • A right-sided hip drop when standing on the left foot suggests that there is a weakness or paralysis of the left-sided muscles that stabilize the pelvis during a single-leg stance.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Right gluteus maximus and gluteus medius: Right gluteus maximus and gluteus medius: if the right gluteus maximus and gluteus medius were paralyzed, it would result in difficulty extending the hip and abducting the hip, respectively, but would not cause a right-sided hip drop when standing on the left foot.

Option B - Right gluteus medius and gluteus minimus: Right gluteus medius and gluteus minimus: If the right gluteus medius and gluteus minimus were paralyzed, they would have difficulty abducting the hip and stabilizing the pelvis during a single-leg stance on the right side. However, this would not cause a right-sided hip drop when standing on the left foot, as the left-sided muscles would stabilize the pelvis during a single-leg stance on the left side. 

Option C - Left gluteus maximus and gluteus medius: Left gluteus maximus and gluteus medius: If the left gluteus maximus and gluteus medius were paralyzed, they would have difficulty extending the hip and abducting the hip, respectively, but would not cause a right-sided hip drop when standing on the left foot.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is most significant in resisting hyperextension and lateral rotation at the hip joint?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Iliofemoral ligament:

  • Illiofemoral ligament of bigelow attaches to the ileum bone and the femur bone in order to prevent the hyperextension.

  • It comes from the hip bone and attaches to the femur and prevents the movement of femur to reach more posteriorly

  • It is the strongest ligament of the human body

  • The Iliofemoral Ligament resists both hyperextension and lateral rotation at the hip joint. 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Pubofemoral ligament:

  • The Pubofemoral ligament reinforces the joint inferiorly and limits extension and abduction.

  • The base of the ligament attaches to the superior ramus of the pubis, and the apex attaches below to the lower part of the intertrochanteric line.

Option B - Ischiofemoral ligament:

  • The Ischiofemoral ligament reinforces the joint posteriorly and limits limits internal rotation and hip adduction with flexion

Option D - Gluteus maximus muscle:

  • The Gluteus Maximus muscle extends and laterally rotates the thigh and does not particularly resist hyperextension.

questions.text: An infant was brought to the pediatric department for routine vaccination. After the vaccination, the mother took the baby to the doctor as she noticed the baby's asymmetrically flat head and uneven ears.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this infant?
questions.solution:
Option A: Plagiocephaly

  • Plagiocephaly is defined as the asymmetric shape of the head due to unilateral flattening that can result from:
    • Asymmetry in the closure of sutures.
    • Asymmetry of brain growth or deformation of the skull.
  • It may be frontal or occipital plagiocephaly.
  • Frontal plagiocephaly is caused by premature fusion of coronal and sphenofrontal sutures characterized by:
    • Unilateral flattening of the forehead
    • Elevation of the ipsilateral orbit and eyebrow
    • Prominent ear on the corresponding side
  • Occipital plagiocephaly is caused by positioning during infancy. It is more common in immobile children or children with a disability. Fusion of lambdoid suture can cause unilateral occipital flattening and bulging of the ipsilateral frontal bone.

Option B: Dolichocephaly

  • A condition in which the head is elongated from front to back in the sagittal plane.
  • Dolichocephaly is due to premature closure of the sagittal suture, which produces a long and narrow head with a cephalic index of less than 75.
  • It is characterized by an increased anterior-posterior diameter of the skull.
  • It is also known as scaphocephaly.
  • It is the most common form of craniosynostosis.

Option C: Brachycephaly

  • A condition in which the head shape is shortened from front to back along the sagittal plane; typically, the back of the skull (occiput) and face are flatter than normal.

Option D: Anencephaly

  • A condition in which a baby is born with an underdeveloped brain and an incomplete skull
  • It is a type of neural tube defect that occurs when the neural tube fails to close at the base of the skull during the third to fourth week of development.

questions.text: A child presents with his stepmother in the outpatient department with complaints of fever and continuous irritability. She does not know his exact age. On examination, the baby was in a tripod position, had a bi-dextrous approach, had stranger anxiety, and could speak monosyllables. Based on the above findings, what is the estimated age of the baby?
questions.solution:
Option A: 7 months

  • Based on the clinical scenario, the baby is 7 months old.
  • The baby can sit in a tripod position.
  • Bi-dexterous approach by the fifth month.
  • Monosyllables by the 6th month
  • Stranger anxiety and transferring objects from one hand to another by the 7th  month

Option B: 12 months

  • At 12 months, the child can speak 2–3 words with meaning.
  • At 12 months, the baby kisses on request and Plays a simple ball game.

Option C: 9 months

  • At 9 months, the child can speak bi-syllabic babbling (mama and papa but without meaning).
  • A child can wave bye-bye.

Option D: 10 months

  • At the age of 10 months, children have improved motor skills.
  • Plays peek-a-boo

questions.text: A 16-month-old baby boy is brought to the pediatric OPD with a complaint of eating mud, chalk, and other non-nutritive things for the last two months. The mother says no matter how much they try giving him good food at regular intervals throughout the day, he does not stop eating mud. What abnormality does this child have?
questions.solution:
Option C: Pica

  • The above case is most probably of 'Pica.'
  • Pica is the persistent eating of non-nutritive, non-food substances over at least one month, such as plaster, charcoal, paint, and soil.
  • It provides emotional relief.
  • Pica is commonly seen in children and pregnant ladies.
  • It is associated with malnutrition, iron deficiency anemia, emotional trauma, and developmental disabilities.
  • There is an increased risk of lead poisoning and parasitic infestations.
  • Treatment is by behavioral modification, deworming, iron supplementation, and screening for lead poisoning.

Option A: Bruxism

  • Bruxism (teeth grinding) causes muscular or temporomandibular joint pain, dental occlusion.

Option B: Avoidant/restricted food intake disorder

  • ARFID does not include persistent eating of non-nutritive, non-food substances

Option D: Rumination disorder

  • Rumination disorder does not include persistent eating of non-nutritive, non-food substances

questions.text: A newborn with a gestational age of 34 weeks and a birth weight of 1600 grams has been managed in a warmer for the last 18 hours. On examination, the neonate is shivering and has a heart rate of 122 beats per minute and a respiratory rate of 60 breaths per minute. The child has an axillary temperature of <36.5° and a warm abdomen but cold extremities. What is the quick diagnosis that should be made in this clinical setting?
questions.solution:
Option C: Cold stress

  • Pre-term and low-birth-weight babies are more at risk of developing neonatal hypothermia.
  • The presence of shivering, a temperature of <36.5°C, and a warm abdomen but cold peripheries suggest mild hypothermia. The cardio-respiratory systems are also in compensation.
  • Mild hypothermia is also called cold stress.
  • During mild hypothermia, the body stimulates the shivering mechanism and increases metabolism. Heat loss is also decreased by peripheral vasoconstriction.

Option A: Normal body temperature

  • In Fahrenheit, the normal core body temperature range is 95.8 to 99.3°F.
  • In Celsius, it is 36.5°C to 37.5°C.

Option B: Severe hypothermia

  • In severe hypothermia, body systems fail to function. The core temperature is < 32°C.
  • The patient is in a coma with fixed, dilated pupils, apnea, and pulselessness.
  • Muscles also become stiff.

Option D: Shock

  • Clinical findings of tissue hypoperfusion manifest it.
  • On examination, cold extremities, acrocyanosis, poor capillary refill, and tachycardia suggest the diagnosis of neonatal shock.

questions.text: A 20-day-old infant girl is brought to the emergency department by her mother with complaints of fever, vomiting, and diarrhea for four hours. She has decreased her urine output for one day. The diet of the patient consists of breast milk and cow milk protein-based formula. The patient is otherwise vitally stable. The abdominal examination reveals abdominal rigidity. The test of the stool for occult blood is positive. An x-ray of the abdomen shows gas within the intestinal wall and the peritoneal cavity. Which of the following are risk factors for the patient’s current pathology?
questions.solution:
Option C: Lack of breastfeeding

  • This is a case of necrotising enterocolitis in which the patient presents with complaints of fever, vomiting and diarrhoea for four hours. The abdominal examination of the patient revealed abdominal rigidity. The test of the stool for occult blood is positive.
  • The abdominal x-ray of the patient revealed gas within the intestinal wall and peritoneal cavity, which is suggestive of necrotising enterocolitis.
  • Lack of breastfeeding is one of the risk factors for necrotising enterocolitis.
  • The aetiology of this disease is unknown.
  • The other risk factor for necrotising enterocolitis includes prematurity, aggressive formula feeding, maternal cocaine abuse, fetal hypoxia and absent or reversed end-diastolic flow in the umbilical artery on antenatal USG.

Option A: Fetal hyperoxia

  • Fetal hyperoxia can lead to a reduction in fetal vascular resistance.
  • It can also lead to secondary increased fetal pulmonary flow.

Option B: Maternal alcohol abuse

  • Maternal alcohol abuse can cause the following abnormalities in neonates:
    • Microcephaly
    • Abnormal facies
    • Neuromuscular disorders such as seizures

Option D: Gestational diabetes

  • Gestational diabetes can cause the following abnormalities in neonates:
    • Macrosomia
    • Shoulder dystocia
    • Higher body fat

questions.text: A neonate is admitted to NICU after 16 hours of birth with the complaint of yellow skin. Neonate’s palms and soles are yellow. The baby weighs 3.3 kg at birth. Total serum bilirubin test results show a 19.1 mg/dl bilirubin level. Clinical examination and lab results are suggestive of pathological jaundice. Phototherapy is prescribed. Which mechanism in phototherapy is chiefly responsible for the reduction in serum bilirubin?
questions.solution:
Option C: Structural isomerisation

  • Bilirubin → Lumirubin → excreted through kidney without conjugation
  • It is faster and irreversible
  • The most important mechanism by which phototherapy acts to reduce serum bilirubin.

 

Option A: Photo-oxidation

  • It is the least important mechanism where photo products are excreted in the urine. 
  • This reaction is slow and occurs in small quantities, with dosages in the urine of between 2-9 mg/l.27 

Option B: Photo-isomerisation

  • Bilirubin → Polar compound → excreted through the kidney without conjugation
  • It is slow and reversible
  • Compared to Structural-isomerisation, Photo-isomerization is the least important by which phototherapy acts to reduce serum bilirubin.

 

Option D: Conjugation 

  • It is a physiological process that occurs in the liver and converts unconjugated bilirubin into conjugated bilirubin by the enzyme uridine diphosphate glucuronyl transferase (UDP-GT.) 
  • Jaundice can be of both types, with the bilirubin either unconjugated or conjugated

questions.text: A 5-day-old male child admitted to the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) was born at 37 weeks of gestation because of intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR). His mother is a hepatitis B carrier. On physical examination, he has microcephaly, flat occiput and dysmorphic facial features with relatively large ears and a short neck. He has ambiguous external genitalia. Chromosomal analysis has been performed due to dysmorphic facial features, which revealed a mosaic karyotype with abnormalities of chromosome 13 with deletions at locus 13q32. Which of the following is the possible chromosomal abnormality in this case?
questions.solution:
Option D: Ring chromosome

  • Ring chromosomes are unusual circular chromosomes.
  • Ring chromosome 13, also known as r(13), is a chromosomal abnormality where both ends of chromosome 13 fuse together, forming a ring-shaped chromosome.
  • When ring chromosome 13 is associated with clinical features resembling Patau syndrome (trisomy 13), phenotypic similarities between ring chromosome 13 and Patau syndrome include craniofacial abnormalities, intellectual disability, congenital heart defects, and other systemic anomalies are found.

Option A: Translocation

  • This process is called translocation, when a chromosome or segment breaks off the parent chromosome and joins another chromosome.

Option B: Telomeric fusion

  • Telomeres uphold chromosomal integrity by capping the ends of linear chromosomes to prevent fusion.
  • The gradual telomere erosion will lead to the loss of the end-capping function forming short dysfunctional telomeres.
  • It results in the fusion of telomeres with other telomeric loci and produces dicentric chromosomes.
  • This mutational event can lead to large-scale genomic rearrangements, mostly observed in different cancers

Option C: Isochromosome

  • One arm of a chromosome is lost, and the remaining arm is duplicated, known as an isochromosome.
  •  Normally chromosomes divide longitudinally, but during the formation of isochromosomes, chromosome divides transversely across the centromere, with half of the chromosome replicating to form its complement.
  • Therefore, two new types of chromosomes are reduced, one having both long arms and the other with short arms

questions.text: An infant is evaluated in the nursery. The infant was born by vaginal delivery about an hour before. The mother has a history of preeclampsia during pregnancy. The mother had a vesicular rash over her body two days ago, but the rash spread towards the body. APGAR scores were 8 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. The boy weighs 3 kg . The vital signs are normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate step for this infant?

choices.text: Test for the presence of antibody

questions.solution:
Option C: Passive immunization with monoclonal antibody

  • The mother's fever and vesicular rash are indicators of the outbreak of the varicella-zoster virus, or chickenpox.
  • They spread through droplets, and both are highly contagious.
  • Post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) is giving immunoglobulins or vaccines to the patient after exposure to the virus to prevent future infection.
  • If the patients are not immunized or have not received two doses of the varicella-zoster virus vaccine, then post-exposure prophylaxis should be recommended. If the patient is immunocompetent, the post-exposure prophylaxis is limited to immunization with the live varicella-zoster virus vaccine.
  • For high-risk patients (as in this infant), who can't receive the varicella virus vaccine, post-exposure prophylaxis is given through immunoglobulins against the varicella-zoster virus. This is also called VZIG, or Varicella zoster immunoglobulins. The indications of varicella zoster immunoglobulins are neonates, immunocompromised patients, and pregnant women. In infants, it is effective if the mother gets infected five days before and two days after delivery.

Option A: Active immunization with live-attenuated virus

  • The varicella-zoster vaccine is recommended for immunocompetent patients. Neonates have compromised immunity, so the live virus vaccine is contraindicated at less than 1 year of age.

Option B: Close observation

  • Follow-up and close observation are not indicated in this case because there is a 95% chance that exposed infants may get an infection.
  • Neonatal varicella infection is a severe disease involving multiple systems, e.g., meningitis, encephalitis, or hepatitis.

Option D: Test for the presence of antibody

  • Testing for immunoglobulins is not helpful in this case because the infant has not had enough time to make his immunoglobulins. It takes two to three weeks to develop after the infection, IgG is not transferred through the placenta.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman with complaints of Recurrent Headaches has been advised to get a CT Head. CT scan exposes the Brain to Ionizing radiation, which of the following enzyme protects the brain from free radical injury is?
questions.solution:
Option B: Superoxide dismutase

  • Superoxidase dismutases (SODs) are found in many cell types and convert O2 radicals into hydrogen peroxide.
  • superoxide dismutase is an enzyme that prevents the cell from reactive oxygen species.

This group of enzymes includes:-

  • Manganese-SOD localized in mitochondria
  • Copper-zinc- SOD found in the cytosol.

One of the earliest discovered hereditary forms of Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) has mutations in the gene encoding copper-zinc superoxide dismutase (SOD1) on chromosome 21; this variant accounts for about 20% of familial cases.

Option A: Myeloperoxidase 

  • Myeloperoxidase is a peroxidase enzyme.
  • It is mainly present in neutrophil granulocytes
  • It produces hypochlorous acid to act as an antimicrobial enzyme.

Option C: NADPH oxidase

  • NADPH oxidase is the membrane-bound enzyme complex that faces extracellular space
  • It is used by neutrophils to engulf microorganisms.

Option D: Hydroxylase

  • Hydroxylases are enzymes that catalyze the addition of hydroxyl groups.
  • It is just involved in hydroxylation reactions.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a complaint of fever and cough. He is vitally stable. On examination, left lower lobe crepitation is heard. A diagnosis of pneumonia is made. Pneumonia is an acute lung parenchymal infection. The protective response is the invasion of neutrophils at the area of infection. A process known as NETosis is involved during the whole event of inflammation. Which of the following is least likely associated with the process of "NETosis"?

choices.text: Detected in blood in patients with sepsis
Plays a role in the pathogenesis of SLE

questions.solution:
Option B: Chromatin condensation

  • During NETosis, chromatin decondensation occurs.

Neutrophils extracellular traps:

  • Neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs) are characterised as extracellular DNA fibres comprised of histone and cytoplasmic granule proteins.
  • NETs were first described as an innate response against pathogen invasion, which can capture pathogens, degrade toxic bacterial factors, and kill bacteria. Additionally, NETs also provide a scaffold for protein and cell binding.
  • Protein binding to NETs activates the coagulation system, which participates in thrombosis.
  • In addition, NETs also can damage the tissues due to the proteins they carry.
  • Many studies have suggested that the excessive formation of NETs may contribute to various diseases, including thrombosis, atherosclerosis, autoimmune diseases, and sepsis.

Formation of NETs:

  • NETs are released by neutrophils in different forms depending on the specific assay employed and the stimuli used.
  • Presently, three NET formation pathways have been identified: vesicle-mediated, cell-lytic, and mitochondrial release.
  • The analysis of NET formation in vitro is complicated because neutrophils respond uniformly to strong NET instigators like PMA and ionomycin. Still, only a limited amount of neutrophils undergo NET formation in response to bacteria, fungi and LPS, leading to the presence of both unstimulated neutrophils and NETs in the same well.

The following hypotheses of NET formation have been proposed:

  • (1) Vesicle-mediated NET releases: under external stimulation with Staphylococcus aureus, the lobular nucleus of the neutrophil becomes round, and chromatin is uniformly concentrated in the nucleus. The nuclear membrane is then ruptured, and the vesicles wrapped with DNA move to the cell membrane. These vesicles subsequently fuse with the cell membrane and release the DNA in the vesicles, i.e., release NETs. Generally, NETs can be released within 30–60 min via vesicles
  • (2) Cell lytic: prototypical formation of NETs in response to PMA leads to cell lysis and requires more time (3–4 h). The nuclear membrane is enzymatically degraded upon external stimulation. The study reported that NE and MPO reportedly cooperate in nuclear lysis and chromatin decondensation in PMA-induced NET formation
  • (3) Mitochondrial DNA: Currently, few studies have reported that neutrophils release mitochondrial DNA to form NETs in a reactive oxygen species- (ROS-) dependent manner, while the detailed molecular mechanisms of mitochondrial DNA release are still unclear

Option A: Causes death of neutrophils

  • During NETosis, the nuclei of the neutrophils are lost, leading to the death of the cells.

Option C: Detected in blood in patients with sepsis

  • The process of NETosis has been found in patients with sepsis.

Option D: Plays a role in the pathogenesis of SLE

  • The nuclear chromatin in the NETs, which includes histones and associated DNA, has been postulated to be a source of nuclear antigens in systemic autoimmune diseases, particularly lupus, in which individuals react against their DNA and nucleoproteins

questions.text:
A 24-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a complaint of fever and cough. He is vitally stable. On examination, right lower lobe crepitation is heard. A diagnosis of pneumonia is made. Pneumonia is an acute lung parenchymal infection. The protective response is the invasion of neutrophils at the area of infection. Neutrophils trap the extracellular microbes via a fibrillary network, known as neutrophil extracellular traps. The process is shown below:



Which of the following is the most important amino acid formed from the cellular reaction shown above?
questions.solution:
The most important amino acid in the context of neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs) is:

Option C - Arginine:

Arginine plays a crucial role in NETosis, which is the process by which neutrophils release web-like structures composed of chromatin (DNA) and antimicrobial proteins to capture and neutralize pathogens.

Here's why arginine is important in NET formation:

  1. Nitric Oxide (NO) Production: Arginine is a substrate for the enzyme nitric oxide synthase (NOS), which generates nitric oxide (NO). Nitric oxide is involved in various cellular processes, including the regulation of NET formation.

  2. Citrullination: During NETosis, arginine residues on histones are converted into citrulline by a specific enzyme called peptidylarginine deiminase (PAD). This citrullination of histones is a crucial step in chromatin decondensation, which is necessary for NET formation.

As for the other amino acids mentioned:

Option A. Leucine, B. Methionine, and D. Valine are important amino acids in protein synthesis and other cellular processes, but they are not specifically known to play a central role in NETosis. Arginine, on the other hand, is directly involved in the processes critical for NET formation, making it the most important amino acid in this context.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is brought to the outpatient department by his mother with the complaint of frequent falls. The patient was born prematurely at 36 weeks gestation via normal vaginal delivery, and there was no known history of cyanosis in the neonatal period. He has met all the developmental milestones. He is up to date with his current vaccination. examination reveals lower limb bowing and blue sclera. The diagnosis of osteogenesis imperfecta has been made. Which of the following is the mode of inheritance of osteogenesis imperfecta?
questions.solution:
Option A: Autosomal dominant

  • Autosomal dominance is a pattern of inheritance characteristic of some genetic disorders. “Autosomal” means that the gene in question is located on one of the numbered, or non-sex, chromosomes. “Dominant” means that a single copy of the mutated gene (from one parent) is enough to cause the disorder.
  • A child of a person affected by an autosomal dominant condition has a 50% chance of being affected by that condition via inheritance of a dominant allele.
  • It is often due to defects in structural genes.
  • Many generations, both males and females, are affected.
  • Example:
    • Achondroplasia
    • Huntington disease
    • Neurofibromatosis type 1 and 2
    • Osteogenesis imperfecta
    • Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease
    • Myotonic muscular dystrophy etc

 Option B: Autosomal recessive

  • Autosomal recessive traits are one pattern of inheritance for a trait, disease, or disorder to be passed on through families. For a recessive trait or disease to be displayed, two copies of the trait or disorder need to be presented. The trait or gene will be located on a non-sex chromosome.
  • Often due to enzyme deficiencies.
  • With 2 carrier (heterozygous) parents, ¼ of the children will be affected, ½ of the children will be carriers, and ¼ of the children will be unaffected.
  • Examples:
    • Cystic fibrosis
    • Wilson disease
    • Sickle cell disease etc

Option C: X-linked recessive

  • X-linked recessive inheritance refers to genetic conditions associated with mutations in genes on the X chromosome. A male carrying such a mutation will be affected because he carries only one X chromosome. A female carrying a mutation in one gene, with a normal gene on the other X chromosome, is generally unaffected.
  • Sons of heterozygous mothers have a 50% chance of being affected.
  • No male-to-male transmission occurs.
  • Example: Haemophilia

Option D: Co-dominance

  • In codominant inheritance, two different versions (alleles) of a gene are expressed, and each version makes a slightly different protein.
  • Both alleles influence the genetic trait or determine the characteristics of the genetic condition.
  • Example: ABO blood grouping.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male presents to the emergency department with abnormal movement of the limbs. The family members also complain of memory decline over the past few months. According to his mother, his father has similar symptoms, but these symptoms developed when his father was in his forties. The doctor suspected the phenomena whereby successive generations are in danger of developing diseases early and more severely. Which of the following term best describes this phenomenon?
questions.solution:
Option A: Anticipation

  • A phenomenon in which disease onset occurs earlier and/or the disease manifestation is more severe in offspring than in parents.

Anticipation:

  • In genetics, anticipation is a phenomenon whereby, as a genetic disorder is passed on to the next generation, the symptoms of the genetic disorder become apparent at an earlier age with each generation. In most cases, an increase in the severity of symptoms is also noted.
  • Anticipation is common in trinucleotide repeat disorders, such as Huntington's disease and myotonic dystrophy, where a dynamic mutation in DNA occurs.
  • All of these diseases have neurological symptoms. Before understanding the genetic mechanism for anticipation, it was debated whether anticipation was a true biological phenomenon or whether the earlier age of diagnosis was related to heightened awareness of disease symptoms within a family.

Diseases showing genetic anticipation:

Autosomal Dominant

Autosomal Recessive

Multiple spinocerebellar ataxias

Friedreich’s ataxia – GAA

Huntington’s disease – CAG

X-linked

Myotonic dystrophy – CTG

Fragile X Syndrome – CGG

Congenital dyskeratosis – TTAGGG (telomere repeating sequence)

No expression type

Crohn’s disease

Behcet’s disease

Option B: Pleiotropy

  • Pleiotropy occurs when one gene influences two or more seemingly unrelated phenotypic traits. Such a gene that exhibits multiple phenotypic expressions is called a pleiotropic gene.
  • One of the most widely cited examples of pleiotropy in humans is phenylketonuria (PKU).
  • This disorder is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase, which is necessary to convert the essential amino acid phenylalanine to tyrosine

Option C: Imprinting

  • Imprinting is a mechanism of gene regulation in which one allele of a gene is silenced and imprinted while the other allele is expressed depending on which parent it was inherited from (i.e., parent-of-origin effect)
  • Disorders of imprinting are Angelman syndrome and Prader-Willi syndrome.

Option D: Mosaicism

  • Mosaicism or genetic mosaicism is a condition in multicellular organisms in which a single organism possesses more than one genetic line due to genetic mutation.
  • This means that various genetic lines resulted from a single fertilized egg.
  • For example, a person may have some cells in their body with 46 chromosomes, while others in their body have 47 chromosomes.
  • An example of mosaicism is Down mosaic syndrome.

questions.text: An 18-year-old male underwent renal transplantation (in the right iliac fossa) in 2008 for chronic interstitial nephritis-related renal failure with the mother as a donor. He was treated with triple immunosuppression (cyclosporine, prednisolone and mycophenolate mofetil). The patient was normal till 2020, when he developed dull-aching, non-radiating right lower abdominal pain. A hard tumour (about 15 cm x 10 cm) was felt under the surgical scar in the right iliac fossa. Ultrasound-guided biopsy from the mass revealed monomorphic B-cell non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma. The blood's lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) level was 850 U/L(normal: 140–280 units per litre). The 18FDG PET-CT was taken from the figure below. Serum creatinine was 1.10 mg/dl. It was diagnosed as a case of Post Transplant Lymphoma; it is caused by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Option B: EBV

  • Nasopharyngeal cancer, or cancer of the back of the nose, and some rapidly spreading lymphomas, like Burkitt lymphoma, are made more likely by EBV infection.
  • Additionally, some occurrences of stomach cancer and Hodgkin lymphoma may be connected.

Epstein-Barr virus

  • Lymphoid Malignancy
  • Post–organ transplant lymphoma
  • Primary CNS diffuses large B cell lymphoma
  • Extranodal NK/T cell lymphoma, nasal type
  • Hodgkin’s disease
  • Although no medicine can cure an EBV infection, you can take these steps at home to ease your symptoms:
    • Get plenty of rest.
    • Drink a lot of water and other liquids to stay hydrated.

Option A: CMV

  • In some cases, infection in healthy people can cause mild illnesses that may include:
    • Fever
    • Sore throat
    • Fatigue
    • Swollen glands
  • Blood, tears, semen, saliva, urine, and breast milk are a few examples of bodily fluids through which CMV patients may spread the virus. Infected individuals can transmit CMV to others in the following ways:
    • directly in contact with saliva or urine, particularly that of infants or young children
    • via sexual interaction
  • Blood tests can diagnose adults with signs of CMV infection. Blood, however, is not the ideal fluid to test babies who have a possible CMV infection. For neonates, saliva or urine tests are suggested.
  • Antiviral drugs, particularly valganciclovir, may enhance hearing and developmental outcomes for infants who exhibit congenital CMV infection at birth.

Option C: Herpes simplex

  • There are two forms of the herpes simplex virus (HSV): HSV-1 and HSV-2. HSV-1 can cause genital herpes but is most commonly spread by oral-to-oral contact. It causes oral herpes, which includes symptoms known as cold sores. Genital herpes is a sexually transmitted disease caused by HSV-2.
  • Symptoms:
    • Cold sores around their lips, mouth or tongue. They may look crusty or like fluid-filled blisters.
    • Sores on their genitals or around their anus.
    • Tingling, itching or burning.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Viral culture. This test involves taking a tissue sample or scraping the sores for examination in the laboratory
    • Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test.
    • Blood test.
  • For those with HSV infection, antiviral drugs, including acyclovir, famciclovir, and valacyclovir, are most effective (see WHO recommendations). However, they cannot treat the infection; they can only help lessen the symptoms' intensity and frequency.

Option D: H. Influenza virus

  • "Haemophilus influenzae sickness" refers to any ailment brought on by the H bacterium. influenzae.
  • Some of these illnesses are mild, like ear infections, while others are quite deadly, like bloodstream infections. H. Despite its name, influenzae does not cause the flu.
  • A doctor often diagnoses Haemophilus influenzae infection using one or more laboratory tests. A blood or spinal fluid sample is used in most diagnostic procedures.
  • The oral antibiotics trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, cefuroxime axetil, cefixime, clarithromycin, azithromycin, and fluoroquinolones all have an action against beta-lactamase-producing H influenzae.

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman is losing weight, feeling anxious, and perspiring excessively. Physical examination reveals tachycardia, exophthalmos, and a diffusely enlarged thyroid that is warm to the touch. According to lab results, her serum thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) levels are low, but her thyroid hormone (T3 and T4) levels are significantly higher. Which of the following disease pathways best describes the development of this patient's thyroid problem?
questions.solution:
Option A: Antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity

  • The patient has Graves disease, a TYPE II hypersensitivity type. 
  • Antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity is a TYPE II hypersensitivity. 
  • Antibodies bind to TSH receptors and stimulate thyroid hormone production. 
  • Labs of patients with graves disease are 
    • High T3 and T4 
    • Low TSH 
  • Symptoms of graves disease are 
    • Sweating 
    • Weight loss 
    • Tachycardia 
    • Exophthalmos 
  • TYPE II hypersensitivity is caused by an antigen reaction on the extracellular matrix. 
    • Opsonisation and Phagocytosis 
      • Antibodies labelled the cells that were detected by phagocyte Fc receptors. 
      • As a result, the tagged antigen is phagocytosed and destroyed by phagocytes. 
    • Complement and Fc receptor-mediated inflammation 
      • IgG and IgM both activate the complement system via the classic pathway. 
      • It causes an increase in vascular permeability and leukocyte-derived substances that may cause collagen, basement membrane, elastin, and cartilage digestion. 
    • Antibody-mediated cellular dysfunction
      • Antibodies bind to surface receptors, causing them to malfunction or stimulate. 
      • Graves disease is an example of TSH receptor antibodies stimulating T3 and T4 production. 

Option B: Immune Complex–Mediated disease

  • Type III hypersensitivity is characterised by immune complex-mediated disease. 
  • It results in the accumulation of antigen-antibody complexes in tissues. 

Option C: Delayed-type hypersensitivity

  • Type IV hypersensitivity is delayed hypersensitivity. 
  • It stimulates CD4 and CD8 T lymphocytes. 

Option D: Immediate hypersensitivity

  • Type I hypersensitivity is immediate hypersensitivity. 
  • It causes the release of IgE antibodies, which results in mast cell degranulation.

questions.text: A 2-month-old Infant born to a 24-year-old human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) positive female via spontaneous vaginal delivery at her own residence was brought to the outpatient department for follow-up. Which of the following is a non-reliable method used for the diagnosis of HIV in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: HIV ELISA (enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay)

  • HIV ELISA is required for the detection of antibodies against the virus.
  • The antibodies may be present in the infant because of maternal infection and also because IgG antibodies can cross the placental barrier.
  • So, this test is not reliable for the diagnosis of HIV in a 2-month-old child.

Option A: HIV-1 PCR (polymerase chain reaction)

  • HIV-1 PCR detects both RNA and pro-viral DNA with a sensitivity and specificity of more than 98%.

Option B: Viral culture

  • The HIV culture method is called ‘peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMC) using the virus microculture in macrophages concept.
  • PBMCs are drawn in high concentration from centrifugation of freshly drawn anticoagulated venous blood.

Option D: p24 antigen assay

  • p24 is an important structural component of the retroviral particle and is estimated at 2,000–4,000 molecules in each virion.
  • p24 antigen testing is sensitive and specific in diagnosing pediatric HIV infection, infection in the window phase, prediction of CD4+ T cell decline and clinical progression at an early and late stage of infection, and suitable for anti-retroviral treatment monitoring in both adults and children

questions.text: A professor was discussing the tumours of the cardiovascular system with medical students. After explaining the primary, secondary, benign and malignant tumours affecting the cardiovascular system, he mentions the most common tumour affecting the heart. Which of the following is the most commonest cardiac neoplasm in adults?
questions.solution:
Option C: Metastatic tumours

  • Heart tumours are classified into primary and secondary tumours.

Primary tumours: 

  • Primary tumours are further classified into benign and malignant tumours of the heart.
  • Primary heart tumours are rare.
  • Benign primary tumours include: 
    • Myxoma is the most common primary benign heart tumour in adults. It most commonly involves the left atrium.
    • Rhabdomyoma – It is most commonly seen in children and is a benign skeletal muscle tumour.
  • Malignant primary tumours include: 
    • Angiosarcoma – It is most commonly seen in adults, and it is a malignant tumour that involves the lining of the blood vessels.
    • Rhabdomyosarcoma- It most commonly affects children, and it is a malignant tumour of the skeletal muscle and is associated with tuberous sclerosis.
  • Secondary tumours: 
    • Secondary tumours of the heart involve the tumours that metastasize to the heart
    • They are most commonly metastasizing from breast, lung, melanomas, leukaemias, and lymphomas.
    • These are more common than the primary tumours of the heart.
    • The most common cardiac tissue involved is the pericardium of the heart.

Option A: Cardiac rhabdomyoma

  • Cardiac rhabdomyoma is a benign primary tumour of the heart. Secondary tumours are the most common cardiac tumours.

Option B: Atrial Myxoma

  • Atrial Myxoma is the most common benign primary tumour of the heart. Secondary tumours are the most common cardiac tumours.

Option D: Angiosarcoma

  • Angiosarcoma is a primary malignant tumour of the heart. Secondary tumours are the most common cardiac tumours.

questions.text: A man in his 35th year who complained of having difficulty breathing visited an outpatient clinic. He is a smoker and is employed in the plumbing industry. His blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg, and his pulse is 90/minute. The chest CT scan revealed fibrotic changes and bilateral pleural plaques at the basal areas of the lungs. The findings of the transbronchial biopsies were as displayed in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Asbestosis 

  • Asbestos causes inflammation in the lung parenchyma, leading to fibrosis and raising cancer risk. 
  • Occupational exposure (plumbing) is a major source of exposure.
  • Characteristics of asbestosis are 
    • Fibrous plaques
    • Pleural fibrosis 
    • Interstitial fibrosis 
    • Mesothelioma and bronchogenic carcinoma risk increases 
  • There are two types of asbestos on the market: serpentine and amphibole.
  • Because of its aerodynamic properties and solubility, amphibole is more pathogenic than the other. 
  • Morphology of asbestosis 
    • Asbestos bodies (golden brown rods with translucent centre coated with iron)
    • Ferruginous bodies (iron-coated organic materials)
    • Diffuse pulmonary interstitial fibrosis 

Option A: Silicosis

  • It is the most common type of pneumoconiosis. 
  • It increases the risk of tuberculosis. 
  • It manifests as an eggshell appearance in the lung parenchyma. 

Option B: Byssinosis

  • It is a pneumoconiosis caused by cotton, flax, and hemp exposure. 
  • It is very common among textile workers. 

Option D: Bagassosis

  • Bagasse exposure causes hypersensitive pneumonitis. 
  • It is common among workers in the wallboard and paper industries.

questions.text: A 30-year-old healthy woman who delivers an infant diagnosed with severe immunodeficiency is referred to the department of reproductive genetics of the hospital. Her infant presents recurrent pneumonia, reduced CD3 and CD4 positive leucocyte cell ratio, inverted CD4/CD8 ratio and reduced IgG, IgA, and IgM concentrations at six months of her age. The infant died at 22 months due to severe respiratory infection and respiratory failure. The infant is born at full term to healthy un-consanguineous parents without a family history of any genetic disorders. What is true regarding the case mentioned-above?
questions.solution:
Option A: Defect in β2-Microglobulin

  • Clinical signs: Diagnosed severe immunodeficiency, recurrent pneumonia, reduced CD3 and CD4 positive leucocyte cell ratio, inverted CD4/CD8 ratio and reduced concentrations of IgG, IgA, and IgM, severe respiratory infection and respiratory failure all indicate the diagnosis of bare lymphocyte syndrome.
  • BLS (Bare Lymphocyte Syndrome):
    • Deficiencies in MHC class I or class II are called bare-lymphocyte syndrome, reflecting the absence of these proteins from cell surfaces.
    • The important and ubiquitous role of MHC class I molecules is highlighted in patients with defective expression of all class I proteins.
    • Mutations can cause this rare immunodeficiency disorder in β2-microglobulin, a subunit of MHC class I proteins, or in the TAP proteins, which are vital to antigen presentation by MHC class I molecules.
    • In early life, the TAP-deficient individual suffers frequent bacterial infections of the upper respiratory tract and, in the second decade, begins to experience a chronic infection of the lungs.
    • The most characteristic mark of the deficiency is the occurrence of necrotizing skin lesions on the extremities and the midface.
    • These defects affecting MHC class I proteins result in impaired positive selection of CD8 T cells, depressed cell-mediated immunity, and heightened susceptibility to viral infection.

Option B: Autosomal dominant inheritance

  • It is an autosomal recessive inheritance.
  • Therefore this option is incorrect

Option C: MHC overexpression

  • Deficiencies in MHC class I or class II are called bare-lymphocyte syndrome, reflecting the absence of these proteins from cell surfaces.
  • So, MHC non-expression is seen in this condition.

Option D: MHC expression

  • Deficiencies in MHC class I or class II are called bare-lymphocyte syndrome, reflecting the absence of these proteins from cell surfaces.
  • The important and ubiquitous role of MHC class I molecules is highlighted in patients with defective expression of all class I proteins.

questions.text: A 52-year-old hypochondriac female patient presents with complaints of fever and easy fatigability. On examination, hepatomegaly is observed. The patient also has a history of multiple radiation exposures from multiple CT scans & X-rays. Further investigations reveal decreased Leukocyte alkaline phosphatase (LAP). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option C: Chronic myeloid leukemia

LAP elevated in: LAP decreased in:
Leukemoid reaction. CML.
Pregnancy Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria.
Polycythemia vera. Sickle cell anemia.
Aplastic anemia. Multiple myeloma Hypophosphatasia.
Obstructive jaundice.

 
Hodgkin's disease.

 

 

  • Alkaline phosphatase is a group of enzymes that remove phosphate groups from molecules.
  • These enzymes work best in alkaline/basic media.
  •  Leukocytes alkaline phosphatase (LAP) is found in mature leukocytes.
  • In CML, leukocytes undergo left shifting (immature cells); thus, they have less than normal LAP.
  • CML is characterised by massive hepatosplenomegaly, ecchymosis, and fever due to opportunistic infections.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Myelofibrosis

  • Myelofibrosis is an uncommon type of bone marrow cancer that causes extensive scarring in bone marrow leading to severe anaemia that causes weakness and fatigue.
  • However, the LAP score increases in myelofibrosis.

 

Option B: Essential thrombocythemia

  • Essential thrombocythemia (ET) is also an uncommon disorder of the platelets in which they increase in number.
  • Symptoms of ET include headache, dizziness, chest pain, fainting, temporary vision changes, numbness or tingling of the hands and feet, and throbbing/burning pain in the hands and feet.
  • LAP score increases in ET, not decreases.

 

Option D: Polycythemia Vera

  • Polycythemia Vera is a type of chronic leukemia that causes bone marrow to produce excessive red blood cells.
  • These excessive red blood cells cause blood to thicken and increase the risk of blood clots, thus leading to heart attack and stroke.
  • Symptoms of Polycythemia Vera include headache, blurry vision, red skin, and itching, particularly after a hot bath, tiredness, high blood pressure, dizziness, and sometimes confusion.
  • LAP score increases in Polycythemia Vera.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child from a Punjabi family with a history of blood transfusions presents with haemoglobin of 4.5 g/dl, MCV is 70 fl, and RDW is 22. The peripheral smear reveals anisopoikilocytosis with microcytic hypochromic anaemia and target cells. The osmotic fragility is reduced too. Which of the following is the most likely working diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Beta thalassemia major

  • This patient with a history of blood transfusions, haemoglobin 4.5 g/dl, MCV is 70 fl, RDW is 22, anisopoikilocytosis with microcytic hypochromic anaemia and target cells, and reduced osmotic fragility most likely has Beta thalassemia major.
  • It is characterized by the following:
    • Severe hemolytic anaemia requiring repeated transfusions
    • Hepatosplenomegaly
    • Skeletal deformities
    • Transient aplastic crisis
    • Growth retardation
  • The peripheral blood smear findings may include the following:
    • Target cells
    • Anisopoikiolocytosis
    • Inclusion bodies
  • Apart from Punjabis, other ethnic groups with a high prevalence of thalassemia are Sindhis, Gujaratis, Parsis, Bengalis and Lohanas.

Option A: Iron deficiency anaemia

  • This patient's history of repeated transfusion makes this diagnosis unlikely, as the need for such repeated transfusions is highly unlikely in iron deficiency anaemia.

Option C: Sickle cell anaemia

  • Reduced osmotic fragility may be seen in sickle cell anaemia,
  • But the absence of sickle cells on the patient's peripheral smear rules it out.

Option D: G6PD deficiency

  • It results in normocytic anaemia secondary to exposure to oxidizing agents in G6PD-deficient individuals.
  • This patient's reduced MCV effectively rules it out.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents to the hospital complaining of epigastric abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhoea. He has a history of hyperparathyroidism and transsphenoidal prolactinoma resection a few years back. His abdomen's contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) scan reveals hyper-enhancing pancreatic lesions and duodenal inflammation, suggesting pancreatic neuroendocrine tumour (gastrinoma) with secondary duodenitis and bilateral indeterminate hypoattenuating adrenal nodules. Moreover, his follow-up magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) confirms benign adrenal adenomas and a parathyroid adenoma. Mutation of which of the following will be present in this patient if genetic research is carried out?
questions.solution:
Correct Option

Option C: MEN 1

  • Given clinical features suggests the diagnosis of multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) syndrome associated with parathyroid adenoma.

  • Patients with MEN syndrome type 1 & 2 have gene mutations that make them susceptible to neoplasia or hyperplasia in multiple organs.

Multiple endocrine neoplasia:

  • All MEN syndromes have an autosomal dominant inheritance.

  • It has the following types:

    • MEN1

    • MEN2A

    • MEN 2B

  • MEN1 It is caused by a mutation of MEN1 (menin, a tumour suppressor gene on chromosome 11).

    • It is characterised by pituitary tumours (prolactin or Growth hormone), pancreatic endocrine tumours (Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, insulinomas, VIPomas, glucagonomas) and parathyroid adenomas.

  • MEN2A is characterised by parathyroid hyperplasia, medullary thyroid carcinoma and pheochromocytoma.

    • It is associated with a mutation in RET.
  • MEN2B is characterised by medullary thyroid cancer, pheochromocytoma, and mucosal neuromas.
    • It is associated with a mutation in RET gene

Incorrect Options:

Option A: BRCA1

  • Mutation in BRCA1 causes the following:
    • Breast cancer
    • Ovarian cancer
    • Pancreatic cancer
    • Prostate cancer

Option B: RB

  • Mutation in RB causes:
    • Retinoblastoma
    • Osteosarcoma

Option D: VHL

  • Mutation in VHL causes Von-Hippel-Lindau disease
  • Therefore this option is incorrect

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman presents to the physician with a complaint of excessive fatigue and jaundice. She reports that she had felt fatigued for months. Recently, she noticed that her skin is more orange. On physical exam, she is noted to have scleral icterus and jaundice. Laboratory results reveal transaminitis. Anti-smooth muscle antibodies were negative, but a liver biopsy showed granulomatous inflammation of the bile ducts. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Primary Biliary Cholangitis (PBC)

  • In the above-mentioned case, the findings such as excessive fatigue, skin more orange, scleral icterus, and jaundice on physical examination with granulomatous inflammation of the bile ducts on biopsy are suggestive of Primary Biliary Cholangitis (PBC).
  • PBC is an autoimmune disease characterized by inflammatory destruction of small- and medium-sized intrahepatic bile ducts.
  • Large intrahepatic ducts and the extrahepatic biliary tree are not involved. Most patients are diagnosed in the early stages of the disease.
  • Antimitochondrial antibodies directed against pyruvate dehydrogenase complex (PDC-E2) are the most characteristic finding in PBC.
  • The hallmark of PBC is lymphocytic infiltration and epithelial injury involving the small interlobular bile ducts.
  • The histologic picture of lymphocytic and granulomatous bile duct destruction (florid duct lesion) is highly characteristic of PBC.
  • Hypercholesterolemia is common. Splenomegaly and jaundice are seen in advanced diseases.
  •  Other features that may be seen include skin hyperpigmentation, xanthelasmas, steatorrhea, and vitamin D malabsorption–related osteomalacia and/or osteoporosis.

Option B: Non-alcoholic steatohepatitis

  • It is the inflammation and damage of the liver caused by a fatty deposition in the liver. It is an aggressive form of fatty liver disease.
  • Obesity is one of the risk factors for this disease.

Option C: Hemochromatosis

  • Hemochromatosis is caused by excessive iron absorption, most of which is deposited in the liver and pancreas, followed by the heart, joints, and endocrine organs.
  • It includes the triad of cirrhosis, diabetes, and skin bronze pigmentation.

Option D: Wilson disease

  • Most patients typically present before age 40.
  • The features include cirrhosis, neurologic disease, psychiatric disease, and Kayser-Fleischer rings in the eyes.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents with a complaint of headache, especially when he wakes up. He recently got difficulty seeing the board in class. He also had an episode of unconsciousness at school. The image shows histological findings in the brain of a patient suffering from the most common primary benign brain tumour in children. What is your likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Pilocytic astrocytoma

  • On microscopic examination of pilocytic astrocytoma, the tumour is composed of bipolar cells with long, thin "hairlike" processes that are GFAP-positive and form dense fibrillary meshworks.
  • Rosenthal fibres and eosinophilic granular bodies are often present.
  • Most common benign brain tumour in children
  • Cerebellar location > 3rd ventricle
  • Cystic mass
  • p53 mutation is rare
  • Grade I Astrocytoma
  • NF-1, BRAF mutation

Option B: Glioblastoma

  • Glioblastoma is a Grade IV astrocytoma.
  • It is a common, highly malignant primary brain tumour with one-year median survival.
  • It is found in the cerebral hemispheres.
  • It can cross the corpus callosum "butterfly glioma" associated with EGFR amplification.
  • It is of astrocyte origin, glial fibrillary acidic protein(GFAP) positive.
  • "Pseudopalisading" pleomorphic tumour cells with central border areas of necrosis, haemorrhage, and/or microvascular proliferation.

Option C: Medulloblastoma

  • Most common malignant brain tumour in childhood.
  • It commonly involves the cerebellum and can compress the 4th ventricle causing non-communicating hydrocephalus causing, headaches and papilledema.
  • It can involve the cerebellar vermis causing truncal ataxia.
  • It can send "drop metastases" to the spinal cord.
  • Histology shows it is a form of primitive neuroectodermal tumour (PNET).
  • "Homer-Wright rosette" (small blue cells surrounding the central area of the neuropil)
  • It is positive for synaptophysin.

Option D: Ependymoma

  • Most commonly found in the fourth ventricle.
  • Histologically, it is of ependymal origin.
  • Characteristic "peri-vascular pseudorosettes" are seen.
  • Rod-shaped blepharoblasts (basal ciliary bodies) are found near the nucleus.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman presents in the emergency with the complaint of watery diarrhea and abdominal pain associated with flatulence after having a banana milkshake 4 hours ago. She has a medical history of undergoing chemotherapy for breast cancer diagnosed 3 months ago. Which enzyme deficiency is the most probable cause of the symptoms described?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Beta-galactosidase:

  • Beta-galactosidase, or lactase, in intestinal cells digests lactose into glucose and galactose for absorption.
  • Lactase deficiency leads to lactose intolerance.
  • Primary deficiency involves declining lactase activity after weaning due to a lack of lactase-persistent allele.
  • Secondary deficiency results from various conditions damaging the intestinal brush border.
  • Symptoms of lactose intolerance include diarrhea, bloating, flatulence, abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting.
  • Diagnosis relies on clinical presentation and three main investigations:
    • Stool pH decrease
    • Lactose hydrogen breath test for increased hydrogen content (best confirmatory)
    • Intestinal biopsy (rarely performed, distinguishes between primary and secondary deficiency)
  • Management involves a lactose-free diet and enzyme replacement therapy.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Alpha-amylase:

  • Alpha-amylase breaks down starch into smaller carbohydrates like maltose.
  • Produced by salivary glands and pancreas.
  • Salivary amylase acts in the mouth, continuing in the stomach until destroyed by acidity.
  • Pancreatic amylase in the duodenum digests remaining starch.
  • Deficiency indicates pancreas or salivary gland disorders.
  • Often linked to pancreatic insufficiency from conditions like cystic fibrosis or chronic pancreatitis, leading to malabsorption.

Option C - Alpha-glucosidase:

  • Alpha-glucosidase, or acid maltase, is a lysosomal enzyme that breaks down glycogen into glucose.
  • Deficiency leads to Pompe's disease (type II GSD), particularly in infants, often fatal.
  • Affected areas include the heart, liver, and muscles, with normal serum glucose levels.
  • Symptoms include cardiomegaly, enlarged tongue, hypotonia, and liver enlargement.
  • Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is a common cause of death.
  • Muscle biopsy reveals glycogen accumulation in lysosomes.

Option D - Sucrase:

  • Sucrase is an enzyme that breaks down sucrose into fructose and glucose in the intestines.
  • Its deficiency is a congenital disorder, leading to symptoms like chronic diarrhea, failure to thrive, colic, abdominal swelling, irritability, indigestion, vomiting, and severe diaper rash in infants.

questions.text: What intermediate of the TCA cycle is depleted in patients with uncontrolled diabetes leading to it's suppression?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D – Oxaloacetate:

Oxaloacetate is a critical intermediate in the TCA cycle as it combines with acetyl-CoA to initiate the cycle. In uncontrolled diabetes, oxaloacetate levels can become depleted due to the increased diversion of oxaloacetate towards gluconeogenesis to compensate for the high blood glucose levels characteristic of uncontrolled diabetes.Uncontrolled diabetes can suppress the tricarboxylic acid (TCA) cycle due to:

  1. Decreasing insulin level reduces the entry of pyruvate into mitochondria, lowering oxaloacetate production.
  2. Increased fatty acid beta-oxidation, generating excess NADH and depleting NAD levels.
  3. Diversion of Acetyl CoA towards ketone body synthesis instead of entering the TCA cycle.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A – Succinate:

  • The primary factor causing TCA suppression in diabetic patients is the shortage of TCA carrier oxaloacetate, which is diverted to gluconeogenesis. However, Succinate is not involved in gluconeogenesis.

Option B – Malate:

  • Though malate is formed during gluconeogenesis, it is not used for glucose synthesis.

Option C - α-Ketoglutarate:

  • In diabetes, anabolic reactions, including amino acid synthesis, are generally suppressed. Since α-Ketoglutarate is primarily used for these anabolic reactions, there won't be depletion of it in diabetes.

questions.text: An obese young woman accidentally ingests a banned drug and develops a high-grade fever. It was once known to be used for weight reduction. The drug is known to affect ATP formation in the Electron Transport Chain. What could be that drug?
questions.solution:
Option C: 2, 4 dinitrophenol

  • The drug 2,4 dinitrophenol is an ionophore.
  • Ionophore allows proton to pass through & dissipates the electrochemical gradient generated by proton pumps.
  • Because it is a chemical ionophore, 2,4 DNP inhibits the last stage of the energy conversion process that is Uncouples the oxidation from phosphorylation. i.e. Oxidation continues without phosphorylation.
  • Because of this change potential energy of protons is lost in the form of heat rather than being converted to ATP which in turn results in increase in body temperature (hyperthermia) seen in this patient.

Option A: Barbiturate

  • Barbiturates such as amobarbital inhibit the electron transport from Complex I to Coenzyme Q.
  • So, they inhibit both oxidation and phosphorylation.
  • Barbiturate poisoning leads to hypothermia, not fever

Option B: Malonate

  • Malonate does not decouple oxidative phosphorylation.
  • It inhibits Electron Transport Chain Complex II.
  • It is an inhibitor of the TCA cycle (a competitive inhibitor of enzyme succinate dehydrogenase).

Option D: Rotenone

  • It does not decouple oxidative phosphorylation but inhibits it by inhibiting complex I.
  • Rotenone is produced naturally in the stem and seeds of certain plants.
  • It is a fish poison and is used for catching fish. It is not an over-the-counter drug.

questions.text: Which of the following vitamins is a part of the prosthetic group of an acyl carrier protein (ACP) of fatty acid synthase complex?
questions.solution:
Correct option C: Pantothenate

  • Pantothenic acid plays a central role in acyl group metabolism.
  • It functions as the pantetheine moiety in coenzyme A (CoA) and acyl carrier protein (ACP).
  • Pantetheine is formed through the combination of pantothenate with cysteine.
    • Cysteine provides the -SH prosthetic group for CoA and ACP.
  • CoA is involved in various biochemical reactions:
    • Participates in the citric acid cycle.
    • Plays a role in fatty acid oxidation.
    • Facilitates acetylations.
    • Contributes to cholesterol synthesis.
  • ACP is specifically engaged in fatty acid synthesis.

 

Incorrect options

Option A: Pyridoxine

  • Pyridoxal-5-phosphate is a form of active co-enzyme which is used to measure B6 in blood.

Option D: Thiamine

  • Thiamin is also a water-soluble vitamin B1.
