  • It can be found in some foods and also can take from vitamin B1 supplements.
  • It cannot be synthesized by the body

Option B: Folate

  • It is known as vitamin B6.
  • It is used as a dietary supplement.
  • It is the natural form of soluble vitamin B9.
  • It is available in the form of folic acid, which is good for absorption.

questions.text: A patient presents with episodes of flushing, diarrhea, and abdominal cramping. What is the chemical structure of the monoamine neurotransmitter linked to these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 5-hydroxytryptamine:

  • Diagnosis: Carcinoid syndrome, caused by neuroendocrine tumors producing excessive serotonin.
  • Symptoms: Flushing, diarrhea, abdominal cramping, wheezing, and heart palpitations due to serotonin release.
  • Chemical structure: Serotonin (5-hydroxytryptamine or 5-HT), synthesized mainly in enterochromaffin cells of the gastrointestinal tract.
  • Storage sites: Serotonergic neurons in the CNS, myenteric intestinal plexus, enterochromaffin cells in the gastrointestinal mucosa, platelets, and mast cells.
  • Synthesis: Serotonin synthesized from tryptophan by hydroxylation and decarboxylation.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Acetyl methyl serotonin:

  • This compound is melatonin.

Option C - 3-Methoxytyramine:

  • It is a metabolite of dopamine.
  • It is formed when the methyl group is transferred to dopamine by COMT.

Option D - 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid:

  • Monoamine oxidase (MAO) converts serotonin to 5-hydroxy indole acetic acid (HIAA) as a metabolite of serotonin.
  • Confirmation of carcinoid syndrome involves measuring 24-hour urinary levels of 5-HIAA.

questions.text: Which of the following is a dietarily non-essential amino acid that becomes essential in patients with type I homocystinuria?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Cysteine:

  • Cysteine is dietarily non-essential, synthesized from methionine.
  • Classical homocystinuria results from CBS enzyme deficiency, inherited autosomal recessive.
  • Clinical manifestations include failure to thrive, ectopia lentis, thromboembolic events.
  • Diagnosis involves elevated homocysteine and methionine in blood and urine.
  • Treatment includes high doses of pyridoxine, folic acid, B12, and betaine.
  • In classical homocystinuria, methionine-to-cysteine conversion is affected, making cysteine essential in the diet.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Methionine:

  • Methionine synthesis increases due to elevated homocysteine levels, resulting in its restriction in diet.

Option C - Homocysteine:

  • In type I homocystinuria, homocysteine level is increased
  • Hence, it does not require supplementation.

Option D - Tyrosine:

  • Tyrosine becomes an essential amino acid in phenylketonuria as phenylalanine to tyrosine conversion is inhibited.
  • It is not required in patients with type I homocystinuria.

questions.text: Which of the following is the only prokaryotic DNA polymerase with 5'→3' exonuclease activity?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - DNA polymerase I:

  • 1st DNA polymerase discovered
  • Only polymerase with 5' → 3' exonuclease activity.

E.coli (Prokaryotic)

Eukaryotic

Function

DNA Polymerase I

Mitochondria

  • RNase
  • FEN-1 (Flap>endonyclease)
  • δ-polymerase (Minor role)

Nucleus

  • RNase H
  • FEN-1
  • Removes primer (5’ → 3' exonuclease activity)
  • Fill the gap (5’ → 3’ polymerase activity)

DNA Polymerase II
  • β(beta)
  • γ(gamma)
  • DNA proofreading and repair (5’ → 3’ polymerase and 3’ → 5' exonuclease activities)
  • Mitochondrial DNA synthesis

DNA Polymerase III
  • ε (Epsilon)
  • δ (Delta)
  • Leading strand synthesis
  • Lagging strand synthesis

Incorrect Options:

Option B, C, and D: Refer to the table above

questions.text: A study is being done on the replicative nature of DNA. In this experiment, a cell is placed in a medium containing radioactively labeled thymidine. After the cells undergo replication 3 times, what percentage of cells will have both strands of DNA labeled?
questions.solution:
Correct option C: 75%

  • In semi-conservative, each strand of DNA acts like a template for the other new strand, which is being synthesized (complementary strand). So, it results in the formation of two double-stranded DNA  with each having one old and one new strand in the first replication generation (F1).
  • in this mode of replication, in each round of replication, one strand is old, and one is synthesized new in newly replicated DNA
  • In this above scenario, they asked about how many percentages of cells had labeled DNA on both strands after three replications, that would be 75%, as in the 1st generation, there would be no such type of molecule, and in the 2nd replication there would be half molecules having labeled cells in both strands as described in the picture below (In this fig, the red strand represents the labeled strand):

Incorrect options

Option A: 25%

  • 25% is not seen in any replication generation in the above picture.

Option B: 50%

  • 50% of molecules with labeled cells (on both strands) in one molecule are seen in 2nd generation.

Option D: 100%

  • 100% DNA molecules with newly labeled cells in all strands of all molecules are not practically possible.

questions.text: The following Michaelis Menten graph represents the effect of substrate concentration [S] on the initial velocity [Vi] of an enzyme-catalyzed reaction. Which of the following statement is not true about this graph?

choices.text: The curve is hyperbolic in shape
“?” here represents Km of the enzyme
At point C only a small amount of the enzyme is present as the Enzyme-Substrate complex
At point C, Vi is independent of [S].

questions.solution:
Option C: At point C only a small amount of the enzyme is present as the Enzyme-Substrate complex.

  • This is Michaelis-Menten graph shown which explains the kinetics of a simple enzyme with one substrate.
  • This is obtained by first determining initial velocities (substrate produced/unit time) of an enzyme at variable substrate concentrations and then plotting these velocities against their substrate concentration at Y and X axis respectively.
  • The shape of the curve obtained is rectangular hyperbola shape (Option A is true).
  • The nature of curve can be explained as:
    • As low substrate concentrations the velocity of enzyme increase linearly as more and more enzymes gets bound by substrate to give more product per unit time. Kinetics here is first order kinetics i.e. velocity is directly proportional to substrate concentration
    • Once all the enzyme molecules are bound to substrate there is no further increase in the velocity and curve starts to flatten out (Point C in curve) indicating a constant velocity (Option C is False).
    • At this point increasing the substrate concentration do not further increase velocity as there is no more enzyme to bound to increasing substrate molecules. In other words, enzyme follow zero order kinetics i.e. velocity is independent of substrate concentration (Option D is true)

Option A, B and D: Refer to explanation of C

questions.text: A group of neurologists is studying signal-transmitting cells of the nervous system. They concluded that a myelin sheath covers neurons. Loss of myelin can occur due to direct damage to the myelin sheath or indirectly through a primarily genetic disorder or attack during inflammation or toxic exposure. Which of the following cells form myelin in CNS?
questions.solution:
Option A: Oligodendrocytes

  • The Glial cells are classified into two types: macroglia and microglia.
  • Astrocytes and oligodendrocytes are macroglia.
  • Astrocytes are central nervous system-supporting cells that provide a variety of roles, such as structural support, insulating receptive surfaces, and buffering the extracellular compartment.
  • Oligodendrocytes: CNS nerve myelination; one oligodendrocyte myelinates several neurons (1:20).
  • In the CNS, oligodendrocytes generate the myelin sheath.
  • Oligodendrocytes are the primary CNS-supporting cells.
  • Each oligodendrocyte may myelinate up to 30 CNS axons.
  • As a result, oligodendrocytes are the most common kind of glial cell in white matter.
  • Derived from neuroectoderm, it shows on histology slides as a 'fried egg.'
  • Multiple sclerosis, leukodystrophies, and multifocal leukoencephalopathy can all cause indirect myelin sheath damage.

Option B: Schwann cells

  • The Myelin sheath of the peripheral nerves is formed by the Schwann cells.

Option C: Microglia

  • Microglia are neuronal support cells (Neuroglia) found in the central nervous systems of invertebrates and vertebrates that predominantly operate as immune cells.
  • Microglia, like peripheral macrophages, are the major immune cells of the central nervous system.
  • They do not myelinate neurons in any way.

Option D: Astrocytes

  • Astrocytes are supporting cells within the central nervous system that have numerous functions, including providing structural support, insulating receptive surfaces, and buffering the extracellular compartment.
  • These are the most common glial cells in CNS but do not form the myelin sheath, so this answer is wrong.

questions.text: Which of the following organs is most likely to establish collateral circulation?
questions.solution:
Correct option D: Heart

Collateral circulation:

  • Collateral channels are blood vessels that allow blood to flow directly from one artery to another.
  • There are no functional inter-coronary channels or existing collaterals in the normal human heart.
  • Sudden blockade of an artery may lead to ischemia and necrosis of the corresponding portion of the myocardium.
  • However, if the narrowing of a coronary artery occurs slowly, there may be a development of collateral vessels.
  • Collateral channels have also been found to develop in skeletal muscle circulation.
  • Collateral vessels originate from existing branches that undergo remodeling with the proliferation of endothelial and smooth muscle cells.
  • Stimuli for collateral development include angiogenic molecules released from the ischemic tissue and changes in mechanical stress in the walls of vessels supplying the affected region.

Incorrect options

Option A: Lungs

  • Arteries in the lungs are end arteries.
  • Such arteries have no anastomoses with their neighboring arteries.
  • While the pulmonary arteries are end arteries and they do not create extensive anastomoses with neighboring arteries within the lung tissue, collateral circulation can still occur in the lungs through other mechanisms, though they are as not prominent as those formed in the heart.
  • Collateral vessels in lungs can develop in response to certain pathological conditions or chronic hypoxia.

Option B: Kidneys

  • Arteries in the kidneys are end arteries,
  • So, collateral circulation is not seen in kidneys.
  • However, in certain conditions such as Renal Artery Stenosis (RAS), collaterals may develop to bypass the narrowed segment of the artery, although these are variable.

Option C: Spleen

  • Arteries in the spleen are end-arteries.
  • Such arteries have no anastomoses with their neighboring arteries.
  • So, collateral circulation is not seen in it.
  • Although spleen is devoid of extensive anastomotic networks, spleen is still capable of developing some form of collateral circulation under certain conditions. It may not be as robust or as immediately effective as in other organs.
  • In conditions leading to gradual occlusion (chronic vascular occlusive conditions) of the splenic artery or its major branches, collateral vessels may form from nearby vascular structures, such as the short gastric arteries or the left gastroepiploic artery, to maintain splenic perfusion. These collaterals can develop over time in response to chronic vascular occlusive conditions, providing an alternative blood supply to the spleen and potentially preventing total infarction.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man experiences hemorrhagic shock following a road accident and significant blood loss. Which center in the central nervous system initially receives signals from the diminished firing of carotid baroreceptors due to hypovolemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - NTS (Nucleus Tractus Solitarius):

  • NTS initially receives signals from the diminished firing of carotid baroreceptors due to hypovolemia

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - RVLM (Rostral Ventrolateral Medulla):

  • In hemorrhagic shock, blood pressure decreases, and the baroreceptors are activated at low levels.
  • The vasomotor center(VMC), also known as RVLM (Rostral Ventrolateral Medulla), gets activated and restores the blood pressure and heart rate.

Option C - Nucleus Ambiguus:

  • Nucleus ambiguus is not involved in the control of blood pressure.

Option D - Raphe Nucleus:

  • The raphe nuclei are not primarily associated with the regulation of cardiovascular responses to changes in blood volume.

questions.text: Which one of the following is present in both Serum and Plasma?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B: Factor VII

  • Factor VII is present in plasma and is also stable in serum (“Noble factor”).
  • It is a part of the extrinsic pathway of coagulation
  • It is also known as Proconvertin.
  • A deficiency of factor VII is a rare disorder.

PLASMA:

  • Plasma, also known as blood plasma, appears light-yellowish or straw-colored. It serves as the liquid base for whole blood.
  • Whole blood minus erythrocytes (RBCs), leukocytes (WBCs), and thrombocytes (platelets) makes up plasma
  • Serum, sometimes mistakenly synonymous with plasma, consists of plasma without fibrinogen.
  • Plasma contains 91% to 92% of water and 8% to 9% of solids.
  • It comprises:
    1. Coagulants, mainly fibrinogen, help in blood clotting
    2. Plasma proteins, such as albumin and globulin, help to maintain the colloidal osmotic pressure at about 25 mmHg
    3. Electrolytes like sodium, potassium, bicarbonate, chloride, and calcium helps to maintain blood pH
    4. Immunoglobulins help to fight infection and various other lesser amounts of enzymes, hormones, and vitamins

Incorrect options

Option A: Fibrinogen

This is false because:

  • Factor I (Fibrinogen) is deficient in serum.

Option C: Factor V

This is false because:

  • Factor V (Labile/Proaccelerin) is deficient in serum.

Option D: Factor II

This is false because:

  • Factor II (Prothrombin) is deficient in serum.

questions.text: The relation between intravesical pressure and volume can be studied by inserting a catheter, emptying the bladder, and then recording the pressure. At the same time, the bladder is filled with 50-mL increments of water or air (cytometry). A plot of intravesical pressure against the fluid volume in the bladder is called a Cystometrogram. The first urge to void is felt at which of the following point?
questions.solution:
Option C: Phase Ib of Cystometrogram

  • The plateau phase lasts until the bladder volume is 400 mL. The first urge to void is felt at a bladder volume of about 150 mL and a marked sense of fullness at about 400 mL. The flatness of segment Ib is a manifestation of the law of Laplace.

Cystometry:

  • Cystometry refers to the process of studying the relationship between the intravesical volume and pressure; the Cystometrogram refers to a visual record of this relationship.
  • Normal Cystometrogram shows three phases of filling:
    • Phase Ia: It is the initial phase of filling in which pressure rises from 0 to 10 cm H2O when about 50 mL of fluid is collected in the bladder
    • Phase Ib is the plateau phase that lasts until the bladder volume is 400 mL. The first urge to void is felt at a bladder volume of about 150 mL and a marked sense of fullness at about 400 mL. The flatness of segment Ib is a manifestation of the law of Laplace.
    • Phase II: This phase starts beyond 400 mL volume when the pressure begins to rise and hence triggers the micturition reflex

 

Option A: Bladder volume of 400 mL

  • The first urge to void is felt at a bladder volume of about 150 mL and a marked sense of fullness at about 400mL.

Option B: Phase Ia of Cystometrogram

  • It is the initial phase of filling in which pressure rises from 0 to 10 cm H2O when about 50 mL of fluid is collected in the bladder.

Option D: Phase II of Cystometrogram

  • This phase starts beyond 400 mL volume when the pressure begins to rise markedly, triggering the micturition reflex.

questions.text: Central diabetes insipidus is caused by a lack of ADH secretion. In a patient affected by severe lack of ADH secretion, which of the following parts of the tubule would have the lowest tubular fluid osmolarity?
questions.solution:
Answer : Option B   Descending loop of Henle The descending limb is permeable to water but not to solutes. In the absence of ADH, water reabsorption in the descending limb is impaired, leading to further dilution of the tubular fluid. This segment is where the tubular fluid osmolarity would be the lowest in a patient with central diabetes insipidus.

Option A: Proximal convoluted tubule

  • About 70 % of the water is reabsorbed in the proximal tubule.

Option C: Thick ascending loop of Henle  The thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle is relatively impermeable to water even under conditions of maximal antidiuresis. Water permeability of the late distal and collecting tubules increases markedly during antidiuresis because of increased levels of ADH.

Option D: Collecting ducts 

  • .In central diabetes insipidus, where ADH is lacking, the collecting ducts are unable to reabsorb water effectively, resulting in the excretion of large volumes of dilute urine. Therefore, the tubular fluid osmolarity in the collecting ducts is also low.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man comes to the clinic for a follow-up visit. He has a medical history of hypertension which is under control with medications. He smokes two packs of cigarettes daily, and his BMI is 31 kg/m2. He is advised to perform regular aerobic and muscle strength exercises along with a reduction in smoking. Regarding exercise, which of the following statement is false?

choices.text: The oxyhemoglobin dissociation curve moves to the left.

questions.solution:
Option D: The oxyhemoglobin dissociation curve moves to the left

  • The response to exercise depends upon its intensity and duration.
  • During aerobic and strength training exercises, the requirements for oxygen increase.
  • During exercise, numerous alterations in the chemical and mechanical cardiovascular and ventilator functions exist to meet the metabolic demands of the skeletal muscles.
  • During exercise, the increase in ventilation is proportional to the rise in carbon dioxide production and oxygen consumption.
  • PCO2 increases with exercise because during exercise, the muscle work harder, resulting in increased consumption of oxygen which produces more oxygen.
  • Haemoglobin is fully saturated throughout exercise in individuals with normal respiratory function.
  • Similarly, the respiratory exchange ratio, i.e. the CO2 production/O2 uptake, increases as the intensity of exercise increases.
  • The value of this ratio gives us an indication of whether the body is performing aerobically or anaerobically.
  • In the oxyhemoglobin dissociation curve, exercise causes a right shift due to increased body temperature, carbon dioxide and decreased pH due to a rise in lactic acid production.

Option A: PCO2 increases with exercise

  • During exercise, the requirement for energy increases which causes the tissues to utilize more oxygen.
  • This increased utilization of oxygen results in increased production of CO2.

Option B: Oxygen consumption increases

  • During exercise, the requirement for energy increases which causes the tissues to utilize more oxygen.

Option C: Respiration exchange ratio increases

  • It is the ratio of the volume of carbon dioxide produced and the proportion of oxygen used.
  • It increases with the intensity of exercise.

questions.text: Where are J-Receptors (Juxta-pulmonary capillary receptors) located?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Alveolar walls:

  • J receptors, or juxta-pulmonary capillary receptors, are located in the alveolar walls near the pulmonary capillaries.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - MainBronchi:

  • Main bronchi contain pulmonary stretch receptors, not J receptors.

Option B - Pulmonary capillary walls:

  • J receptors are located near pulmonary capillaries but not within the capillary walls themselves.

Option C - Wall of the trachea:

  • Pulmonary stretch receptors are present in the trachea, not J receptors.

questions.text: Which system has the best degree of temporal and spatial fidelity in transmitting somatosensory information?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B: Dorsal column–medial lemniscal system

  • The dorsal roots of spinal nerves are the entry points for almost all sensory data from the somatic parts of the body. Sensory information entering the spinal cord is primarily transmitted to the brain via two major pathways: the dorsal column-medial lemniscal (DCML) system, which carries information about fine touch, proprioception, and vibration; and the anterolateral system (also known as the spinothalamic tract), which transmits information about pain, temperature, and coarse touch. The thalamus is a relay station for sensory information from these tracts to the cerebral cortex.
  • As its name suggests, the dorsal column-medial lemniscal system primarily sends impulses through the spinal cord's dorsal columns upward to the brain's medulla. The impulses then proceed upward through the brain stem and the medial lemniscus to the thalamus after synapsing and crossing to the opposing side in the medulla.
  • Because the nerve fibers of the dorsal column and medial lemniscal system are highly spatially oriented at their points of origin, they can transfer sensory data quickly and accurately in both time (temporal) and space (spatial).

 

Incorrect Options

Option A: Anterolateral system

  • In contrast to the dorsal column medial lemniscus system, the anterolateral system has substantially less spatial orientation and transmits sensations that do not need a fast or precise spatial transmission.
  • In contrast to the dorsal system, the anterolateral system can transmit a wide range of sensory modalities, including pain, warmth, cold, and basic tactile sensations. Only a few types of mechanoreceptive sensations are available to the dorsal system.

Option C: Corticospinal system

  • The corticospinal tract, also known as the pyramidal tract, is an output tract that relays information from the motor cortex to the spinal cord.
  • It does not transmit somatosensory information.
  • The ventral corticospinal tract and medial descending brainstem pathways (tectospinal, reticulospinal, and vestibulospinal tracts) are concerned with adjustments of proximal muscles and posture, and the lateral corticospinal and rubrospinal tracts are concerned with distal limb muscles and, particularly in the case of the lateral corticospinal tract, with skilled voluntary movements.
     

Option D: Spinocerebellar system

  • Dorsal and ventral spinocerebellar tracts carry impulses directly to the cerebellum from the body's periphery.
  • It primarily conveys information to the ipsilateral (same side) cerebellum. The dorsal tract conveys proprioceptive and other sensory information from the periphery to the cerebellum for processing.
  • Muscle spindles are the primary source of the signals that go via the dorsal spinocerebellar tracts, with smaller contributions coming from Golgi tendon organs, big tactile receptors on the skin, and joint receptors.
  • The peripheral receptors provide substantially less information to the ventral spinocerebellar pathways. Instead, they are primarily stimulated by motor impulses that enter the anterior horns of the spinal cord via (2) internal motor pattern generators inside the cord and (3) the brain through the corticospinal and rubrospinal tracts.

questions.text: Which bodily component is medially represented inside the postcentral gyrus?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Lower limb:

  • The lower limb is medially represented inside the postcentral gyrus, as shown in the sensory homunculus.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Upper limb:

  • The upper limb is represented along the lateral side of the postcentral gyrus.

Option C - Abdomen:

  • The abdomen has its representation beneath the regions handling sensation for the mouth, tongue, and throat.

Option D - Genitalia:

  • The genitalia are represented in the medialmost area of the somatosensory homunculus.

questions.text: Three days after starting a new drug for malaria prophylaxis, a 19-year-old college student had dark-colored urine and fatigue, scleral icterus, and poikilocytes with bite-shaped irregularities. Which drugs will the patient most likely be taking?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Primaquine:

  • Antimalarial medication inducing oxidative stress in RBCs, potentially leading to hemolytic anemia in individuals with G6PD deficiency.
  • Symptoms include sudden pain, jaundice, dark urine, and transient splenomegaly, with characteristic blood smear findings of bite cells and Heinz bodies.
  • Contraindicated in G6PD deficiency.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Metronidazole:

  • Metronidazole forms toxic free radical metabolites in bacterial cells, damaging DNA, but it does not precipitate hemolytic episodes in G6PD deficient patients.

Option D - Erythromycin:

  • Erythromycin is a macrolide antibiotic that inhibits bacterial protein synthesis but does not cause hemolysis in G6PD deficiency.

Option B - Albuterol:

  • Albuterol, a beta2 agonist, relaxes bronchial smooth muscles by stimulating β2 adrenergic receptors. It is not associated with hemolysis in G6PD deficiency.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs can be given without the need for therapeutic dose monitoring after calculating the required dose based on the patient's weight, unlike drugs with a narrow therapeutic index?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Penicillin:

Therapeutic index:

  • It is a quantitative measurement of the relative drug safety profile.
  • Penicillin has a wide therapeutic index and does not require therapeutic dose monitoring (TDM).
  • A drug having a high therapeutic index possesses a favourable safety and efficacy profile.
  • Drugs with a narrow therapeutic index require close therapeutic dose monitoring as they possess a high risk of adverse events.
  • TDM is only for drugs with narrow therapeutic index, whose values cannot be monitored by simple laboratory parameters and have inconsistent/ erratic pharmacodynamics.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Amikacin:

  • Amikacin is an aminoglycoside with a narrow therapeutic index, it requires close TDM.

Option C - Phenytoin:

  • Phenytoin has a narrow therapeutic window and it requires TDM.

Option D - Cyclosporine:

  • Cyclosporine is a narrow therapeutic index drug that can cause kidney injury at high doses.
  • Hence, it requires close TDM.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl presents to the doctor complaining of a headache right above the nape of her neck and nausea for 1 month. The doctor suspects it could be of hypertensive origin and orders a battery of tests. It is noted that the serum cortisol levels and ACTH levels are normal, but an ultrasound kidney, ureter, and bladder reveals renal artery stenosis. Since the patient has moderate hypertension, which of the following drug should be given to this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Thiazide

  • Renal artery stenosis is a disease in which atherosclerosis occurs in the arteries that carry blood to the kidney. It can lead to hypertension and damage to the kidney.
  • RAS is mostly seen in older people and can be unilateral or bilateral. The prolonged RAS can lead to kidney failure.
  • Patients with RAS should be given diuretics as the first line of medical treatment. They can reduce the blood pressure in renal arteries by removing salt and water from the kidney, increasing urine output. Thiazide is a diuretic that is given in RAS.

Option B: Guanethidine

  • Guanethidine is also used in the treatment of renal artery stenosis. It is an adrenergic neuron blocker that blocks the action of adrenaline on neuronal alpha 2 adrenoceptors.
  • It also blocks the alpha and beta-adrenoceptor-mediated effects of released adrenaline. But does not blocks any effect of injected adrenaline.

Option C: Lisinopril

  • Lisinopril is an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor used to treat blood pressure. It is used in the treatment of renal artery stenosis.
  • ACE inhibitors can be given in unilateral RAS but are contraindicated in bilateral renal artery stenosis due to the risk of azotemia.

Option D: Pseudoephedrine

  • It is a sympathomimetic drug that is used to relieve nasal congestion.
  • Pseudoephedrine is contraindicated in renal artery stenosis. It is a decongestant that can increase blood pressure and damage the kidney.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female presents to the outpatient department with nausea and a pulsating headache on the left side of the head for 2 hours. The patient tells the doctor that he has been having episodes of similar headaches for the past 8 months On examination, the patient seems sensitive to light . Which of the following medications can be given by the doctor in this condition?
questions.solution:
Option A: Ergotamine

  • Ergotamine act as a partial agonist at the alpha adrenoreceptor and an agonist at the dopamine receptor. It can cause strong constriction of blood vessels due to its partial agonist activity. Ergotamine is very effective in the acute attack of migraine. It can cause spasms of coronary arteries in variant angina and can be used for diagnostic purposes.
  • Migraine is a complex neurological disease that is very common and affects more than 1 billion people worldwide. It can be of many types depending upon the symptoms and episodes.
  • It typically presents with unilateral headache, which is pulsatile in nature, nausea or vomiting, photophobia, and phonophobia. It impacts the entire nervous system, disturbing a person's normal activity.

  • Acute treatment of migraines: Ergotamine is typically used as an acute treatment for migraines. It is available in different formulations, including oral tablets, sublingual tablets, rectal suppositories, and nasal sprays. When taken at the onset of a migraine attack, ergotamine can help alleviate the symptoms and reduce the severity and duration of the migraine.

  • Mechanism of action: Ergotamine primarily acts on serotonin (5-HT) receptors, particularly the 5-HT1D subtype. It binds to these receptors, causing vasoconstriction (narrowing of blood vessels) and reducing the inflammation associated with migraines. Additionally, ergotamine has some partial agonist activity at alpha-adrenergic and dopamine receptors.

Option B: Phenoxybenzamine

  • It is nonselective, linking covalently to both alpha 1 and alpha 2 receptors. Phenoxybenzamine prevents vasoconstriction of peripheral blood vessels by endogenous catecholamines.
  • It is used in the treatment of pheochromocytomas. This drug is also effective in frostbite, acrocyanosis, and Raynaud disease.

Option C: Prazosin

  • Prazosin is a selective competitive blocker of the alpha-1 receptor. It is useful in the treatment of hypertension in contrast to phenoxybenzamine.
  • It acts as a dilator by dilating arteries and veins that decrease the preload and afterload, increasing cardiac output.

Option D: Phentolamine

  • It is an alpha-adrenergic blocking agent that produces a competitive block of alpha 1 and 2 receptors.
  • Phentolamine is also a vasodilator used in the short-term management of pheochromocytoma. It is also used to prevent dermal necrosis locally.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the physician with complaints of nausea, redness, swelling and pain at the bite site for 4 hours. He further gives the history that he was bitten by a spider while he was parking his car in the garage. He says that he had washed his hand immediately after the bite. He also started to develop tremors till the time he arrived at the hospital. The patient has no history of any chronic illness. He is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examination reveals no abnormalities. The spider that has bitten the patient is shown in the image below. The spider involved in this case is known to produce a toxin that causes which of the following?

choices.text: Blocking Active transport of Ach into the synaptic vesicle

questions.solution:
Option A: Excess release of acetylcholine

  • This is a case of spider bite in which the patient presents to the physician with complaints of nausea, redness, swelling and pain at the bite site for 4 hours. He further gives the history that he was bitten by a spider while he was parking his car in the garage. He says that he had washed his hand immediately after the bite.
  • The patient also started to develop tremors till the time he arrived at the hospital.
  • All these symptoms suggest excess acetylcholine release.
  • The spider shown in the image is a black widow spider.
  • The black widow spider produces a toxin which is known as alpha-latrotoxin.
  • It induces a massive release of acetylcholine.

Option B: Decrease the release of acetylcholine

  • The release of acetylcholine can be decreased by: Botulinum toxin

Option C: Inhibits synthesis of acetylcholine

  • The synthesis of acetylcholine can be inhibited by Hemicholinium (HC3) blocks choline uptake (the rate-limiting step in Ach synthesis) and depletes Ach.

Option D: Blocking Active transport of Ach into the synaptic vesicle

  • Active transport of Ach into the synaptic vesicle is Inhibited by vesamicol.

questions.text: How might clonidine, given intravenously to a 60-year-old hypertensive man experiencing nausea, vomiting, and headache, contribute to increased blood pressure?

choices.text: Release of noradrenaline from adrenergic nerve endings
Agonistic action on vascular α2 adrenergic receptors

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Agonistic action on vascular α2 adrenergic receptors:

  • Clonidine initially acts on α2B receptors in blood vessels, causing vasoconstriction and a mild increase in blood pressure.
  • It then reaches the CNS, acting on α2A receptors, decreasing noradrenaline release, and leading to a subsequent decrease in blood pressure.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Stimulation of the vasomotor center: Clonidine reduces noradrenaline release in the anterior hypothalamus, suppressing excitatory cardiovascular neurons, leading to decreased blood pressure.

Option B: Release of noradrenaline from adrenergic nerve endings: Alpha-2 adrenergic agonists inhibit noradrenaline release, rather than promoting it.

Option D: Cardiac stimulation: Although clonidine initially reduces heart rate and stroke volume, peripheral vascular resistance is typically decreased, resulting in an overall decrease in blood pressure.

questions.text: What additional anti-hypertensive drug, focusing on peripheral effects, might be prescribed to a 47-year-old woman already taking atenolol for hypertension?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Prazosin:

  • Alpha-1 blocker that inhibits alpha-adrenergic receptors, causing arterial and venous dilation, reducing blood pressure.
  • Used for hypertension, symptoms of an enlarged prostate, nightmares from PTSD, heart failure, and Raynaud syndrome.
  • Administered orally, acts peripherally without central mechanism

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Bisoprolol:

  • Beta blocker, cardio-selective for beta-1 at low doses.
  • Decreases blood pressure and heart rate by reducing sympathetic nervous system output.
  • Used for hypertension and heart failure.

Option B - Methyldopa:

  • Lowers blood pressure by central inhibition of alpha-adrenergic receptors or reduced plasma renin activity.
  • Used for hypertension, hypertensive crisis, and preferred for mild to moderate hypertension in pregnancy.

Option C - Clonidine:

  • Stimulates central alpha receptors, reducing sympathetic outflow, peripheral vascular resistance, heart rate, and blood pressure.
  • Used for hypertension, management of withdrawal symptoms, pain relief (epidurally), and ADHD treatment.

questions.text: A 57-year-old lady with a traveling job presents to the endocrinologist for her general check-up. She is a known case of diabetes for which she takes metformin 500mg daily. On examination, her blood pressure was 164/102 mmHg, and she had a pulse rate of 80 per minute. The endocrinologist has decided to put on her anti-hypertensive medicine. Which of the following is the most suitable drug for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Losartan:

  • Based on the medical history of diabetes and high blood pressure, the most suitable drug for this patient will be Losartan. ACE inhibitors and angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs) are effective agents in diabetic patients with hypertension. They also reduce the risk of diabetic nephropathy.
  • Blocks angiotensin II type 1 receptors, inhibiting vasoconstriction and aldosterone secretion.
  • Indicated for hypertension, hypertension with left ventricular hypertrophy, and nephropathy in Type 2 diabetes.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Atenolol:

  • Beta blocker, selective for beta1 receptors.
  • Used for hypertension, angina pectoris, post myocardial infarction, and thyrotoxicosis.

Option C - Clonidine:

  • Centrally-acting anti-hypertensive.
  • Stimulates central alpha receptors, reducing sympathetic outflow, heart rate, and blood pressure.
  • Not ideal for patients with frequent travel due to potential for missed doses.

Option D - Hydrochlorothiazide:

  • Thiazide diuretic, inhibits sodium and chloride reabsorption.
  • Increases urine excretion of sodium, potassium, and bicarbonate.
  • Used for hypertension, edema, and hypertension in heart failure.

questions.text: A 28-year-old young male has a seizure disorder characterized by rigidity of all limbs followed in 20-30 sec by massive jerking involving the entire body. This jerking phase lasts for 1-3 min. What is the antiepileptic drug of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Valproic acid:

  • The diagnosis of this patient is generalized tonic-clonic seizure (GTCS) or grand mal epilepsy.
  • Valproate is an anticonvulsant that increases Na+ channel inactivation and GABA concentration by inhibiting GABA transaminase.
  • It is a first-line medication for the prevention of tonic-clonic seizures but can also be used for treating partial (focal) seizures.
  • It is also used for prophylaxis for migraines, myoclonic seizures, and bipolar disorder.
  • Generalized Tonic-Clonic Seizures (GTCS): Initial medications include valproic acid, lamotrigine, and topiramate.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Clonazepam:

  • Benzodiazepine used for absent seizures, myoclonic seizures, panic disorder, anxiety.
  • Associated with sedation and tolerance.
  • Often used for actively convulsing patients.

Option B - Ethosuximide:

  • Drug of choice for absence seizures.
  • Can be taken alone or in combination with other antiseizure drugs like valproic acid.
  • Administered orally, typically well-tolerated.

Option C - Fosphenytoin:

  • Water-soluble phenytoin prodrug given intravenously for convulsive status epilepticus.
  • Used short-term to distribute phenytoin safely.

questions.text: A 33-year-old presents to the clinic. The patient has a history of seizures for which she takes valproic acid. She had unprotected intercourse a few weeks ago and missed her period. The home pregnancy test was positive. She is now concerned that the antiepileptic medicine she takes will affect her child. Apart from changing her medication, Which of the following should be prescribed to her to decrease the risk of neural tube defects?
questions.solution:
Option A: Folic acid

  • Folic acid should be given at higher doses(up to 5mg/day) to reduce the baby's risk development of neural tube defects if it is at high risk (valproate use)
  • The risk of neural tube defects is increased with many antiepileptic drugs, including valproic acid in pregnancy.

Option B: Vitamin A

  • Vitamin A at high doses is contraindicated during pregnancy as it is a teratogen and can cause cleft palate and cardiac defects.
  • A negative pregnancy test and two forms of contraception are required before prescribing isotretinoin.

Option C: Vitamin E

  • Vitamin E deficiency causes demyelination of posterior columns and spinocerebellar tract, resulting in decreased proprioception, vibration sensation and ataxia.
  • The neurologic defect may mimic the one caused by vitamin B12 deficiency, but it will lack megaloblastic anaemia, hyper-segmented neutrophils, and increased serum methylmalonic acid.

Option D: Pyridoxine

  • Pyridoxine supplementation is advised in peripheral neuropathy caused by oral contraceptives or isoniazid.

questions.text: A 37-year-old patient presents to the ophthalmology OPD with complaints of eye pain, nausea, and headache associated with blurred vision with coloured halos for 4 days. The general physical examination was unremarkable. On ocular exam, there is a hazy cornea, the pupils are non-reactive, and the angle of the anterior chamber is completely closed. Which of the following medication would be given to this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Timolol

  • Based on the symptoms and signs, the diagnosis is angle-closure glaucoma. In the given scenario, a beta-antagonist drug, timolol, will be used.
  • Timolol is a non-selective beta-adrenergic receptor blocker.
  • It reduces intraocular pressure by reducing the production of aqueous humour.
  • It should be administered twice a day.

Option A: Corticosteroids

  • In the given scenario, corticosteroids will not be used.
  • Corticosteroids, used frequently as anti-inflammatory drugs, can increase the risk of glaucoma by raising the intraocular pressure when administered exogenously (topically, peri-ocularly, or systemically) and in certain conditions such as Cushing's syndrome.

Option C: Ipratropium

  • In the given scenario, ipratropium will not be used.
  • Beta-agonist drugs can increase intraocular pressure, which can aggravate angle-closure glaucoma.
  • Ipratropium is used to help control the symptoms of pulmonary diseases such as asthma, chronic bronchitis, and emphysema.

Option D: Atropine

  • Atropine is an anti-cholinergic that acts via nonselective muscarinic receptor blockade.
  • Anti-cholinergic drugs are contra-indicated in angle closure glaucoma because they increase the IOP by closing the canal of Schlemm.

questions.text: Selective estrogen receptor modulators (SERMs), also known as estrogen receptor agonists/antagonists, are drugs that act on the estrogen receptor. A characteristic that distinguishes these substances from pure ER agonists and antagonists (that is, full agonists and silent antagonists) is that their action is different in various tissues, thereby granting the possibility to inhibit or stimulate estrogen-like action in various tissues selectively. Which of the following is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM)?
questions.solution:
Option C: Raloxifene

  • Raloxifene and Tamoxifen are the two well-known SERMs.
  • Raloxifene is a selective estrogen receptor modulator.
  • It is a partial estrogen agonist in the bone and cardiovascular system but an antagonist in the endometrium and breast.
  • Several long-term multicentric studies have shown that raloxifene prevents bone loss in postmenopausal women; bone mineral density (BMD) may increase by 0.9–3.4% over the years in different bones, particularly the lumbar vertebrae.
  • However, accelerated bone loss occurs when raloxifene is stopped.
  • The risk of vertebral fracture is reduced to half, but not that of long bones.
  • Raloxifene is less productive than bisphosphonates in preventing fractures.
  • In postmenopausal women, raloxifene reduces LDL cholesterol by upregulating hepatic LDL receptors.
  • In contrast to estrogen HRT, there is no increase in HDL and triglyceride levels.
  • Follow-up studies have shown that raloxifene reduces the risk of breast cancer by 65%, though the protection was confined to ER-positive breast cancer. 
  • Raloxifene does not stimulate endometrial proliferation, and there is no increase in the risk of endometrial carcinoma.
  • No relief of menopausal vasomotor symptoms occurs; rather, hot flushes may be induced in some women.

Option A: Danazol

  • Danazol belongs to a class of drugs called Androgens

Option B: Mifepristone

  • Mifepristone is a cortisol receptor blocker used to treat Cushing's syndrome and to terminate pregnancies.

Option D: Dantrolene

  • Dantrolene is a muscle relaxants.
  • Used in chronic muscle spasms caused by conditions such as cerebral palsy, multiple sclerosis, stroke, or spinal cord injury.
  • Also used in malignant hyperthermia and Neuroleptic malignant syndrome

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient presents to the clinic with a 3-week history of feeling sad and having a decreased interest in previously enjoyed activities. The patient also reports feeling guilty and worthless, experiencing easy fatigability, and having difficulty concentrating. There have been significant changes in appetite and weight, with a 7% weight loss over the past month. The patient has been experiencing psychomotor retardation and has been having suicidal thoughts. On further questioning, the patient mentioned having difficulty falling asleep and waking up at least 2 hours before the usual time. Based on these symptoms, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is A: Major depressive disorder

  • The patient's symptoms align with the criteria for major depressive disorder according to the DSM-5. The presence of a sad/depressed mood, decreased interest/anhedonia, feelings of guilt/worthlessness, decreased energy/fatigue, decreased concentration, appetite changes with significant weight loss, psychomotor retardation, suicidal thoughts, and sleeping disturbances (early morning insomnia) supports a diagnosis of major depressive disorder.
  • Symptoms persist for at least two weeks.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Bipolar disorder

  • For bipolar disorder , the DSM-5 criteria require the presence of manic or hypomanic episodes, which are distinct periods of abnormally and persistently elevated, expansive, or irritable mood. These episodes must last for at least one week for a diagnosis of bipolar I disorder and at least four days for a diagnosis of bipolar II disorder. The scenario does not mention any manic or hypomanic symptoms, making major depressive disorder a more likely diagnosis than bipolar disorder.

Option C - Generalized anxiety disorder

  • For generalized anxiety disorder, the DSM-5 criteria state that excessive worry and anxiety must be present for at least six months for a diagnosis of generalized anxiety disorder. The scenario does not provide sufficient information to support a diagnosis of generalized anxiety disorder.

Option D - Post-traumatic stress disorder

  • Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is characterized by symptoms that develop after exposure to a traumatic event, such as intrusive thoughts, flashbacks, nightmares, avoidance, and hyperarousal. For post-traumatic stress disorder,, the DSM-5 criteria specify that symptoms must persist for at least one month and cause significant distress or impairment in functioning. While the patient in the scenario is experiencing distressing symptoms, there is no mention of a specific traumatic event or symptoms associated with PTSD.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with persistent sadness, loss of interest in activities, and decreased energy for the past few months. The patient also reports changes in appetite, weight loss, and difficulty sleeping. Based on the symptoms, the patient is diagnosed with major depressive disorder. Which is the most appropriate treatment option for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is B: Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI)

  • The most appropriate treatment option for the patient with major depressive disorder presenting with the described symptoms is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI). SSRIs are commonly used as first-line pharmacotherapy for depression due to their effectiveness in improving depressive symptoms. These medications work by increasing the availability of serotonin, a neurotransmitter involved in mood regulation, in the brain. The delayed onset of action (3-4 weeks) is a characteristic feature of SSRIs.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Cognitive Behavioural Therapy (CBT): While CBT is a valuable and evidence-based psychotherapy for depression, the question specifically asks for a treatment option. CBT alone may be a suitable treatment option for some patients, but in this scenario, pharmacotherapy is more appropriate considering the severity of the symptoms and the need for intervention.

Option C - Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT): ECT is generally reserved for cases of severe or treatment-resistant depression when other treatment modalities have been ineffective. It involves the administration of controlled electric currents to induce a brief seizure, which is believed to have a therapeutic effect on depression. ECT is typically considered when other treatment options have failed or in cases of urgent clinical need.

Option D - Mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR): MBSR is a form of psychotherapy that incorporates mindfulness meditation and stress reduction techniques. While it can be beneficial for managing stress and improving overall well-being, it may not be the primary treatment choice for major depressive disorder. In most cases, MBSR would be used as an adjunct to other treatment modalities, such as medication or psychotherapy.

questions.text: Mr. Smith, an alcoholic, has stopped drinking for the past 24 hours. He presents with coarse tremors, nausea, and sweating. Which stage of alcohol withdrawal is he most likely experiencing?

choices.text: Mild Symptoms (6-8 hours after stopping alcohol)
Moderate Symptoms (8-12 hours after stopping alcohol)
Severe Symptoms (12-24 hours after stopping alcohol)
Life-threatening Symptoms (within 72 hours after stopping alcohol)

questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Mild Symptoms (6-8 hours after stopping alcohol)

  • Based on the timeline provided, Mr. Smith's symptoms of coarse tremors, nausea, and sweating align with the mild symptoms of alcohol withdrawal, which typically occur around 6-8 hours after stopping alcohol.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male patient is admitted to the hospital with complaints of sudden onset confusion, disorientation, and fluctuating levels of consciousness. His family reports that he was previously alert and oriented. The patient appears restless and exhibits inattention during the examination. The healthcare provider notices diffuse slowing of background activity on the patient's EEG. What is the likely diagnosis of this patient, and what would be the appropriate treatment choice?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Delirium; Antipsychotics:

  • Delirium is characterized by acute onset confusion, disorientation, and fluctuating levels of consciousness. Antipsychotic medications, such as haloperidol or olanzapine, are commonly used to manage delirium symptoms, including delusions, hallucinations, and agitation.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Dementia; Benzodiazepines: This option is incorrect. Dementia is characterized by gradual and insidious onset cognitive decline, not sudden onset confusion and fluctuating levels of consciousness. Benzodiazepines are not the treatment of choice for dementia and may even worsen cognitive function and increase the risk of falls and other adverse effects.

Option C - Delirium; Acetylcholinesterase inhibitors: Pharmacotherapy, specifically antipsychotics, is  necessary to manage the symptoms of delirium effectively and not acetylcholinesterase inhibitors

Option D - Dementia; Acetylcholinesterase inhibitors: This option is incorrect. Dementia is characterized by gradual and insidious cognitive decline, whereas the clinical scenario describes a sudden onset of confusion and fluctuating consciousness. Acetylcholinesterase inhibitors, such as donepezil or rivastigmine, are commonly used in the treatment of dementia to improve cognitive function, but they are not the appropriate choice for managing delirium.

questions.text: What should the doctor do when faced with an unconscious 19-year-old female patient who presented to the emergency department, exhibiting signs of hydrocephalus on a non-contrast CT scan, and requiring immediate neurosurgical intervention, while also lacking any accompanying individual or means of identification?

choices.text: Take consent by calling the relatives

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Operate without consent:

  • Since, the patient requires urgent medical intervention and she is unconscious. Also, she has no relatives accompanying her, so their consents couldn’t be taken in this case scenario. She might die if the doctor waits for her relatives to come and give consent.

  • In such a scenario (emergency), section 92 IPC would be taken into consideration.

  • 92 IPC states that: Nothing is an offense which is done in good faith and for the benefit of person (or) the guardian in a situation when taking the consent is not possible (like in emergencies)

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Do not operate without consent: Patient was presented with an emergency requiring urgent neurological intervention. the patient may acquire some irreversible damages and may also lead to the death of the patient, if we wait for consent. Hence, the correct step would be to operate without consent.

Option B - Wait for arrival of relatives: If the doctor waits for the relatives to come to give consent, some irreversible damages to the patient might occur and the condition might become life-threatening.

Option D - Take consent by calling the relatives: Taking consent by calling the relatives might be a good step, but since the patient is in an emergency situation, section 92 IPC permits the doctor to operate without consent.

questions.text: Which among the following is a method of direct local violence to conduct criminal abortion?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Cupping:

  • CUPPING: A form of direct local violence, A mug is turned mouth downwards over a lighted wick and placed on the hypogastrium and the mug is pulled, which results in partial separation of the placenta. This is usually practiced in advanced pregnancy.

Incorrect Options:

Option A/ B/ C - Abortion stick/ Electricity/ Syringing:

  • Higginson's syringing (AIR / Soap water in the uterus), rupturing the membrane (pointed object), abortion sticks, dilation of the cervix (slippery elm bark and drugs), Dilatation and Curettage, air insuﬄation.
  • All these are local methods used in criminal abortion.

questions.text: What is this finding suggestive of:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Antemortem drowning:

  • Violent respiratory struggle causes churring effect, which mixes Mucus + surfactant + water + air & results in production of Froth.

  • In post-mortem drowning as this violent respiratory struggle is missing, froth can't be seen.

  • Thus, it is a sign of Antemortem drowning.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A, C & D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation for the correct answer.

questions.text: A girl was allegedly kidnapped by a man. In court, she says that she is a major and is married to the man, X ray images of her elbow, wrist and pelvis are given. What is the approximate age of the girl?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 21 to 22 years:

Explanation:

  • A method called skeletal age assessment can be used to determine an individual's approximate age based on X-ray images of their elbow, wrist, and pelvis. This method relies on assessing ossification centers and fusion of growth plates in these areas, which occur at predictable ages during development. The X-ray findings are consistent with the girl’s age of 21-22.

  • Findings:

    • Elbow: In a 21-22 year old female, the epiphyseal plates in the elbow region should be closed, indicating the completion of growth and fusion. The bones of the elbow joint, including the humerus, radius, and ulna, should appear fully developed and fused. The joint space should be minimal, and the bony contours should be well-defined.

    • Wrist: At this age, the growth plates in the wrist region should also be closed, indicating the completion of growth. The carpal bones of the wrist, including the scaphoid, lunate, triquetrum, pisiform, trapezium, trapezoid, capitate, and hamate, should be well-formed and have fused together. The bony architecture of the wrist should be well-defined.

    • Pelvis: In a 21-22 year old female, the pelvis should have completed its growth and reached its adult form. The ilium, ischium, and pubis bones of the pelvis should be fully developed and fused. The sacroiliac joints should be stable, and the symphysis pubis should be fused with minimal or no joint space.

Bone Region Epiphyseal Fusion Age (approximate)
Wrist (Lower end of radius & ulna) 17–18 years
Elbow (medial epicondyle, lateral epicondyle, capitulum, etc.) 14–16 years
Pelvis (iliac crest, ischial tuberosity) 18–21 years
Clavicle (medial end) 21–22 years (last to fuse)

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy has been brought to the emergency with complaints of 8 episodes of vomiting. The vomit has bluish-green color and has been associated with severe abdominal pain. On examination, he was seen to be hypotensive and had elevated serum creatinine. On HD 2, a rash appeared on the palms, soles and buttocks. The doctor was able to document the triad of Erythema, Desquamation, and Exfoliation of the skin. This triad is seen in poisoning with which one of the following?
questions.solution:
Option A: Boric acid poisoning

  • Triad of Erythema, Desquamation, and Exfoliation of the skin seen in Boric acid poisoning.
  • Rash is particularly seen on the palms, soles, and buttocks.

Option B: Sulphuric acid poisoning

  • In Sulphuric acid poisoning: The voice becomes hoarse and husky. The lips are usually swollen and blackish. Teeth are chalky-white. The tongue becomes swollen, sodden, and black.

Option C: Phosphorus exposure

  • Fatal dose: 60–120 mg of white phosphorus.
  • Fatal period: Within 24 hrs, but may be delayed by 5–7 days.
  • White or crystalline: Samples of white phosphorus always contain some red phosphorus and therefore appear yellow (also called ‘yellow phosphorus’).
  • Red or amorphous: White phosphorus gradually changes to red phosphorus. This transformation is accelerated by heat and light.

Option D: Carbolic acid poisoning

  • Poisoning by carbolic acid is known as carbolism. Phenol being fat-soluble, attacks the nervous system and causes paralysis of respiratory and CVS centers leading to death.
  • Grayish or brownish corrosions at the angle of the mouth, chin, front of the body, arms and hands with phenolic odor.

questions.text: A 50-year-old farmer has been brought unconscious to the emergency after being discovered in the fields with an empty bottle of an organophosphate compound. The mainstay of medical therapy includes atropine, pralidoxime (2-PAM), and benzodiazepines . In order to achieve adequate atropinization quickly, a doubling approach is typically used. Poisoning with an OP compound is characterized by all of the following, except?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Constipation:

  • Poisoning with an organophosphate (OP) compound is not characterized by constipation; rather, it typically causes diarrhea.

Incorrect Options:

Option A/ B/ D - Pulmonary oedema/ Pinpoint pupil/ Vomiting:

  • GIT: Increased salivation, nausea, vomiting, retro-sternal pain, abdominal cramps, diarrhea, fecal incontinence.
  • CVS: Bradycardia, hypertension.
  • RS: Rhinorrhea, bronchospasm, bronchorrhea, cough, wheezing, dyspnea.May resemble an attack of asthma.
  • Ocular: Blurred vision, miosis (Pinpoint pupil).

questions.text: A 35-year-old obese male who is a case of gynaecomastia planned for webster's procedure under general anaesthesia. After the induction of anaesthesia with Inj.Thiopentone sodium, the reservoir bag collapsed. Guedel's airway was inserted, the oxygen flush valve was activated, and the patient was ventilated and intubated. No other leaks were found in the anaesthesia machine. Which of the following is correct about oxygen flush?

choices.text: Delivery of a flow between 25 and 50 L/minute
Barotrauma and awareness during Anaesthesia, if accidentally activated
Activation if the master switch is on
Delivery of oxygen at 30 psi pressure

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Barotrauma and awareness during Anaesthesia, if accidentally activated:

  • If the oxygen flush valve is accidentally activated, then high pressure of oxygen is delivered to the lung tissues causing a rapid expansion of the lungs, which can cause lung trauma (barotrauma).
  • The oxygen flush valve can deliver flow between 35 to 75 L /minute, depending on the machine and operating pressure (minimum flow is 35 L/minute), directly to the patient's breathing circuit to overcome the circuit leaks or to rapidly increase inhaled oxygen concentration and it bypasses the anaesthetic vaporizers.
  • It can be activated regardless of whether the master switch is turned on or off.
  • A direct tubing connecting the pressure regulator to the O2 flush directs high unmetered flow directly to the common gas outlet.
  • It comes under the components of an intermediate pressure system.
  • Its main use is during mask ventilation, with many leaks between the mask and the patient's face, especially in elderly patients and patients with difficult airways. It is also an acceptable power source for jet ventilation for providing partial, if not total, ventilatory support in most clinical situations.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Delivery of a flow between 25 and 50 L/minute: Delivery of an oxygen flow occurs between 35 and 75 L/minute.

Option C - Activation if the master switch is on: The oxygen flush valve is activated regardless of whether the master switch is off or on.

Option D - Delivery of oxygen at 30 psi pressure: Delivery of oxygen pressure occurs at 55 to 60 psi pressure.

questions.text: A 35-year-old athlete arrives at the emergency department complaining of right knee pain. His medical history is unremarkable. His blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg, and his pulse is 90/minute. Physical examination reveals swelling of the right knee and restricted active and passive motion at the knee due to pain. A knee MRI reveals an anterior cruciate tendon rupture, and surgical repair is planned. Because vecuronium was unavailable, succinylcholine (> 640 mg) was used to anaesthetize the patient for surgery. The patient is now unable to breathe or move his lower limbs. What is the underlying cause of the patient's condition?

choices.text: Succinylcholine muscle paralysis due to fasciculation

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Phase II block:

  • Prolonged apnea can occur due to repeated doses of succinylcholine because of phase 2 block.
  • The mechanism of succinylcholine is divided into two phases. Phase 1 and phase 2
  • Phase I depolarises the neuromuscular junction endplate, which is preceded by muscle fasciculation.
    • It functions similarly to acetylcholine, acting on nicotinic channels and depolarising the endplate.
    • The rapid hydrolysis of succinylcholine by butyrylcholinesterase (plasma cholinesterase) ends the phase I depolarising blockade.
    • No fade during repetitive stimulation
    • No post-tetanic fasciculation
    • Recovery in 4-8 minutes
  • Phase II causes the endplate to repolarise following prolonged succinylcholine exposure.
    • It resembles non-depolarising muscle relaxants.
    • The endplate gets desensitised and is unable to depolarise easily.             
    • Fade during repetitive stimulation (tetanic or TOF)
    • Post-tetanic facilitation (potentiation) is present
    • Recovery takes greater than 20 minutes
    • A cholinesterase inhibitor, such as neostigmine, can be used to counteract phase II block.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Succinylcholine muscle paralysis due to fasciculation:

  • Muscle paralysis due to succinylcholine is a part of Phase I depolarisation.
  • Phase 1 is usually preceded by fasciculation

Option C - Hidden Muscle Dystrophy:

  • Muscle dystrophies are congenital conditions that cause muscles to weaken over time; Duchenne and Becker muscular dystrophies are the most common.
  • Succinylcholine is contraindicated in patients with muscle dystrophies.
  • Because the patient is an athlete with no history of muscle weakness, underlying muscle dystrophy is less likely.

Option D - Pseudocholinesterase deficiency:

  • Pseudocholinesterase degrades succinylcholine at the synapse, reducing its effect.
  • A lack of pseudocholinesterase can prolong the effect of phase I, which is a depolarised state.
  • This patient has flaccid paralysis due to the prolonged effect of Phase II.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man was brought to an emergency room with severe pain in the right iliac fossa for the last 6 days. He also had a mild fever and stomach discomfort for 3 days. His blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg, and his pulse is 100 beats per minute. On ultrasonography, his appendix seemed inflamed. The patient is scheduled for an appendectomy. Which of the following intravenous anaesthetic agents will reduce postoperative nausea and vomiting in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Propofol:

  • Propofol is known for its least adverse effect of postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV) and rapid emergence from anaesthesia.
  • Depending on the risk scoring of postoperative nausea and vomiting, propofol is an ideal anaesthetic agent, especially when used as total intravenous anaesthesia.
  • Propofol at a sub-anaesthetic dose (10 mg) produces direct antiemetic effects.
  • In addition, using propofol for the maintenance of anaesthesia produces a positive effect on PONV reduction.
  • Propofol decreases the level of serotonin in the blood, thereby resulting in the least activation of 5 HT3 receptors in the area postrema of the brain, thereby producing antiemetic effects.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Thiopentone:

  • Thiopentone has no role in decreasing postoperative nausea and vomiting. Instead, it can cause nausea itself.

Option C - Etomidate:

  • Postoperative nausea and vomiting are more common with etomidate. Hence, it has no anti-emetic action itself.

Option D - Ketamine:

  • Ketamine's short-term side effects are nausea, vomiting, dizziness, and high blood pressure.
  • Hence, it has no anti-emetic action itself.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male with a known history of diabetes and hypertension presents as an outpatient for complaints of vomiting, difficulty in articulation, increased sweating, headache, and blurred vision for 1 month.  The patient appears to have an enlarged thyroid, spade-like hands, large feet, and an enlarged lower jaw and tongue with thickened lips and skin. His Mallampati score was assessed to be 4. What could be the most probable diagnosis and the reason for his Mallampatti score?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Acromegaly, enlarged tongue:

  • The patient presents with typical physical features of acromegaly, such as thickened skin, spade-like hands, prominent supra-orbital ridges, increased hat size, and an enlarged tongue. Acromegaly is caused by the hypersecretion of Growth Hormones after puberty in adults.
  • The presenting features, such as vomiting, blurred vision, and headache, are due to the local effects of pituitary adenomas.         
  • Acromegaly occurs after puberty because of the over-secretion of growth hormones after epiphyseal closure.
  • The Modified Mallampatti score is an assessment of the size of the tongue relative to the oropharyngeal opening in order to predict a difficult airway. Since this patient has an enlarged tongue, only the hard palate will be visible so the Mallampatti score is 4. This indicates that it will be difficult to secure the airway when the patient needs one.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Gigantism, enlarged goiter :

  • In gigantism, physical changes occur before puberty
  • The enlarged goiter is not the factor for the oral cavity assessment as in the MPC.

Option C -  Gigantism, enlarged tongue: In gigantism, physical changes occur before puberty.

Option D - Acromegaly, enlarged goiter: The enlarged goiter is not the factor for the oral cavity assessment as in the MPC.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presents to the emergency department with a history of blunt trauma to the chest and abdomen. The patient's blood pressure is 70/50 mmHg. He is tachycardic and dyspneic. On ultra-sonography examination in M mode, the following finding is seen. What could be the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
ANSWER Option D: Pneumothorax

  • Pneumothorax is the collection of air in the pleural space
  • It is a serious potential consequence of blunt thoracic trauma and, if misdiagnosed, it may quickly become life-threatening.
  • The diagnosis of this condition is based on an X-ray, CT Scan, and MRI
  • Treatment is done through a conservative approach or chest tube intubation.

USG findings of pneumothorax:

  • The normal lung interface with pleura shows lung sliding with z-lines, which appear as vertical comet tails running down from the pleural surface.
  • In pneumothorax, this sliding is absent, and so are the comet tail artefacts from the pleura.
  • The sight of even a single B-line excludes pneumothorax at that location.
  • There is also loss of the lung pulse, the subtle lung oscillation in tandem with cardiac contraction, which is especially important when trying to distinguish between right mainstem intubation (failure of sliding on the left, but lung pulse is present) and left-sided pneumothorax (no sliding or lung pulse).
  • Free intrathoracic air will then reflect incident ultrasound waves, obscuring the visceral pleura beneath; while all dynamic signs will be abolished, A-lines will be seen extending into the far field.
  • Visualizing the junction between the sliding lung and absent sliding is known as the lung point sign and is near 100% specific for pneumothorax.
  • One may use the mid-axillary line as a landmark for subsequent semi-quantification of the pneumothorax volume.
  • It cannot be found in all pneumothoraces (sensitivity is around 65%), especially in large pneumothoraces where the lung is collapsed and there is globally absent sliding.
  • On M mode, classical signs for the grey scale imaging are seen: seashore sign: normal lung sliding and barcode/stratosphere sign: pneumothorax

Option A: Pleural effusion

  • Pleural effusion is the collection of fluid in the pleural space, i.e. between the parietal pleura and the visceral pleura of the lung's coverings.
  • An inspiratory decrease in the depth of the outflow, classically demonstrated in M-mode, is the sinusoid sign, a manifestation of intrinsically liquid dynamics (may be absent if extremely viscous)
  • If the underlying lung is submerged in pleural effusion when demonstrated in B-mode, the respiratory dynamics are reminiscent of a jellyfish, hence the jellyfish sign, a subtype of the sinusoid sign

Option B: Bronchial obstruction

  • Bronchial obstruction is the condition in which either one or both of the bronchus may block due to malignancy or any other pulmonary condition

Option C: Lung abscess

  • Ultrasound does not play a recurring role in assessing lung abscesses, as any aerated intervening lung will prevent visualisation.
  • Peripheral abscesses abutting the pleura or with only compressed or consolidated lung may be visible and should not be mistaken for an empyema.
  • The consolidated lung may mimic a fluid collection with low-level echoes.

questions.text: A 53-year-old man presented with sudden visual loss affecting the right temporal region. Ultrasound of the globe demonstrated right-sided retinal detachment with a well-defined flat echogenic mass. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Ocular melanoma

  • Choroidal melanoma is adults' most common primary intraocular malignancy and accounts for 80% of all uveal melanomas.
  • The incidence of this tumor increases with age.
  • Clinical presentation may range from no symptoms over various visual disturbances to visual loss.
  • Ultrasound is an excellent modality for examining the globe and can visualize small plaque-like or discoid uveal melanoma with a thickness of less than 3 mm, which are usually difficult to assess on CT or MRI.
  • Typical USG Features include hypo-to-isoechoic "collar button" or "mushroom" shaped lobulated mass with internal vascularity.

Other options

Option A: Choroidal metastases

  • Choroidal metastases are the most frequent malignant intraocular tumor. In most cases, they arise after identifying the primary tumor and are associated with the involvement of other organs.
  • Less frequently, the ocular lesion may be the first presentation of a primary tumor or relapse of a primary disseminated tumor.
  • Enhanced choroid imaging allows a better understanding and precise diagnosis of choroidal metastases.
  • If the primary remains unknown, tumor biopsy may help identify the primary and guide treatment.
  • To date, fractionated radiotherapy remains the treatment of choice for choroidal metastases.

Option B: Orbital hematoma

  • Orbital hematomas may occur spontaneously due to vascular anomalies, or they may be induced by trauma or occur following paranasal sinus surgery.
  • The retrobulbar hematoma requires special attention because its potential optic nerve compression may compromise vision or cause blindness.
  • Orbital hematoma has been described as a rare complication of trans-nasal endoscopic sinus surgery (<0.4% cases).
  • Other causes were .trauma, vascular malformation, orbital neoplastic or non-neoplastic lesions, bleeding disorders, and barotrauma during anesthesia.

Option D: Ocular hemangioma

  • A hemangioma can grow red to the red-purple raised lesion on the skin and sometimes get very large.
  • When hemangiomas grow on the eyelids, the eye surface, or the eye socket, they can interrupt the normal development of vision. Hemangiomas can affect vision in several ways.
  • These conditions can be life-threatening if they are large or affect a child's airway or another organ.
  • A hemangioma can also be serious if it has uncontrollable bleeding.
  • Where a child's growth is located may cause physical problems.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with recurrent urinary tract infections and left flank pain. She undergoes imaging studies to evaluate her renal anatomy. MRI is given below. No hydronephrosis or calculi are identified. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Pancake kidney

  • Pancake kidney, also known as discoid kidney, is a rare congenital anomaly where both kidneys are fused and form a flat, disc-like structure. It typically occurs on one side of the abdomen. 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Horseshoe kidney: Horseshoe kidney is the fusion of the lower poles of both kidneys, resulting in a U-shaped structure that lies anterior to the aorta and inferior vena cava. It is the most common fusion anomaly of the kidneys.

Option C - Crossed renal ectopia:  Also known as crossed fused renal ectopia, is a congenital condition .

  • One kidney is observed on the right side with its ureter terminating on the right side of the bladder.
  •  Another pelvic calyceal system is observed on the right side, with its ureter terminating on the left side of the bladder.

Option D - Supernumerary kidney: Supernumerary kidney refers to the presence of an additional, small-sized kidney, usually located inferior to the normal kidneys.

questions.text: Provides an image of the blood vessels in the brain to detect a problem with blood flow. Below is a picture of digital subtraction angiography of the carotid artery. Which of the following is the pathology depicted or shown below?

choices.text: Angiofibroma tumour blush in the region supplied by the maxillary artery
Diffused Hemangioma of the head and neck region

questions.solution:
ANSWER Option B: Caroticocavernous fistula

  • Digital subtraction angiography showing Caroticocavernous fistula
  • Prominent blood flow into the Superior ophthalmic vein
  • A dent causing blood or contrast to flow through cavernous sinus → superior ophthalmic vein→ Orbit

Carotid-cavernous fistula:

  • Abnormal communication between the arterial and venous systems within the cavernous sinus in the skull.
  • Type of arteriovenous fistula.
  • Causes pulsatile exophthalmos

Other options

Option A: Angiofibroma tumor blush in the region supplied by the maxillary artery

Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma:

  • Benign tumors arise predominantly in the nasopharynx of adolescent males.
  • This causes a tumor blush in the area provided by a maxillary artery in angiography.

Option C: Pseudoaneurysm of ICA

  • Pseudoaneurysms of the internal carotid artery are less common than true aneurysms comprising 14% of cases.
  • True aneurysms are most commonly due to atherosclerosis or fibromuscular dysplasia.
  • The major cause of pseudoaneurysm is the previous endarterectomy.
  • Other causes include trauma and infections.

Option D: Diffused Hemangioma of the head and neck region

  • Hemangiomas are common benign vascular tumors of infancy characterized by a proliferative growth phase followed by very slow inevitable regression (involution phase) between one to ten years of age.
  • 70% of the lesions are present in the head and neck region.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to the clinic with multiple asymptomatic, well-demarcated, scaly patches on his trunk. On examination, the patches are hypopigmented and do not show any inflammation. The Wood's lamp examination reveals yellowish fluorescence in the affected areas. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C- Pityriasis Versicolor:

  • Pityriasis versicolor, also known as tinea versicolor, is a superficial fungal infection caused by the Malassezia species. It commonly affects young adults and is characterized by multiple well-demarcated, scaly patches that can be hypopigmented, hyperpigmented, or erythematous. The absence of inflammation is a distinguishing feature of this condition. Under a Wood's lamp, the affected areas typically appear yellow-green or coppery-orange fluorescence, which helps confirm the diagnosis.
  • Tinea versicolor is usually a clinical diagnosis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Psoriasis: Psoriasis is a chronic autoimmune condition characterized by well-defined, red, scaly plaques with silvery scales. Unlike pityriasis versicolor, psoriasis typically presents with inflammation and erythema. Additionally, Psoriasis is not associated with fluorescence under a Wood's lamp.
