Option B - Pityriasis rosea: Pityriasis rosea is a common skin condition that usually begins with a single large pink or red patch called a herald patch, followed by the appearance of numerous smaller oval patches in a Christmas tree distribution. Unlike pityriasis versicolor, which is caused by a fungal infection, pityriasis rosea is believed to have a viral etiology. Pityriasis rosea patches are typically pink or red and do not show fluorescence under a Wood's lamp.

Herald Patch

Christmas Tree / Fir Tree Pattern

Option D - Tinea corporis: Tinea corporis, also known as ringworm, is a fungal infection of the skin characterized by annular erythematous patches with central clearing and an active raised border. It commonly affects the body, including the trunk. Unlike pityriasis versicolor, tinea corporis does not cause hypopigmentation and is associated with inflammation and itching. Wood's lamp examination may or may not reveal fluorescence, depending on the causative fungus.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with a brownish-black, non-scaly macule on the palm of his hand. The lesion has been gradually increasing in size over the past few months. On microscopic examination, fungal elements are observed. What is the most likely causative organism responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D- Exophiala werneckii/ Hortaea wernickii:

  • The clinical presentation described is characteristic of Tinea nigra, a superficial fungal infection of the skin. The most common causative organism associated with Tinea nigra is Exophiala werneckii, a pigmented fungus. It typically presents as a well-defined brownish-black or dark brown macule, often on the palms or soles. The lesion is non-scaly and slowly enlarges over time. KOH and microscopic examination: Brown hyphae with light brown septa, confirming the diagnosis of Tinea nigra.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Microsporum canis: Microsporum canis is a dermatophyte fungus that commonly causes Tinea capitis (scalp infection) and occasionally Tinea corporis. It does not cause Tinea nigra.

Option B - Epidermophyton floccosum: Epidermophyton floccosum is another dermatophyte fungus that causes various types of dermatophyte infections. However, it is not associated with Tinea nigra. It commonly causes infections like Tinea cruris (jock itch) and Tinea corporis (ringworm).

Option C - Malassezia furfur: Malassezia furfur is the causative organism of Pityriasis versicolor, which presents as scaly patches with variable pigmentation. It is not associated with Tinea nigra.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a history of chronic plaque psoriasis presents with worsening symptoms. The patient reports increased erythema, scaling, and itchiness in her psoriatic plaques after stopping the treatment under stress as she was not noticing any improvement. Additionally, she notices that her plaques are spreading to previously unaffected areas . Her blood investigations reveal hypocalcemia. What term best describes the current state of her psoriasis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C- Unstable psoriasis:

  • In this clinical scenario, the patient's psoriasis is showing worsening symptoms, including increased erythema, scaling, and itchiness, as well as spreading to new areas as a result of steroid withdrawal suggesting diagnosis of Unstable psoriasis

Incorrect Options:

Option A- Exacerbation: 

  • An exacerbation refers to a temporary worsening or flare-up of a chronic condition, such as psoriasis. While it may partly describe the patient's condition, it does not capture the persistent and progressive nature of the psoriasis in this scenario.

Option B- Stable remission: 

  • Stable remission would indicate a period of time when the patient's psoriasis is under control, with minimal or no active symptoms. This term does not apply to the patient's current condition, as her psoriasis is not in a stable state.

Option D- Psoriatic arthritis: 

  • Psoriatic arthritis is a separate condition that affects some individuals with psoriasis. It involves joint inflammation and is not directly related to the description of the patient's current skin symptoms.

questions.text: A patient presents with a single painless ulcer with a clean base and indurated borders on the genitals. Which stage of syphilis does this presentation indicate, and what is the recommended medical treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Primary syphilis, Benzathine penicillin:

  • The presentation of a single painless ulcer with a clean base and indurated borders on the genitals is characteristic of primary syphilis. The recommended medical treatment for primary syphilis is Benzathine penicillin G (2.4 million units), which is administered as a single intramuscular injection.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Secondary syphilis, Doxycycline:

  • Secondary syphilis is characterized by a systemic rash and flu-like symptoms. Doxycycline is the preferred medication to treat cases with severe penicillin allergy.

Option C - Tertiary syphilis, Ceftriaxone:

  • Tertiary syphilis is the late stage of the disease, which occurs years after the initial infection. It is characterized by the development of severe complications, such as gummas (soft, non-cancerous growths), cardiovascular abnormalities, and neurosyphilis. The presentation of a single painless ulcer with a clean base and indurated borders is more typical of primary syphilis. Ceftriaxone is not the first-line treatment for primary syphilis, it is the preferred medication for neurosyphilis in cases of severe penicillin allergy

Option D - Congenital syphilis, Azithromycin:

  • Congenital syphilis occurs when a pregnant woman with syphilis passes the infection to her unborn child. The presentation described in the question is not indicative of congenital syphilis, as it refers to an ulcer on the genitals of the patient.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female with atticoantral CSOM presents with extensive bone destruction involving the annulus, tympanic bone, ossicles, and tegmen tympani. The patient has a foul-smelling and purulent ear discharge. Which of the following treatment approaches would be the most appropriate for managing this patient's condition?

choices.text: Aural toilet and ear drop administration

questions.solution:
Correct Option D: Reconstructive surgery (e.g., tympanoplasty)

  • In cases of atticoantral CSOM with extensive bone destruction and chronic disease, reconstructive surgery (e.g., tympanoplasty) is often the most appropriate treatment approach.
  • This surgery aims to reconstruct the middle ear structures and restore hearing function.
  • Given the presentation of extensive bone destruction and the need for long-term management, reconstructive surgery would likely offer the best outcome for this patient. Therefore, this choice is more likely to be the most appropriate answer.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Aural toilet and ear drop administration:

  • Aural toilet, which involves removing debris and aural polyps, and administering ear drops (e.g., Neomycin+ Polymyxin + Chloromycetin or gentamicin) are medical treatment options for CSOM.
  • However, in a case of extensive bone destruction and foul-smelling purulent discharge, these measures alone may not be sufficient to manage the condition effectively. Therefore, this choice is less likely to be the most appropriate answer.

Option B - Systemic antibiotics for acute exacerbation:

  • Systemic antibiotics are typically used in cases of acute exacerbation in CSOM.
  • However, in a scenario with extensive bone destruction and chronic atticoantral CSOM, systemic antibiotics alone may not provide adequate control of the disease. Therefore, this choice is less likely to be the most appropriate answer.

Option C - Mastoid x-rays and audiogram assessment:

  • Mastoid x-rays and audiogram assessment are important diagnostic tools to evaluate the extent of bone destruction and the degree of hearing loss in CSOM.
  • While these investigations are essential in the management of CSOM, they are primarily used for evaluation rather than a definitive treatment approach. Therefore, this choice is less likely to be the most appropriate answer.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with vertigo that is provoked by loud noises. Examination reveals a dilated saccule in close proximity to the oval window. Which of the following terms describes this phenomenon?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Tullio's phenomenon

  • The given scenario describes Tullio's phenomenon, which is characterized by vertigo in response to loud noises in patients with Meniere's disease.
  • In Meniere's disease, the dilated saccule lies in close proximity to the oval window, allowing rapid transmission of sound vibrations to the saccule. This results in an imbalance of the macula, leading to vertigo.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Caloric reflex:

  • Refers to the Caloric reflex, which is assessed using the Caloric test to evaluate the function of the vestibular system.

Option C – Recruitment:

  • Refers to Recruitment, a phenomenon seen in cochlear pathologies where there is a disproportionate increase in loudness perception as sound intensity increases.

Option D - Weber test:

  • Refers to the Weber test, which is performed to assess lateralization of sound perception in patients with hearing loss.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with gradually progressive hearing loss in his right ear. Otoscopic examination reveals a whitish plaque on the footplate of the stapes. Microscopic analysis of the lesion shows increased vascularity and spongy bone formation. Which of the following best describes the histological features of this otosclerosis lesion?

choices.text: Increased osteoblastic activity and solid sclerotic bone
Blue appearance on H & E stain due to increased vascularity and bone resorption
Absence of numerous irregular bones and increased number of osteoclasts
Proliferation of osteoclasts and osteoblasts with inactive lesion

questions.solution:
Correct Option B: Blue appearance on H & E stain due to increased vascularity and bone resorption

  • The histological features of an otosclerosis lesion include increased vascularity, osteoclastic and osteoblastic activity, and spongy bone formation. These features are seen on H & E stain as a blue appearance, known as the "blue mantle of Manasse."

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Increased osteoblastic activity and solid sclerotic bone:

  • This choice does not accurately describe the histological features of an otosclerosis lesion. Otosclerosis is characterized by spongy bone formation and increased vascularity, rather than solid sclerotic bone.

Option C - Absence of numerous irregular bones and increased number of osteoclasts:

  • This choice is incorrect as it does not describe the histological features of an active otosclerosis lesion. Active lesions are characterized by the presence of spongy or irregular bones, increased vascularity, and an increased number of osteoclasts and blasts.

Option D - Proliferation of osteoclasts and osteoblasts with inactive lesion:

  • This choice does not accurately represent the histological features of an inactive otosclerosis lesion. Inactive lesions are characterized by solid sclerotic bone and a lack of active disease progression.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male presents with bilateral hearing loss and a feeling of ear fullness. On examination, the tympanic membranes appear normal, and there is no evidence of mobility restriction. Which of the following clinical features is commonly associated with otosclerosis?

choices.text: Flamingo pink hue on the promontory

questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Paracusis willisii

  • Paracusis willisii, which refers to hearing better in noisy environments than in quiet ones, is commonly associated with otosclerosis.
  • It is a specific symptom that can help differentiate otosclerosis from other causes of hearing loss.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Episodic vertigo:

  • Episodic vertigo is not a characteristic feature of otosclerosis. It is more commonly associated with conditions such as Meniere's disease, vestibular neuritis, or benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV).

Option B - Ear pain and discharge:

  • Ear pain and discharge are not typically seen in otosclerosis. These symptoms are more suggestive of conditions such as chronic otitis media or otitis externa.

Option D - Flamingo pink hue on the promontory:

  • The flamingo pink hue on the promontory is a sign known as Schwartz sign, which can be observed in active otosclerotic lesions. It is not a clinical feature commonly experienced by patients with otosclerosis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with a history of recurrent nasal obstruction and occasional blood-stained nasal discharge. On examination, finger-like projections are observed coming from the lateral wall of the nose. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B: Inverted papilloma 

  • The clinical presentation of recurrent nasal obstruction, blood-stained nasal discharge, and finger-like projections from the lateral wall of the nose is consistent with inverted papilloma.

 

Incorrect options

Option A - Inflammatory polyp:

  • Inflammatory polyps typically present with nasal obstruction but do not exhibit finger-like projections from the lateral wall of the nose, as seen in this case. Incorrect.

Option C - Nasal adenocarcinoma:

  • Nasal adenocarcinoma usually presents with symptoms such as nasal obstruction, epistaxis (nosebleeds), and facial pain.
  • It does not exhibit the characteristic finger-like projections seen in inverted papilloma. Incorrect.

Option D - Olfactory neuroblastoma:

  • Olfactory neuroblastoma is a rare malignant tumor that arises from the olfactory epithelium.
  • It typically presents with symptoms such as nasal obstruction, epistaxis, and anosmia (loss of sense of smell).
  • It does not exhibit the characteristic finger-like projections seen in inverted papilloma. Incorrect.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female presents with a small, pearly papule on her forehead. She reports occasional sun exposure without any significant history of sunburn. Examination reveals a raised, translucent nodule with central ulceration. Biopsy confirms basal cell carcinoma. What is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: UV radiation exposure 

  • This is the most significant risk factor for basal cell carcinoma, as mentioned in the text provided.
  • Prolonged exposure to UV rays, especially in regions with high UV exposure like Australia, increases the risk of developing basal cell carcinoma.

 

Incorrect options

Option A - Genetic mutation:

  • While genetic mutations can contribute to the development of certain types of skin cancers, basal cell carcinoma is primarily associated with environmental factors, particularly UV radiation exposure.

Option B - Occupational exposure to chemicals:

  • Basal cell carcinoma is not commonly associated with occupational exposure to chemicals.
  • Other types of skin cancers, such as squamous cell carcinoma, may be more strongly linked to chemical exposure.

Option D - Viral infection:

  • Basal cell carcinoma is not caused by viral infections.
  • Viruses, such as human papillomavirus (HPV), are associated with other types of skin cancers, such as squamous cell carcinoma.

questions.text: A 16-year-old male presents with recurrent unprovoked profuse epistaxis (nosebleeds). Physical examination reveals a mass in the nasopharynx. Further investigations reveal a vascular tumor composed of endothelium-lined blood vessels without a muscular layer. The tumor is non-encapsulated and locally invasive. Based on these findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma:

  • Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is a benign and non-encapsulated tumor that occurs predominantly in adolescent males.
  • The characteristic pathology of this tumor includes endothelium-lined blood vessels without a muscular layer.
  • It is a locally invasive lesion, which explains the recurrent unprovoked profuse epistaxis seen in this patient.
  • Biopsy is not recommended due to the risk of significant bleeding. 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Hemangioma:

  • Hemangiomas are benign tumors composed of proliferating blood vessels. Unlike juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma, hemangiomas usually have a muscular layer in the blood vessels.
  • Moreover, hemangiomas are typically not locally invasive and do not cause recurrent unprovoked profuse epistaxis. 

Option C - Squamous cell carcinoma:

  • Squamous cell carcinoma is a malignant tumor that arises from the squamous epithelial cells.
  • It does not involve blood vessels and is not characterized by the presence of endothelium-lined blood vessels without a muscular layer.
  • Squamous cell carcinoma typically presents with symptoms such as pain, ulceration, and regional lymphadenopathy. 

Option D - Nasal polyps:

  • Nasal polyps are non-neoplastic, inflammatory growths that arise from the nasal mucosa.
  • They are not associated with the characteristic pathology described in the clinical case, which includes the presence of endothelium-lined blood vessels without a muscular layer.
  • Nasal polyps do not cause recurrent unprovoked profuse epistaxis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents with dysphagia and regurgitation of undigested food. Barium swallow reveals a Zenker's diverticulum measuring 4 cm in size. The patient is fit for surgery. What is the most appropriate treatment option for this patient?

choices.text: Endoscopic balloon dilation of the cricopharyngeal muscle.
Excision of pouch and cricopharyngeal myotomy through a cervical approach.

questions.solution:
Correct Option B: Excision of pouch and cricopharyngeal myotomy through a cervical approach.

  • This option involves surgically removing the Zenker's diverticulum and performing cricopharyngeal myotomy through a cervical approach.
  • It is considered the standard treatment for fit patients with symptomatic Zenker's diverticulum, particularly when the diverticulum is large or causing significant symptoms.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Endoscopic balloon dilation of the cricopharyngeal muscle:

  • Endoscopic balloon dilation is a non-surgical treatment option for Zenker's diverticulum.
  • It involves using an endoscope and a balloon catheter to stretch and disrupt the cricopharyngeal muscle, allowing improved food passage.
  • However, in this case, the diverticulum size (4 cm) is relatively large, making endoscopic dilation less effective and surgical intervention more appropriate.

Option C - Observation and conservative management:

  • Observation and conservative management may be considered for patients with small Zenker's diverticula and minimal symptoms.
  • However, in this case, the patient's symptoms and the size of the diverticulum indicate the need for intervention rather than observation alone.

Option D - Gastrostomy tube placement:

  • Gastrostomy tube placement is not a primary treatment option for Zenker's diverticulum. It is typically used for enteral nutrition in patients who cannot tolerate oral feeding due to other reasons

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with blurry vision and a feeling of discomfort in both eyes. On examination, the ophthalmologist notes bilateral corneal edema. Further evaluation reveals dysfunction in a cellular layer responsible for maintaining corneal dehydration and transparency. Which of the following is primarily responsible for the maintenance of corneal dehydration and transparency?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Endothelial cells:

  • Endothelial cells are responsible for maintaining corneal dehydration and transparency.
  • Endothelial cells actively pump excess fluid out of the cornea, keeping it in a dehydrated state.
  • This pumping action, known as the endothelial pump, helps to maintain corneal transparency by preventing swelling and maintaining the optimal corneal thickness.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Epithelial cells: The primary function of the corneal epithelium is to provide a barrier against pathogens and foreign substances.

Option C - Stroma: The corneal stroma contributes to the structural integrity of the cornea.

Option D - Bowman's layer: It provides structural support to the cornea.

questions.text: Which of the following is most commonly employed for measuring the axial length of the eye in preparation for cataract surgery?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Pentacam AXL:

  • Pentacam AXL is the specific type of Penta Cam that is used to measure the axial length of the eye. It is particularly useful for intraocular lens (IOL) power calculation and assessment of corneal ectasia. Axial length measurement is crucial for determining the appropriate power of an IOL to be implanted during cataract surgery or refractive lens exchange. Additionally, it is used for assessing corneal ectasia (principally keratoconus), which refers to the progressive thinning and bulging of the cornea.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Pentacam HR: Pentacam HR is not the correct answer because it is primarily used for preoperative assessment of patients for intraocular phakic IOLs. It provides high-resolution imaging and analysis of the cornea, allowing detailed evaluation before deciding on phakic IOL implantation. It is not specifically designed for measuring the axial length of the eye.

Option C - Pachymeter: A pachymeter is a device used to measure corneal thickness. While corneal thickness is an important parameter in various eye conditions, including glaucoma and keratoconus, it is not specifically used for measuring the axial length of the eye or for IOL power calculation.

Option D - Specular microscopy: Specular microscopy is a technique used to examine endothelial cells in high magnification. It helps assess the number, morphology, and function of endothelial cells. However, it is not used for measuring the axial length of the eye or for IOL power calculation.

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient presents with blurry vision and a flare in the left eye. Upon examination, you noted mild conjunctival injection, anterior chamber cells, and  keratic precipitates. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Anterior uveitis:

  • In the given scenario, the patient's symptoms of blurry vision and flare, along with the examination findings of mild conjunctival injection, anterior chamber cells, and keratic precipitates, are indicative of anterior uveitis.
  • Anterior uveitis is characterized by inflammation in the anterior chamber of the eye, involving the iris and ciliary body and on examination keratic precipitates (fine and grey in non-granulomatous uveitis), mutton fat KPs (granulomatous uveitis), aqueous cells, aqueous flare, iris nodules, posterior synechiae and sectoral iris atrophy are observed.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Episcleritis: Episcleritis is an inflammation of the episcleral tissue, which is a thin layer located between the conjunctiva (outermost layer) and the sclera (white of the eye). It typically presents with localized redness, discomfort, and occasionally mild irritation. Episcleritis does not usually cause anterior chamber cells and flare, nor does it lead to posterior synechiae.

Option C - Keratitis : Keratitis is inflammation of the cornea, the clear front surface of the eye. While it can cause blurry vision, it is more likely to cause symptoms such as eye pain, photophobia (sensitivity to light), and foreign body sensation. Anterior chamber cells and posterior synechiae are not characteristic features of keratitis.

Option D - Conjunctivitis: Conjunctivitis, also known as pink eye, is inflammation of the conjunctiva, the thin membrane covering the white part of the eye. It typically presents with symptoms of redness, itching, discharge, and mild discomfort. While mild conjunctival injection is mentioned in the scenario, the presence of other findings such as anterior chamber cells, flare, and posterior synechiae suggests involvement beyond the conjunctiva, making conjunctivitis less likely.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presents with complaints of a partial loss of vision in the upper temporal field of his left eye. He reports difficulty with peripheral vision in that area. On examination, a visual field test confirms the presence of a localized scotoma in the upper temporal quadrant as shown in the image given below. What type of scotoma is most likely responsible for this patient's visual field defect?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Paracentral scotoma:

  • In this clinical scenario, the patient's complaint of a partial loss of vision in the upper temporal field of the left eye, along with difficulty with peripheral vision in that area, suggests a localized visual field defect. The presence of a scotoma in the upper temporal quadrant on visual field testing as shown in the image is of paracentral scotoma.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Central scotoma: Central scotoma is a loss of vision in the central visual field. It typically affects the central fixation area and is inconsistent with the patient's complaint of a partial loss of vision in the upper temporal field.

Option B - Centrocecal scotoma: Centrocecal scotoma is characterized by a scotoma involving the blind spot (optic disc) and the macula. However, in this scenario, the patient's symptoms and visual field defect are specific to the upper temporal field, which is inconsistent with a centrocecal scotoma.

Option D - Absolute scotoma: Absolute scotoma indicates a complete absence of visual perception within a specific area i.e., a blind spot. While the patient experiences a partial loss of vision in the upper temporal field, an absolute scotoma would result in a complete loss of vision in that area.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presents with watery eyes accompanied by mild discomfort with a gritty feeling for the past 3 days. The patient recently had a respiratory tract infection. The Ophthalmologist performs syringing and says that the patient's lacrimal drainage system is normal. Which etiology is commonly associated with this clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Viral conjunctivitis:

  • In this clinical scenario, a patient presents with watery eyes and mild discomfort, accompanied by a recent respiratory tract infection, and normal lacrimal drainage. The commonly associated etiology is viral conjunctivitis. 
  • The fact that the patient recently had a respiratory tract infection is a clue pointing toward a viral etiology.
  • Viral conjunctivitis, often caused by adenoviruses, can manifest with symptoms such as redness, tearing, irritation, and discharge. It may occur in isolation or as part of a viral prodrome, with concurrent systemic symptoms like fever and upper respiratory symptoms.
  • It is highly contagious and can be transmitted through direct contact with the patient and their secretions. It presents with watery or mucoserous discharge and a burning, gritty or sandy sensation. It can start as a unilateral infection but eventually affects the other eye.
  • On examination, the tarsal conjunctiva may have a follicular appearance. It is mostly self-limiting and will take around 2-3 weeks.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Bacterial conjunctivitis: Bacterial conjunctivitis typically presents with a purulent or mucopurulent discharge, which is inconsistent with the watery discharge described in the scenario.

Option B - Chlamydial conjunctivitis: Chlamydial conjunctivitis is more commonly associated with a mucopurulent discharge rather than a watery discharge. It is often seen in individuals with a history of sexual exposure or genital infections.

Option D - Allergic conjunctivitis: Allergic conjunctivitis is characterized by a watery discharge, which aligns with the symptom described in the scenario. However, the association with a recent respiratory tract infection suggests a viral etiology rather than an allergic one.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl is brought to the ophthalmology department by her parents with complaints that her left eye usually stays crossed since birth. She experiences no problems with her vision. The doctor examines her according to the complaint mentioned above; her condition is shown in the figure below. After assessment of the constitution, what will be the best initial treatment modality for her, chosen by the ophthalmologist?

choices.text: Glasses with the base out of Prism

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Glasses with the base out of prism:

  • Based on the history, the left eye usually stays crossed since birth and with the condition that is shown in the image, the child is likely suffering from esotropia.
  • Esotropia means inward rotation of the eye.

The management include:

  • Small angle esotropia can be corrected with hypermetropic spectacle (glasses with the base out prism). This is the earliest treatment modality for a child with esotropia. By correcting refractive errors, glasses help with the eyes' alignment.
  • Surgical weakening of lateral recuts to reduce inward rotation.
  • Injection of Botulinum toxin in medial recuts.
  • It can either be congenital or acquired.
  • Mostly manifests between the ages 1-8.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Laser therapy:

  • Various forms of laser therapies are used to correct retinal disorders.
  • They form an essential role in the management of diabetic retinopathy.
  • They have no role in any kind of strabismus-related disorders.

Option B - Patching the weak eye:

  • Patching is the technique that is used to prevent amblyopia in children with esotropia.
  • This includes patching the normal eye so the normal eye is used to form strong neural connections and develop normal vision.
  • However, patching the weak eye is counterproductive and will only speed up the process of amblyopia.

Option D - Miotics:

  • Miotics are cycloplegic drugs that are best known to treat amblyopia.
  • They are used as an alternative to a patch. The most common drug is known as Phospholine iodide.
  • Although it is used as an assistant to glasses or surgery.
  • Its use alone is not superior to the use of glasses.

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient with cataracts is scheduled for an ophthalmic investigation to assess the macular region. Considering the patient's condition, which test would be not recommended for evaluating macular function?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT):

  • In a patient with cataracts, the lens of the eye becomes cloudy, impairing the transmission of light to the retina. Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT) relies on clear media to obtain accurate images of the retinal layers. Since cataracts cause opacity in the lens, OCT would be contraindicated in this patient. 
  • OCT aids in the diagnosis of other eye conditions such as: 
    • macular hole, pucker, edema
    • age-related macular degeneration
    • glaucoma
    • central serous retinopathy
    • diabetic retinopathy

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Indocyanine Green Angiography (ICG): This choice is incorrect because ICG is not affected by cataracts. ICG angiography uses infrared light, and cataracts do not significantly affect the transmission of infrared light. Therefore, ICG angiography can still provide valuable information about the macular region in a patient with cataracts.

Option C - USG B Scan : This choice is incorrect because Ultrasound B scan uses sound waves to create images of the eye's internal structures, including the retina and choroid. This technique is not dependent on the clarity of the eye's optical media (like the lens in the case of cataracts), so it can often provide useful information even in the presence of cataracts.

Option D - Fluorescein Angiography: This choice is incorrect because while cataracts may cause some scattering of light, fluorescein angiography uses intravenous injection of a dye (fluorescein) and external imaging to assess the blood flow in the retina. Cataracts may cause some interference with the interpretation of the images, but it is not a complete contraindication for fluorescein angiography. Therefore, this test can still be considered in a patient with cataracts, although the images may have some limitations in clarity.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient, Mrs. Smith, presents to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of gradual vision loss and occasional episodes of seeing rainbow-colored halos around lights . She  reports a family history of glaucoma. He has elevated intraocular pressure (IOP) measuring 28 mmHg in both eyes. Which of the following disc changes would not be found in this patient ?

choices.text: Slow thickening of the neuroretinal rim

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Slow thickening of the neuroretinal rim:

  • Slow thickening of the neuroretinal rim is not typically associated with glaucoma. In glaucoma, the neuroretinal rim tends to undergo thinning and notching due to optic nerve damage.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- C/d ratio greater than 0.3: An increased cup-to-disc (C/D) ratio, especially if it's greater than 0.3, is often indicative of glaucomatous damage where the cup of the optic nerve becomes larger in proportion to the disc (optic nerve head).

Option B - Notching of neuroretinal rim: This would be found in glaucoma. Notching of the neuroretinal rim is a characteristic sign of glaucoma where there is localized thinning or excavation of the rim tissue.

Option C - Laminar dot sign: The lamina cribrosa is a porous opening in the sclera through which nerve fibers pass. When these nerve fibers are damaged, these openings become visible. The term "laminar dot sign" refers to the appearance of these visible openings of the lamina cribrosa due to nerve fiber damage

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with back pain and stiffness. Imaging reveals involvement of the lower half of the T6 vertebra and the upper half of the T7 vertebra, along with the intervertebral disc in between. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Options A: TB spondylitis

  • TB spondylitis, also known as Pott's disease, is a form of tuberculosis that affects the spine. It commonly presents with back pain, stiffness, and progressive deformity. The characteristic feature of TB spondylitis is the involvement of two consecutive vertebrae along with the intervertebral disc in between.
  • In this case, the imaging findings of involvement of the lower half of the T6 vertebra and the upper half of the T7 vertebra, along with the intervertebral disc, are consistent with the typical pattern seen in TB spondylitis. The destruction and involvement of the vertebral bodies and disc can lead to collapse, deformity, and spinal instability.

Incorrect Options:

Option B- Lumbar disc herniation:

  • Lumbar disc herniation typically involves the intervertebral discs of the lumbar spine, causing symptoms such as radicular pain and neurological deficits.
  • The involvement of specific vertebral bodies and intervertebral discs seen in this case is not characteristic of lumbar disc herniation.

Option C- Ankylosing spondylitis:

  • Ankylosing spondylitis is a chronic inflammatory condition that primarily affects the sacroiliac joints and the axial skeleton, causing progressive stiffness and fusion of the spine.
  • The imaging findings described in the case do not align with the typical pattern of involvement seen in ankylosing spondylitis.

Option D- Spinal metastasis:

  • Spinal metastasis refers to the spread of cancer from a primary tumor to the spine.
  • While spinal metastasis can lead to destruction of vertebral bodies and involvement of intervertebral discs, the pattern of involvement in this case, with only a portion of two consecutive vertebrae and the intervertebral disc, is more suggestive of TB spondylitis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents with loss of sensation and motor function in the left upper limb following a fall from a bicycle. Physical examination reveals absence of muscle strength and sensation distal to the injury site. Tapping on the affected nerve elicits a tingling sensation. Which of the following classifications best describes the patient's nerve injury?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Neurotmesis

  • The patient's presentation of complete loss of sensation and motor function distal to the injury site, positive Tinel sign, and absence of muscle strength suggests a complete nerve transection.
  • This corresponds to Seddon's classification of Neurotmesis, which involves complete nerve transection. In this case, surgical repair would likely be required for functional recovery.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Seddon's Neuropraxia:

  • It is characterized by a physiological block in nerve conduction without structural damage, leading to temporary loss of nerve function with 100% recovery. This patient's symptoms are more severe than what would be expected in neuropraxia.

Option B - Seddon's Axonotmesis:

  • This involves damage to the axon and myelin sheath, leading to a positive Tinel sign and possible progression of damage. However, this patient's presentation of complete loss of sensation and motor function is more indicative of neurotmesis.

Option D - Mixed Neuropraxia-Axonotmesis:

  • It is not the most appropriate choice based on the given information. The patient's symptoms are more consistent with a complete nerve transection rather than a mixed or partial injury.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the outpatient department to evaluate a deformity in his back for 2 years. The condition has progressed over the years, and he now feels pain in his back. He can no longer play soccer and feels embarrassed due to his inability to participate in school matches. He is at the 60th percentile of height and 55th percentile of weight. Examination of his back is done in a specific posture, as shown in the image below. Which of the following tests is performed while examining the patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Adams test

  • The given image shows Adam's forward bending test to evaluate scoliosis.
  • On physical examination, the height of the patient should be measured.
  • The best clinical test for evaluating spinal curvature is the Adams forward bending test.
  • As the patient bends forward at the waist until the spine is horizontal, the trunk is observed for rotation from behind (to assess midthoracic and lumbar rotation) and from the front (to assess upper thoracic rotation).
  • The knees should be straight, the feet together, the arms dependent, and the palms in opposition.
  • Because of vertebral rotation, this will produce a rib prominence in the thoracic region or a paraspinal fullness in the lumbar region.
  • An angle of more than 7 degrees is considered abnormal and usually correlates with a curve of 15 to 20 degrees.
  • The sagittal plane should also be examined for excessive kyphosis or lordosis.
  • Limb lengths should be evaluated because a discrepancy may cause pelvic tilt and compensatory scoliosis.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Adson's test:

  • Adson's test is done for Thoracic outlet syndrome.

Option C - Thomas test:

  • Done for hip flexion deformities.

Option D - Trendelenburg test:

  • To check the stability of the hip.
  • The stability of the hip depends on :
    • Proper femur head and acetabulum.
    • Normal hip abductors (Gluteus medius and minimus).
    • Superior gluteal nerve.
  • A positive test means a pelvis drop on the opposite (normal) side when a person is asked to stand on one foot.

  • Trendelenburg test is normally negative (hip muscles & hip nerves are normal).

questions.text: A 45-year-old male sustains a spinal cord injury at the level of T10 following a fall. On examination, he has flaccid paralysis and an absence of anal wink and bulbocavernosus reflexes. Which of the following best describes the patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B: Spinal shock

  • The patient's presentation of flaccid paralysis and absence of anal wink and bulbocavernosus reflexes is indicative of spinal shock.
  • Spinal shock is an acute condition that occurs immediately following a spinal cord injury and is characterized by the temporary loss of motor, sensory, and reflex functions below the level of injury.
  • During spinal shock, there is a temporary disruption of nerve signaling and a loss of muscle tone, resulting in flaccid paralysis.
  • The absence of anal wink and bulbocavernosus reflexes further supports the diagnosis of spinal shock.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Neurogenic shock:

  • It refers to a state of hemodynamic instability caused by autonomic dysfunction following a spinal cord injury. It is characterized by hypotension and bradycardia, which are not described in the case.

Option C - Complete spinal cord injury:

  • It refers to a condition where there is a total loss of motor and sensory function below the level of injury. The case does not provide information about sensory loss, so it cannot be determined if it is a complete injury or not.

Option D - Incomplete spinal cord injury:

  • It refers to a condition where there is partial preservation of motor and/or sensory function below the level of injury. Again, the case does not provide information about any preserved motor or sensory function.

questions.text: A 39-year-male presents to the physician with complaints of runny nose, sore throat, and fever for 5 days. The patient has no other symptoms. The patient is vitally stable, and other general physical examinations reveal no abnormalities. COVID-19 was suspected, and to confirm the diagnosis, PCR was advised by the doctor. Which of the following is the main function of the investigation involved in this case?

choices.text: Amplify a small amount of DNA
Seal the cut ends of the DNA

questions.solution:
Option B : Amplify a small amount of DNA

  • This is a case of COVID-19 in which the patient presents with complaints of runny nose, sore throat, and fever for 5 days.

  • COVID-19 has many other symptoms: anosmia, cough, and body pains.

  • The diagnostic test for this disease is PCR.

  • The basic Steps involved in PCR are:

  • DNA extraction from microorganisms

  • Amplification of extracted DNA- 3 steps -Denaturation (95°C), primer annealing (55°C), extension (72°C)

  • Post amplification analysis by different methods like gel electrophoresis.

Option A: Detect target plasmids

  • This step is not primary. This method might be based on PCR, gel electrophoresis, optical mapping, or sequencing. Replicon typing using PCR

  • The plasmid-conserved replicon site is the goal of this strategy, and multiplex PCR can be broadened to simultaneously target several replicons.

Option C: Seal the cut ends of the DNA

  • DNA ligase seals the gap between the molecules, forming a single piece of DNA

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department physician for four days because of generalized fatigue and dark urine. Four weeks ago, she was treated with cephalexin for a skin infection. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), and her blood pressure is 132/89 mm Hg. Physical examination shows 1+ pretibial oedema bilaterally. Her serum creatinine is 1.7 mg/dl. Urine studies show:


	
		
			
			Blood
			
			
			2+
			
		
		
			
			Protein 
			
			
			2+
			
		
		
			
			RBC
			
			
			12–14/HPF with dysmorphic features
			
		
		
			
			RBC casts
			
			
			numerous
			
		
	


A sample was sent for culture, and the organism showed a unique phenomenon given in the image below. Identify the phenomenon.
questions.solution:
Option D: Dienes phenomenon

The phenomenon in the above image is the Dienes phenomenon.

  • When two different strains of swarming, proteus mirabilis, and proteus vulgaris, encounter one another on an agar plate, swarming ceases and a visible line of demarcation forms. This boundary region is known as the dienes line.
  • However, if similar strains of proteus mirabilis are cultured on an agar plate, they are not confined/ restricted to boundaries and intermingle.

  • PROTEUS: Gram negative coccobacilli.

Option A: Antibiotic susceptibility testing

  • Microbiological test results assess a bacterial pathogen's susceptibility to various antibiotics.
  • The antibiogram reports the sensitivity of a pathogen as "susceptible", "intermediate", or "resistant".
  • Based on the antibiogram, the patient can be treated with targeted antibiotic therapy instead of empiric antibiotic therapy.

Option B: Swarming

SWARMS:

  • Swarming motility was seen on Blood agar, and Nutrient agar.
  • The image given below shows Swarming:

Swarming is inhibited by:

  • Increasing concentration of agar from 2% to 6%.
  • Addition of boric acid & chloral hydrate.
  • MacConkey Agar → Produce Non-lactose fermenting [NLF] colonies.
  • Fishy smell/seminal smell produced on culture media.

Biochemical test:

  • PPA test (Phenyl Pyruvic Acid) positive.
  • Tests the ability of an organism to produce enzyme deaminase.
  • PPA test +ve - converts phenylalanine to phenyl pyruvic acid.
  • This test used to differentiate proteus, morganella, and providencia (Positive) from other members of Enterobacteriaceae (PPA negative).
  • The most common clinical manifestation of UTI (Urinary tract infection) leads to struvite/triple phosphate stones/staghorn calculi.

Option C: Nagler's reaction:

  • Exhibited by clostridium perfringens.
  • Due to alpha lecithinase.
  • Neutralization reaction.
  • Done on egg yolk agar.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents to the emergency department complaining of greenish discolouration of the nail bed, as shown in the image below. On physical examination, the patient is afebrile, and other vitals are within normal range. A mild elevation of WBCs in the lab is found. On suspicion of infectious disease, a culture is done. On culture, it showed pigmented colonies of Gram-negative bacilli. What is the likely cause of this manifestation?
questions.solution:
Option B: Pseudomonas

  • Pseudomonas is the likely cause of this manifestation.
  • The diagnosis of this image is green nail syndrome.
    • Discolouration of the infected nail as it turns a dark green colour due to the Pseudomonas secreting the greenish pigments pyoverdin and Pyocyanin.
    • Paronychial infection can develop in individuals whose hands are frequently submerged in water.

Option A: Candida

  • Candida can also infect the nail bed but does not produce pigments or green nail syndrome.

Option C: Staphylococcus aureus

  • Bacterial nail infections can be caused by microorganisms such as staphylococcus aureus (S. aureus).
  • It is a nail fold infection, which may involve the nail plate.
  • However, staph aureus does not give the specific findings in the above image.

Option D: Fusarium

  • Fusarium does cause nail infection but does not cause green nail syndrome.
  • Symptoms include white or yellow nail discolouration, thickening, and separation from the nail bed.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male with a known case of tuberculosis for two months presents to the OPD with a history of persistent cough and weight loss despite being started on the first-line treatment. He admits to being noncompliant with the prescribed medicine. Upon further evaluation, it is noted that the patient’s culture and sensitivity report shows resistance to isoniazid. What is the likely mechanism for Mycobacterium resistance to this drug?

choices.text: Mutations in the DNA gyrase gene

questions.solution:
Answer

Option B: Mutations in the katG gene

  • The KatG gene encodes the catalase-peroxidase enzyme, and mutations in this gene reduce or block enzyme activity.
  • In most strains, the main mechanism of INH resistance is a mutation in the katG gene.
  • Isoniazid mutations mainly in the katG (50–95% of cases) and inhA (up to 45%) genes.
  • KatG encodes catalase-peroxidase enzymes that activate INH, whereas inhA gene mutations have shown mild resistance to INH.

Causes of Drug-resistant Tuberculosis:

  • Poor quality Drugs.
  • Develop TB disease after previously being treated for TB disease.
  • Have spent time with someone who has drug-resistant tuberculosis.

Other options

Option A: Production of β-Lactamase enzyme

  • Beta-lactamase enzymes are responsible for the hydrolysis of beta-lactam rings of cell wall synthesis inhibitors (such as penicillin, cephalosporin, and cephamycins).
  • Bacteria produce these enzymes to develop drug resistance to beta-lactam antibiotics by damaging the active sites of said drugs and, thus, eliminating their anti-bacterial properties.

Option C: Alterations in the rpoB gene

  • Bacterial resistance to rifampin is caused by mutations leading to a change in the structure of the beta subunit of RNA polymerase.
  • Such resistance is not an all-or-nothing phenomenon; rather, a large number of RNA polymerases with various degrees of sensitivity to rifampin have been found. 

Option D: Mutations in the DNA gyrase gene

  • DNA gyrase is the prime target of binding by fluoroquinolones in most gram-negative bacteria, whereas topoisomerase IV targets gram-positive bacteria.
  • Mutations in the DNA gyrase gene produce the structurally altered enzyme that leads to the reduced affinity of fluoroquinolones in gram-negative bacteria.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient who underwent prosthetic heart valve replacement 6 years ago came to the dentistry clinic for a follow-up procedure. The dentist advised her on antibiotic prophylaxis before going for the treatment. Antibiotic prophylaxis against infective endocarditis had been advocated before dental procedures in some patients based on theoretical arguments, observational reports and animal studies. This is most probably due to the risk of infection by?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option A : Streptococcus viridans

  • Viridans streptococci are normally resident in the mouth and upper respiratory tract. They cause transient bacteremia following tooth extraction or other dental procedures; they get implanted on damaged or prosthetic valves or in a congenitally diseased heart and grow to form vegetation.
  • They are ordinarily nonpathogenic but can, on occasion, cause disease. People with pre-existing cardiac lesions may cause bacterial endocarditis, Streptococcus sanguinis being most often responsible.
  • Streptococcus mutans are important in the causation of dental caries.
  • The transient viridans streptococcal bacteremia induced by eating, tooth-brushing, flossing, and other sources of minor trauma, together with adherence to biological surfaces, is thought to account for the predilection of these organisms to cause endocarditis.
  • Viridans streptococci are also isolated, often as a part of mixed flora, from sinusitis, brain abscess, and liver abscess sites.
  • Viridans streptococcal bacteremia occurs relatively frequently in neutropenic patients, particularly after bone marrow transplantation or high-dose chemotherapy for cancer.
  • Treatment of viridans streptococcal infections includes:-
    1. Bacteremia in neutropenic patients → Vancomycin.
    2. Other infections → Penicillin.

Option B: Streptococcus pneumonia

  • Streptococcus pneumonia infection is sometimes found to cause infective endocarditis but is very infrequent.
  • It is known as one of the main causes of community-acquired pneumonia and meningitis.

Option C: Streptococcus pyogenes

  • They cause various infections in children and adults but are rarely seen as a cause of infective endocarditis.
  • The infections range from superficial non-invasive skin infections to invasive infections and diseases like rheumatic fever and post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis.

Option D: Staphylococcus aureus

  • Staph. Aureus infective endocarditis (SAIE) is a serious manifestation with considerable morbidity and mortality.
  • It is found in IV drug users and hospitalized patients with nosocomial infections.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient from Sierra Leone presented to ER with fever, stomach pain, headache, weakness and fatigue for a week. Now he has developed diarrhoea and has started coughing up blood. He works as a nurse and has been doing shifts in isolation wards. However, he reported no breach of PPE. The temperature was 37.1 degrees Celsius on physical examination, and red spots were seen all over the body. Laboratory blood tests showed renal impairment, raised transaminases, elevated creatinine kinase (CK), thrombocytopenia, a prolonged prothrombin time, and prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time, suggesting organ dysfunction. He was admitted and initiated treatment, but over the next few days, his renal impairment and encephalopathy developed. The underlying image shows an infective agent. What is the disease this patient is suffering from?
questions.solution:
Option A: Ebola virus disease (EVD)

  • The Ebola virus is a deadly human disease most commonly affecting people and nonhuman primates (monkeys and gorillas).

Species of genus Ebolavirus:

  • Zaire ebolavirus (Type virus: EBOV).
  • Sudan ebolavirus (Type virus: Sudan virus; SUDV)
  • Bundibugyo ebolavirus (Type virus: Bundibugyo virus; BDBV)
  • Taï Forest ebolavirus (Cote d’Ivoire) (Type virus: Taï Forest virus; TAFV)
  • Reston ebolavirus (Type virus: Reston virus; RESTV)
  • Only 4 species i.e., Zaire, Sudan, Tai, and Bundibugyovirus cause disease in people.
  • The Reston virus is known to cause disease in nonhuman primates and pigs but not in people. 
  • Four of the six known ebolaviruses, including EBOV, cause a severe and often fatal hemorrhagic fever in humans and other mammals, known as Ebola virus disease (EVD)
  • The natural reservoir of the Ebola virus is believed to be bats, particularly fruit bats, and it is primarily transmitted between humans and from animals to humans through body fluids.
  • The Ebola virus (EVD) is a deadly disease in people and nonhuman primates. The viruses that cause EVD are located mainly in sub-Saharan Africa.
  • The Ebola virus was first discovered in 1976 near the Ebola River in the Democratic Republic of Congo. Since then, the virus has been infecting people from time to time, leading to outbreaks in several African countries.

Symptoms

  • The incubation period is from 2 to 21 days.
  • A person infected with Ebola cannot spread the disease until they develop symptoms.
  • Symptoms of EVD can be sudden and include:
  • Fever
  • Fatigue
  • Muscle pain
  • Headache
  • Sore throat

This is followed by:

  • Vomiting
  • Diarrhoea
  • Rash
  • Symptoms of impaired kidney and liver function
  • In some cases, internal and external bleeding (for example, oozing from the gums or blood in the stools).

Diagnostic methods:

  • Antibody-capture enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA)
  • Antigen-capture detection tests
  • Serum neutralization test
  • Reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) assay
  • Electron microscopy
  • Virus isolation by cell culture.

Treatment:

  • Supportive care – rehydration with oral or intravenous fluids – and treatment of specific symptoms improve survival.
  • Two monoclonal antibodies (Inmazeb and Ebanga) were approved for treating Zaire ebolavirus (Ebolavirus) infection in adults and children.

Vaccination:

  • The Ervebo vaccine is effective in protecting people from the species Zaire ebolavirus.
  • Zabdeno-and-Mvabea for individuals 1 year and older.
  • The vaccine is delivered in 2 doses: Zabdeno is administered first, and Mvabea is given approximately 8 weeks later as a second dose.

Option B: Marburg virus infection

  • The causative agent of Marburg virus disease (MVD) is the Marburg virus.
  • Marburg and Ebola viruses are members of the Filoviridae family (filovirus). Though caused by different viruses, the two diseases are clinically similar.
  • Initially, human MVD infection results from prolonged exposure to mines or caves inhabited by Rousettus bat colonies.
  • Marburg spreads through human-to-human transmission via direct contact (through broken skin or mucous membranes) with infected people's blood, secretions, organs or other bodily fluids and surfaces and materials (e.g. bedding, clothing) contaminated with these fluids.
  • Illness caused by the Marburg virus begins abruptly with
    • High fever
    • Severe headache
    • Severe malaise.
    • Muscle aches and pains are common features.
    • Severe watery diarrhoea, abdominal pain with cramping, nausea, and vomiting can begin on the third day.
  • The appearance of patients at this phase has been described as showing “ghost-like” drawn features, deep-set eyes, expressionless faces, and extreme lethargy.
  • Patients develop severe haemorrhagic manifestations between 5 and 7 days, and fatal cases usually have some form of bleeding, often from multiple areas.
  • Currently, there are no vaccines or antiviral treatments approved for MVD. However, supportive care – rehydration with oral or intravenous fluids and treatment of specific symptoms improve survival.

Option C: Yellow fever

  • The yellow fever virus is present in tropical and subtropical areas of Africa and South America. The virus can spread to people by the bite of an infected mosquito.
  • Illness ranges from a fever, aches and pains to severe liver disease with bleeding and yellowing skin (jaundice).
  • Yellow fever infection is diagnosed on laboratory testing, a person’s symptoms, and travel history.
  • There is no medicine to treat or cure infection from yellow fever.
  • Rest, drink fluids, and use pain relievers and medication to reduce fever and relieve aching.
  • Avoid certain medications, such as aspirin or other nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, for example, ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin), or naproxen (Aleve), which may increase the risk of bleeding.

Option D: Dengue fever

  • Dengue viruses can spread to people through the bite of an infected Aedes species (Ae. Aegypti or Ae. Albopictus) mosquito.
  • Mild symptoms of dengue can be confused with other illnesses that cause fever, aches, and pains, or a rash.
  • The most common symptom of dengue is fever with any of the following;
    • Nausea and vomiting
    • Rash
    • Aches and pains (eye pain, typically behind the eyes, muscle, joint, or bone pain)
  • There is no specific treatment for dengue. Rest and supportive treatment is done.

questions.text: The parents of an 18-month-old girl appeared at the ER with their daughter, who had an abrupt onset of vomiting and watery diarrhoea. The symptoms began two days previously at her daycare centre. Initially, she had a mild fever which subsided after a day. She had 3 episodes of vomiting and multiple episodes of watery diarrhoea with abdominal pain. She refused to eat or drink and is very lethargic. What property of the infectious agent causing these symptoms allowed the preparation of a vaccine that could have prevented them?

choices.text: Ability to survive as a temperature-sensitive mutant.

questions.solution:
Option D: Segmented genetic material

Segmented genetic material allowed the preparation of a vaccine for Rotavirus.

  • Rotaviruses are the most common cause of diarrhoea in infants.
  • Rotaviruses are about 60 to 80 nm and have icosahedral symmetry, triple-layered capsid and segmental double-stranded RNA (11 segments).

Reassortant vaccines:

  • It takes advantage of the natural ability of viruses with segmented genomes to reassort when more than one strain infects the host cell.
  • The goal of reassortment is to assemble a virus variant with attenuated pathogenicity that can be used for safe vaccination.

Two types of reassortant Rotavirus vaccines have been developed:

  • Reassortant of human Rotaviruses
  • Reassortant of human and bovine Rotaviruses.
  • RotaTeq and Rotarix are available for the prevention of Rotavirus.
  • RotaTeq is a live, oral pentavalent vaccine that contains 5 live reassortant rotaviruses.

Viruses having segmented genome (Mnemonic: PARBO virus):

P- Picornavirus

A-Arenaviridae

R- Reoviridae

B-Bunyaviridae

O- Orthomyxoviridae

ROTA VIRUS

  • Rotavirus is a very contagious virus that causes diarrhoea.
  • Before the vaccine development, most children had been infected with the virus at least once by age 5.
  • Although rotavirus infections are unpleasant, you can usually treat this infection at home with extra fluids to prevent dehydration.
  • Occasionally, severe dehydration requires receiving fluids through a vein (intravenously) in the hospital.

Symptoms

  • Rotavirus infection usually starts within two days of exposure to the virus.
  • Early symptoms are a fever and vomiting, followed by three to seven days of watery diarrhoea.
  • The infection can cause abdominal pain as well.

Spread of infection

  • Rotavirus is present in an infected person's stool two days before symptoms appear and up to 10 days after symptoms lessen.
  • The virus spreads easily through hand-to-mouth contact throughout this time, even if the infected person doesn’t have symptoms.

Diagnosis

  • Mostly it is diagnosed on symptoms and physical exam.
  • However, a stool sample analysis may be done for confirmation.

Treatment

  • There is no specific treatment for rotavirus infection. It usually resolves within 5 to 7 days.

Option A: Ability to survive as a temperature-sensitive mutant

  • Rotavirus temperature-sensitive mutants are genetically stable.
  • Temperature-sensitive mutants cause disease with reduced severity
  • However, the formation of the vaccine is based on its segmental RNA.

Option B: Identification of an enterotoxin

  • The virus enters the body through the mouth.
  • Viral replication occurs in the villous epithelium of the small intestine.
  • Up to two-thirds of children with severe rotavirus gastroenteritis show the presence of rotavirus antigen in serum (antigenemia), and children can have rotavirus RNA detected in serum.
  • Rotavirus nonstructural protein 4 (NSP4) is an enterotoxin identified as an important agent in symptomatic rotavirus infection.
  • However, the formation of a vaccine is not based on enterotoxin.

Option C: Loss of colonisation factors

  • The ability of ETEC to adhere to the host's intestinal epithelium is an important virulence determinant, and adhesion is mediated by proteinaceous surface appendages called colonisation factors.
  • The basis of rotavirus vaccine formation is its segmented genome.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents in the outpatient department with the complaint of having a ring-shaped redness over the axilla and groin region associated with severe itching. Specimen produces granular colonies in corn meal agar. It shows trichophyton. Trichophyton is basically a dermatophyte that inhabits the soil, humans or animals. Related to its natural habitats, the genus includes anthropophilic, zoophilic, and geophilic species. Which of the following is the zoophilic genus of trichophyton?
questions.solution:
Option D: Trichophyton mentagrophytes

  • Trichophyton mentagrophytes are one of three common fungi which cause ringworm in companion animals.
  • It is the second most common fungi causing tinea infection in humans and the most common fungi causing zoonotic skin disease, i.e., the transmission of mycotic disease from species to species.
  • The causative organisms of the dermatophytoses are often distinguished according to their natural habitats: anthropophilic (residing on human skin), zoophilic (residing on the skin of domestic and farm animals), or geophilic (residing in the soil). Most human infections are caused by anthropophilic and zoophilic organisms.

Trichophyton mentagrophytes

  • Rapidly growing and distributed worldwide
  • One of the most common species recovered in the lab
  • T. mentagrophytes perforates hair and hence can be used as a criterion when having difficulties in distinguishing it from T. rubrum
  • It can produce both micro/macroconidia
  • Responsible for Tinea pedis, Tinea cruris, Tinea capitis, Tinea barbae and Tinea unguium

  • Transmission from human to human or animal to human is by infected skin scales on inanimate objects.
  • Only pathogenic fungi are capable of human-to-human spread.
  • Zoophilic dermatophytes are the species that primarily infect animals and are occasionally transmitted to humans.
  • Zoophilic species of trichophyton are T. mentagrophytes and T. verrucosum.
  • Other zoophilic species of dermatophytes is M. canis.

Option A: Trichophyton tonsurans

  • It is the main cause of tinea capitis.
  • Its colony tends to be flat powdery, and yellow with reddish underwater.
  • It is acquired through infected pets.

Option B:Trichophyton Violaceum

  • It is not zoophilic.
  • It causes tinea capitis in Africans and people of Mediterranean origin.
  • Epidermal changes are variable, but there may be necrosis in some lesions.

Option C: Trichophyton schoenleinni

  • It is not zoophilic.
  • It causes Trichophytosis and tinea favosa.
  • The immune system plays an important role in the development of this infection.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presents in the outpatient department with complaints of fever, chills, muscle aches, and diarrhoea. There is abdominal distension and splenomegaly on physical examination. The physician is concerned about splenic complications associated with this condition. Which of the following organism causes splenic complications in the above-mentioned infection?
questions.solution:
Option A: Plasmodium vivax

  • In the above-given case, the presence of fever, splenomegaly, and abdominal pain is suggestive of splenic rupture.
  • Plasmodium vivax causes a splenic rupture in the above-mentioned infection.
  • Splenomegaly is one of the commonest features of malaria.
  • However, spontaneous splenic rupture, although unusual, represents a severe complication often leading to death.
  • It is mostly seen in acute infection and primary attack, and it is most commonly associated with Plasmodium vivax.
  • In benign malaria, after a few weeks of febrile paroxysm, the spleen gets enlarged and becomes palpable.
  • Splenomegaly is due to the massive proliferation of macrophages that engulf parasitized and non-parasitized coated RBCs.

Option B: Plasmodium ovale

  • It causes tertian malaria 7-42 days after incubation.
  • It causes periodic fever every 48 hours.
  • Ovale hypnozoites can persist in the liver and can cause reinfection.

Option C: Plasmodium malariae

  • Band-shaped trophozoites are seen in P. malariae.
  • It can cause liver or kidney failure.

Option D: Plasmodium falciparum

  • P. falciparum invades and destroy RBCs and cause severe malaria.
  • It can also cause organ dysfunction by causing microinfarctions.
  • Trophozoite ring formation in RBCs can be seen on blood smear examination.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents with a road traffic accident in the emergency. She has been complaining of generalized pain, burning sensation, and dizziness for the last 2 hours. Upon examination, there are wounds on both knees. After debridement of the injury, she is given conservative treatment. Road traffic accidents are known to cause many bacterial infections. Antigen-presenting cells (APCs) act as an immune response to any external pathogens. Which of the following APCs will work on the pathogens?
questions.solution:
Option C: B cells

  • The patient presents with the case of a road traffic accident with a high chance of bacterial or viral infections.

  • APCs represent the cells that present the antigenic peptide and MHC molecules to T cells.

  • They can be classified into 2 groups which are as follows:

    • Professional APCs: Macrophages, Dendritic cells, and B-cells.

    • Nonprofessional APCs: Fibroblasts (skin), thymic epithelial cells, pancreatic beta cells, vascular endothelial cells, glial cells (brain), and thyroid epithelial cells.

  • B cells are one of the classic examples of APCs that produce antibodies and act as a part of immunity.

  • The antibodies produced by these cells, in return, bind to the pathogens or any foreign object and neutralize it accordingly.

  • They also play an essential role in the activation of T cells.

Option A: Natural killer cells

  • These cells are essential to innate immunity and helps to fight the pathogen. Unlike APCs, they do not require prior activation for their action.

  • Natural killer cells are cytotoxic in the form of small granules containing perforin and proteases known as granzymes.

Option B: T cells

  • These are immune cells that are important in the adaptive immune response. They are leukocytic.

  • One of their function is the immune-mediated death of the cell. T cells mature in the thymus gland and release into the bloodstream.

Option D: Polymorphonuclear leukocytes

  • White blood cells have a vital role in the innate immune system. They are also called granulocytes.

  • PMNs are a significant source of enzymes responsible for tissue damage in the inflammatory process.

questions.text: A 58-year-old female comes to the physician complaining of progressively increasing lumps in both breasts for the last three months. Fine-needle aspiration cytology from both breast lumps is suggestive of malignancy. The patient tested positive for the BRCA1 gene mutation. Histopathology shows poorly differentiated cells growing in sheets with high-grade nuclear features. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: Medullary carcinoma

  • This patient has bilateral breast lumps with histological examination showing sheets of malignant cells most likely has medullary carcinoma of the breast.
  • Medullary carcinoma is a subtype of invasive ductal carcinoma.
  • BRCA1 gene mutation is the most important risk factor for developing bilateral medullary carcinoma.
  • Medullary carcinoma accounts for 5% of breast cancers.
  • There is associated axillary lymph node enlargement because of reactive hyperplasia.
  • Histopathologic examination of the biopsy specimen shows:
    • Sheets of malignant cells growing in a syncytial pattern
    • Poorly differentiated cells surrounded by lymphocytes and plasma cells
    • High-grade nuclear features with atypia
    • Borders of the tumor pushing into the adjoining breast tissue
  • Medullary carcinoma is typically triple-negative, i.e., estrogen receptor (ER), progesterone receptor (PR), and HER2-neu receptor-negative.

Option A: Ductal carcinoma in situ

  • Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) is characterized by the malignant proliferation of ductal epithelium; however, the growth of tumor cells does not extend beyond the basement membrane.
  • In addition, DCIS is not usually bilateral or associated with BRCA1 gene mutations.

Option B: Fibroadenoma

  • Fibroadenoma is a benign neoplasm of the breast characterized by the growth of the fibrous tissue and the glands.
  • It is estrogen-sensitive and is typically seen in premenopausal women.

Option D: Mucinous carcinoma

  • Mucinous carcinoma is a histologic subtype of invasive ductal carcinoma.
  • Microscopic examination shows the growth of tumor cells with abundant extracellular mucin, unlike the sheets of malignant cells seen in this patient's biopsy specimen.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman who underwent a mastectomy for breast cancer 2 years ago presents to the emergency department with headache, backache, and frequent vomiting. She is extremely thirsty and confused. Which of the following tests is most likely to identify the cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Option D: Serum Calcium Concentration

  • Hypercalcemia is defined as a serum calcium level above the normal range of 8.5 to 10.5 mEq/L or an increase in the ionized calcium level above 4.2 to 4.8 mg/dL.
  • This patient is a known case of breast cancer operated on 2 years ago and now present with symptoms concerning for metastases such as backache, confusion, and frequent vomiting.
  • The metastasis to the bone causes increased osteoclastic activity in the bone, leading to hypercalcemia. Increased thirst sensation and confusion are symptoms of hypercalcemia. Hence, the investigation needed to be done now is on serum calcium concentration. 
  • Symptomatic hypercalcemiais mainly due to primary hyperparathyroidism and malignancy or secretion of the parathyroid hormone-related protein.
  • Primary hyperparathyroidism and malignancy or secretion of the parathyroid hormone-related protein account for most cases of symptomatic hypercalcemia.
  • Multiple myeloma, lymphoma, and solid tumors metastasis to bone (particularly breast, lung, and prostate cancer) cause hypercalcemia by excessive osteoclastic activity
  • Symptoms of hypercalcemia
    • Gastrointestinal -Anorexia, nausea/vomiting, abdominal pain
    • Neuromuscular - Weakness, confusion, coma, bone pain
    • Cardiovascular - Hypertension, arrhythmia, polyuria, worsening of digitalis toxicity. ECG changes include shortened QT interval, prolonged PR and QRS intervals, increased QRS voltage, T-wave flattening and widening, and atrioventricular block
    • Renal - Polydipsia
  • Severe hypercalcemia, referred to as hypercalcemic crisis, occurs with serum calcium concentration above 14mg/dL and is related to the release of calcium from bone by tumor; it can be effectively managed by saline infusion followed by administration of bisphosphonates (zoledronic acid, pamidronate disodium, and etidronate disodium). They have a potent capacity to reduce the osteoclast-mediated release of calcium from bone.
  • Definitive management of hypercalcemia depends on the correction of the primary problem. Patients with a malignant neoplasm and hypercalcemia may respond to surgical excision, radiation therapy, or chemotherapy

 

Option A: CT Brain without contrast

  • CT brain plain is ordered to look at the structures of the brain and evaluate for the presence of pathologies such as:
    • Mass/tumor
    • Fluid collection (abscess)
    • Ischemic injury (stroke)
    • Hemorrhage
    • Hydrocephalus
    • The trauma of fracture of the skull
  • However, this patient's backache and history of breast cancer are concerning for hypercalcemia. CT would be in line with the management of this patient, but it is not the next best step in the evaluation of this patient's symptoms.

Option B: X-ray of the spine

  • X-ray of the spine is performed to diagnose:
    • Back pain
    • Fractures of the spine
    • Arthritis
    • Spondylolisthesis
    • Degeneration of the disks
    • Tumors
    • Abnormalities in the curvature of the spine, like kyphosis or scoliosis
    • Congenital abnormalities

 

Option C: Serum sodium concentration

  • Low serum sodium levels also cause nausea, vomiting, headache, and confusion.
  • However, this patient's history of breast cancer and backache are more concerning for hypercalcemia.

questions.text: A 22-year-old female presents to the surgery OPD with complaints of increased swelling in her neck over the previous 2 years. She has had a medical history of severe hearing loss since early childhood. On examination, she has a large goiter extending retrosternally with small irregular nodules, no audible bruit, and a negative Pemberton's sign. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D: Pendred syndrome

  • The patient mentioned above has clinical features of sensorineural hearing loss associated with goiter. This presentation is typical of Pendred syndrome.
  • Presentation of Pendred syndrome:
    • Hearing loss or deafness
    • Speech impairment
    • Electrolyte/homeostasis imbalance
    • Goitre
    • Enlarged vestibular aqueduct
    • Hypothyroidism
  • Pendred Syndrome is the combination of sensorineural hearing loss with dyshormonogenetic goiter.
  • It is autosomal recessive. The affected gene is located on chromosome 7q.
  • There is a mutation of the PDS gene, which encodes for pendrin, the protein that transports iodide to the luminal surface of the follicular cell.

Other options

Option A: Werner syndrome

  • Werner syndrome (MEN1) occurs due to germline mutation in the MEN1 gene located in chromosome 11 that encodes menin. It is autosomal dominant hereditary cancer syndrome.
  • Symptoms and signs are shorter than average height, thin arms and legs, voice changes, thinning and greying hair, skin changes, and unusual facial features.

Option B: Turcot syndrome

  • Turcot syndrome is characterized by the following:
    • Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP).
    • Primary CNS tumors (astrocytoma or medulloblastoma).

Option C: Cowden syndrome

  • Cowden's syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder due to mutations in PTEN.
  • Associated cancers include:
    • Breast carcinoma
    • Thyroid carcinoma
    • Endometrial carcinoma

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl is brought in by her mother with a complaint of left-sided anterior neck swelling for 1 week. Her mother states that the swelling is painful and has progressively increased in size over the past week, which is associated with difficulty swallowing. She has a fever of 100° F, a pulse rate of 100 bpm, and a respiratory rate of 20 breaths/minute. She has a history of being treated for an upper respiratory tract infection (URTI) a week ago. On examination, there is no hoarseness, difficulty breathing.. Which one of the following statements is correct about the given condition?

choices.text: Most common cause is the presence of pyriform sinus

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - The most common cause is the presence of pyriform sinus:

  • In the case discussed above, the child has features of neck swelling following an upper respiratory tract infection one week ago. In this case, the diagnosis is suppurative thyroiditis.
  • It is more common in children and is marked by the presence of a pyriform sinus.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - More common in adults:

  • It is more common in children than adults because of the persistent pyriform sinus (the connection between the oropharynx and thyroid).

Option C - Most common organism: legionella:

  • The most common organism that causes acute suppurative thyroiditis is either Staphylococcus aureus or streptococci.

Option D - Most patients are managed conservatively:

  • Patients with acute suppurative thyroiditis are not managed conservatively.
  • The treatment includes incision, drainage, and a suitable antibiotic sensitive to the causative organism.

questions.text: What is the composition of the gallstones given below?

choices.text: Calcium oxalate + calcium phosphate + calcium stearate
Calcium bilirubinate + calcium palmitate + calcium stearate
Insoluble bilirubin polymer + calcium phosphate + calcium bicarbonate
Insoluble bilirubin polymer + calcium phosphate + calcium carbonate

questions.solution:
Option B: Calcium bilirubinate + calcium palmitate + calcium stearate 

  • The image shows brown pigmented stones.
  • They are composed of: 
    • Calcium bilirubinate
    • Calcium palmitate
    • Calcium stearate
  • Most common in the common bile duct (CBD) and are rare in the gall bladder.

Options A and D are incorrect as they do not constitute brown-pigmented stones.
