Option C: Insoluble bilirubin polymer + calcium phosphate + calcium bicarbonate forms black pigmented stones.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient diagnosed with chronic pancreatitis has come to the clinic with pain unresponsive to analgesics for the past 1 month. On imaging, it is seen that the pancreatic head is >4 mm, and he is referred for surgery. What is the surgical procedure shown in the image given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Beger's procedure:

  • The duodenum-preserving pancreatic head resection was first described by Beger and developed to avoid some of the adverse sequelae of pancreaticoduodenectomy.
  • A pancreatic head resection is performed, and only a small part of pancreatic tissue is left on the duodenum to preserve the duodenum. In this procedure, the stomach and common bile duct are not divided.
  • In 25% of the cases, it is still necessary to perform biliary anastomosis on the intrapancreatic part of the common bile duct. A two-sided pancreaticojejunostomy is performed on the small part of pancreatic tissue on the duodenum and the pancreas remnant.
  • Compared to the pancreaticoduodenectomy, an advantage of the Beger procedure is that the duodenum is preserved and that only an anastomosis should be made on both sides of the pancreas. A disadvantage is that it can be a technically demanding operation with a difficult technical anastomosis.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Frey's procedure:

  • Frey and Smith described the local Resection of the pancreatic head with longitudinal Pancreaticojejunostomy (LR-LPJ)
  • In this procedure, the pancreatic head is not fully resected. An advantage of the Frey procedure compared to pancreatic head resection is that it also can treat duct disease in the pancreatic remnant and that coring out the pancreatic head appears to be safer than a pancreatic head resection when portal hypertension or thrombosis is present.
  • It provides thorough decompression of the pancreatic head as well as the body and tail of the gland

Option C - Puestow's procedure:

  • Puestow aka Longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy (LPJ): Originally described as an invaginating anastomosis that drained the entire body and tail. The anastomoses were created after amputating the tail of the gland and opening the duct along the long axis of the gland. This procedure allows good postoperative pain relief of patients and maintains pancreatic function by providing wide ductal drainage without pancreatic resection. 
  • The pancreatic head is not resected in this procedure

Option D - Duval procedure:

  • Duval procedure is the Resection of the tail of the pancreas with retrograde pancreaticojejunostomy. The head of the pancreas is not resected as it is a drainage procedure and not a resection procedure

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman was referred to your hospital with persistent subacute eczema affecting her lower extremities and groin area associated with weight loss, glossitis, and angular stomatitis that had been present for 12 months. She was treated with topical and oral steroids with no improvement. Her medical history revealed a long-standing type 2 diabetes mellitus and recurrent episodes of deep-vein thrombosis in her right leg despite anticoagulant therapy. An abdominal (CT) scan showed hypervascularized tumour measuring 5 to 7 cm in the tail of her pancreas without evidence of metastatic disease. What is your probable diagnosis with the given data?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Glucagonoma:

  • The image shows Central necrosis and Peripheral Erythema, "Necrolytic migratory erythema". It is the most common manifestation of Glucagonoma
  • Glucagonoma:
    • Diabetes in association with dermatitis should raise the suspicion of a glucagonoma. The classic necrolytic migratory erythema (due to low levels of amino acids) manifests as cyclic migrations of lesions with spreading margins and healing centres, typically on the lower abdomen, perineum, perioral area, and feet.
    • Patients also complain of an enlarged sensitive tongue
    • The diagnosis is confirmed by measuring serum glucagon levels, usually >500 pg/mL
    • They are more often in the body and tail of the pancreas.
    • Treatment involves complete resection for resectable disease

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Insulinoma:

  • Insulinoma is a pancreatic tumour in which the symptoms present as a Whipple triad
    • Symptoms of hypoglycemia (palpitations, dizziness)
    • Fasting hypoglycemia
    • Correction of symptoms with administration of glucose

 Option C - Gastrinoma:

  • Gastrinoma is a pancreatic tumour with an overproduction of gastrin which causes hypersecretion of acid and distal duodenum ulcers with gastrin levels >1000 pg/mL.

Option D - Somatostatinoma:

  • Somatostatinoma is a somatostatin-producing pancreatic tumour. Somatostatin inhibits the pancreatic enzymes, both endocrine and exocrine, so it causes diabetes and steatorrhea.

questions.text: Which of the following is a feature of Mackler's triad?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Thoracic pain:

  • Boerhaave's syndrome is characterized by the presence of Mackler's triad. 
    • Thoracic pain 
    • Vomiting 
    • Cervical subcutaneous emphysema 

Incorrect Options:

Options A and C are a part of the Anderson triad, seen in esophageal rupture (Abdominal rigidity, tachypnea, and subcutaneous emphysema)

Option B - Dyspnea:

  • Dyspnea is not a feature of Mackler’s triad.

questions.text: A 30 year old male presents to the emergency department with massive hematemesis. A 2 × 2 cm ulcer is visualized on the upper GI endoscopy on the posterior aspect of the first part of the duodenum. The bleeding vessel is visualized, but the bleeding is not being controlled endoscopically. A blood transfusion is done, and the patient is planned for surgery. Which of the following would be the best surgical management?

choices.text: Antrectomy with ligation of left gastric artery
Duodenotomy with ligation of bleeding vessels with postoperative PPI
Duodenotomy with ligation of bleeding vessels, truncal vagotomy, and pyloroplasty
Duodenotomy with ligation of bleeding vessels, highly selective vagotomy

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Duodenotomy with ligation of bleeding vessels, truncal vagotomy, and pyloroplasty:

  • The following are the components of the optimal surgical treatment for bleeding duodenal ulcer patient: 
    • Duodenotomy 
    • Surgical ligation of the bleeding vessel  
    • Pyloroplasty with a truncal vagotomy. 
  • Despite its rarity, bleeding is the ulcer-related condition that most frequently results in the death of the patient. 
  • 25% of individuals don't respond; thus, endoscopic hemostatic therapy

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A , B & D are not treatment of choice.

questions.text: A 57-year-old male presents to the surgical OPD with an epigastric mass, early satiety, and weight loss for the last 3 months. Abdominal examination revealed an irregular mass in the epigastric region 4×5cm, moving with respiration, and hard in consistency. Endoscopic Biopsy from an ulcer-proliferative lesion in the greater curvature revealed gastric adenocarcinoma. Which of the following is a manifestation of carcinoma stomach?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - All of the above:

  • Most patients have advanced stage III or IV at the time of diagnosis.
  • The most common symptom is weight loss, reduced food intake due to anorexia, and early satiety.
  • Chronic occult blood loss occurs, leading to Iron deficiency anemia and heme-positive stools.
  • Paraneoplastic syndromes such as Trousseau's syndrome (thrombophlebitis), acanthosis nigricans, and peripheral neuropathy may occur.
  • Cervical, Left supraclavicular ( referred to as Virchow's node called Troisier's sign), and axillary (Irish )lymph nodes may be enlarged.
  • Malignant ascites or pleural effusion or aspiration pneumonitis may be present.
  • The abdominal mass shows a large tumor (T4 tumor), liver metastasis, or carcinomatosis (including Krukenberg's tumorof the ovary).
  • Palpable umbilical nodes (Sister Mary Joseph's node) are pathognomic of advanced disease.
  • Rectal examination shows drop metastasis or rectal shelf of Blumer in the pouch of Douglas.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Troisier's sign:

  • The Troisier sign shows an enlargement of a left-sided supraclavicular lymph node. The enlarged supraclavicular lymph node is known as a Virchow node. It is suggestive of gastric malignancy.

Option B - Trousseau's syndrome:

  • Trousseau syndrome is an acquired blood clotting disorder that results in migratory thrombophlebitis (inflammation of a vein due to a blood clot)
  • It is often associated with gastric carcinoma.

Option C - Irish node:

  • Gastric carcinoma may cause an enlargement of an axillary lymph node called the Irish node.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male comes to the outpatient department complaining of hematemesis and melena. He has been suffering from abdominal discomfort and vomiting for many months. His blood pressure is 130/90 mmHg, and his pulse is 60/min. On physical examination, he is pale and thin. There are also swollen lymph nodes in the left supraclavicular region . On further evaluation with endoscopy and imaging modalities, the patient is diagnosed with a case of locally advanced gastric carcinoma. Which of the following is an investigation of choice to know the depth of cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - EUS:

  • EUS (endoscopic ultrasound) is a minimally invasive procedure to assess the digestive tract and nearby organs.
  • It uses a thin, flexible tube inserted into the gastrointestinal tract and a device that uses sound waves to create images.
  • This endoscopic tube also has a small needle to remove fluid or tissue samples for biopsy.
  • The best way to stage the tumour locally is via EUS, which gives fairly accurate (80%) information about the depth of tumour penetration into the gastric wall and can show enlarged (>5mm) perigastric and celiac lymph nodes.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - CECT:

  • CECT is Contrast-enhanced Computed tomography.
  • It is used for imaging the different structures, and the contrast helps to improve the visualisation.
  • In this procedure, a beam of x-ray moves all around the body and different images are taken to form a dimensional image.
  • During surgeries, it is used to place a needle at a specific point for biopsies or aspiration.
  • It helps to visualise the tumours or other diseases before or after treatment.

Option B - MRI:

  • MRI (magnetic resonance) is an imaging test that uses powerful magnets and radio waves.
  • These waves create images of the inside of the abdomen and do not use radiation.
  • Single MRI images are called slices stored on a computer and viewed on a monitor.
  • MRI is mainly used for brain and spinal cord injuries (stroke, tumour, aneurysms)
  • MRI of the abdomen is mainly used for the following:
    • Blood flow in the abdomen
    • Blood vessels in the abdomen
    • Lymph nodes
    • Masses in the liver, kidney, pancreas, and spleen.

Option C - Barium:

  • Different types of barium x-ray examinations are used to determine different parts.
  • A barium swallow is used to study the pharynx and esophagus.
  • A mixture of barium is swallowed in the supine position, and images are taken.
  • A barium meal is used to study the lower esophagus and stomach.
  • Barium follow-through is used to study the small intestine.
  • A barium enema is used to study the large intestine and rectum.
  • It is used for the following purposes:
    • Diagnosis of tumour
    • Location of tumour
    • Ulceration
    • Strictures

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents to the emergency department with an acute onset of abdominal pain. She complains of greenish vomiting but denies a history of diarrhea or fever. An X-ray does not show any air-fluid levels. After an extensive assessment, the surgery is planned. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Duodenal obstruction

  • Duodenum is the first part of the small intestine.
  • Hence, its obstruction does not cause bowel dilation.
  • Moreover, bilious emesis is seen when an obstruction is beyond the second part of the duodenum
  • Small bowel obstruction:
    • Bowel obstruction occurs when the normal flow of intraluminal contents is interrupted, leading to bowel dilation and fluid sequestration within the intestine's lumen proximal to the blockage. At the same time, distal to the blockage, as luminal contents pass, the bowel decompresses.
    • Compromised blood flow to the intestinal tissue due to excessive bowel dilation or strangulation of the mesentery can lead to complications (ischemia, necrosis, perforation), which significantly increase mortality associated with bowel obstruction
    • In the United States and Western Europe, the most common causes of mechanical small bowel obstruction are intraperitoneal adhesions, tumors, and complicated hernias. These three etiologies account for 90 percent of all cases.
    • Less frequent causes of obstruction include Crohn's disease (3 to 7 percent), gallstones (2 percent), Volvulus (4 to 15 percent), and intussusception (4 to 8 percent).
    • The clinical presentation of mechanical small bowel obstruction depends upon the site and etiology of the obstruction.
    • Most patients with small bowel obstruction will present acutely with an abrupt onset of colicky abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and abdominal distention.
    • Vomiting can be severe in patients with proximal small bowel obstruction, while in patients with distal small bowel obstruction, abdominal distension may be more prominent.
    • A minority of patients will present with chronic partial obstruction or intermittent symptoms that resolve only to recur again (recurrent obstructions).
    • A presumptive diagnosis of acute mechanical small bowel obstruction can be made by history and physical examination in many patients, particularly those with prior abdominal surgery or an evident inguinal, femoral, or ventral hernia.
    • Signs of peritonitis with generalized guarding and rebound tenderness may warrant immediate surgical intervention.

 

Option A: CA rectum

  • It is a common cause of large bowel obstruction
  • There is dilatation of both small and large gut.
  • The abdominal distension is dependent on the degree of the obstruction

Option C: Adynamic ileus

  • Adynamic ileus is the failure of passage of enteric contents through the small bowel and colon that are not mechanically obstructed; i.e. it represents a paralysis of intestinal motility.
  • On a radiograph, there is generalized, uniform, gaseous distension of the large and small bowel involvement of large bowel and the lack of a transition point help distinguish it from small bowel obstruction
  • When localized, there may be a sentinel loop

Option D: Pseudo-obstruction

  • Colonic pseudo-obstruction (also known as Ogilvie syndrome) is a potentially fatal condition leading to an acute colonic distention without an underlying mechanical obstruction.
  • It is defined as an acute pseudo-obstruction and dilatation of the colon without mechanical obstruction.
  • The hallmark of colonic pseudo-obstruction is the presence of dilatation of the large bowel (often marked) without evidence of a sharp transition point or mechanically obstructing lesion.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male was admitted with a 6-month history of rectal bleeding, anal discharge, and altered bowel habits. He gave the family history of a grandmother who died of carcinoma of the esophagus. On examination, he had a low rectal mass that was obliterating the anal orifice. A colonoscopy was not possible, but a rectal biopsy revealed a well-differentiated carcinoma of the rectum. Abdominoperineal resection was done. During surgery, he was found to have multiple polyps. Colonoscopy through the colostomy and biopsy confirmed the presence of multiple benign adenomatous polyps involving the entire colon up to the caecum. After counseling, the patient had a total proctocolectomy and an ileostomy done. What is the probable gene mutated in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: APC gene

  • This is a case of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) in which the patient presents with complaints of rectal bleeding, anal discharge, and alteration in bowel habits for six months.
  • Familial adenomatous polyposis is an autosomal dominant disorder.
  • It is characterized by adenomatous polyposis coli (APC) gene mutation, usually located on the long arm of chromosome 5q 21
  • The investigation of choice for screening of family members of FAP patients is APC gene testing.
  • Treatment includes:
    • Restorative proctocolectomy + Ileal pouch-anal anastomosis (J-shaped pouch created).
    • Total proctocolectomy with an end (Brooke) ileostomy.
    • Total abdominal colectomy with ileorectal anastomosis.

Option A: K-ras gene

  • The mutation in the K-ras gene can cause colorectal cancer, lung cancer, and pancreatic cancer.
  • It is located on chromosome 12p 12.1.

Option C: P53 gene

  • Most cancers are caused due to mutation in the P53 gene.
  • It usually causes Li-Fraumeni syndrome.
  • The P53 gene is located on chromosome 17p 13.1

Option D: PIK3CA gene

  • The cancers which are associated with PIK3CA gene mutation cause the production of the p110a subunit, which allows P13K to signal without regulation.
  • Its mutation is usually seen in breast cancer.
  • It is located on chromosome 3q26.3

questions.text: A 55-year-old female presents with complaints of cramping abdominal pain associated with nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea for 6 hours. The patient is on chemotherapy and radiotherapy for cervical carcinoma. Upon abdominal examination, generalized abdominal tenderness with positive bowel sounds is observed. Radiation enteritis is suspected. Which of the following statements regarding this condition is correct?

choices.text: Endoscopy should always be done to find the extent of the injury
Late effects are thrombosis and vascular insufficiency, necrosis, perforation, or stricture formation
Radiotherapy should be immediately stopped in such cases until symptoms subside
General mucosal architecture is intact in chronic cases

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Late effects are thrombosis and vascular insufficiency, necrosis, perforation, or stricture formation:

  • This is the case of acute radiation enteritis caused by direct radiation effects on the mucosa of the bowel, which results in injury to the intestinal mucosa, ulceration, and necrosis.
  • Predisposing factors in the above scenario include advancing age and hypertension.
  • Late effects include: thrombosis, vascular insufficiency, necrosis, and perforation or stricture formation

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Endoscopy should always be done to find the extent of the injury:

  • Endoscopy should usually be avoided in acute cases of radiation-related enteritis as it can increase the risk of perforation.

Option C - Radiotherapy should be immediately stopped in such cases until symptoms subside:

  • The delivery of radiotherapy should be modified to decrease injury to the bowel.

Option D - General mucosal architecture is intact in chronic case:

  • Chronic radiation enteritis is due to obliterative arteritis that leads to intestinal ischemia, which can result in stricture, ulceration, fibrosis, and occasionally fistula formation.

questions.text: What will be the definitive treatment for the remission of acute exacerbation of ulcerative colitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Prednisolone:

  • For acute exacerbation of ulcerative colitis, corticosteroids are the mainstay of treatment.
  • Corticosteroids such as Prednisolone

Incorrect Options:

Option A and C - Sulfasalazine and Aminosalicylic acid:

  • While other medications like sulfasalazine and aminosalicylic acid are commonly used for maintenance therapy or in milder cases of ulcerative colitis

Option D - NSAIDs:

  • NSAIDs are generally avoided in ulcerative colitis as they can worsen symptoms and increase the risk of complications.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male comes to the outpatient department complaining of ball-rolling movements and projectile vomiting of undigested food particles. There is no history of allergy or drug abuse. Vital signs are within normal range. Physical examination reveals visible gastric peristalsis from left to right and a positive succussion splash test. Endoscopy reveals a gastric mass obstructing the pylorus. A biopsy of the lesion revealed gastric adenocarcinoma. Which of the following anemia is a risk factor for the development of gastric carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Option A: Pernicious anemia

  • It is an autoimmune disease due to the CD4+ cell-mediated immune response or antibodies against the stomach's parietal cells.
  • In pernicious anemia, there is progressive destruction of parietal cells, and it results in:
    • Decrease hydrochloric acid secretion, which increases gastric pH.
    • Decrease intrinsic factor secretion impairs vitamin B₁₂ absorption.

Option B: Megaloblastic anemia

  • It is a type of megaloblastic anemia that occurs due to vitamin B₁₂ or folate deficiency.
  • In this anemia, the bone marrow produces stem cells that produce enlarged red blood cells.
    • Fatigue
    • Pallor
    • Shortness of breath.
  • Vitamin B₁₂ deficiency occurs due to the following:
    • Pernicious anemia
    • Gastrectomy
    • Zollinger-Ellison syndrome
    • Pancreatic insufficiency
  • Folate/vitamin B9 deficiency occurs due to the following:
    • Decrease intake of green vegetables, fish, and meat.
    • Cohn’s or ulcerative colitis
    • Hemolytic anemia
    • Increase alcohol intake.

Option C: Aplastic anemia

  • It is a type of anemia in which bone marrow does not produce new blood cells.
  • It is an autoimmune disease in which T-cell-mediated autoimmune destruction of bone marrow occurs.
  • It mostly occurs due to the following:
    • Chemotherapy
    • Toxins (benzene)
    • Certain drugs (like chloramphenicol, carbamazepine, and phenytoin)
    • Autoimmune disorder.
    • Parvovirus (short-lived)
  • It manifests the following:
    • Fatigue
    • Pale skin
    • Shortness of breath
    • Severe bruises
    • Increased risk of infection

Option D: Hemolytic anemia

  • It is a type of anemia that occurs due to the early breakdown of red blood cells.
  • Red blood cells have a 120-day life span; if its breakdown occurs, bone marrow has less time to form new RBCs.
  • There are many types of hemolytic anemia:
    • Sickle cell anemia
    • Thalassemia
    • G6PD deficiency
  • It causes the following signs/symptoms:
    • Jaundice
    • Tachycardia
    • Dyspnea
    • Fatigue
    • Enlarged spleen or liver

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents with severe abdominal and flank pain after a motor vehicle collision where she was the seatbelt-restrained driver. Her abdomen was distended and showing guarding with rebound tenderness. There is frank blood at the urethral orifice, and the introduction of a bladder catheter yielded no urine. Retrograde cystography is shown below. What is the next step in management?

choices.text: Radical cystectomy has to be performed
Simple catheter drainage + Broad-spectrum antibiotics as a precaution for peritonitis
Conservative management is enough, as the intra-abdominal fluid can be drained

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Requires laparotomy:

  • A ruptured intraperitoneal bladder is depicted in the photograph. Note the extraluminal contrast (red arrows) seeping into the peritoneal cavity from outside the normal bladder's boundaries. There is contrast outside of the intestine, in the left paracolic gutter (yellow arrow) according to the above mentioned clinical scenario and image findings, it is diagnosed to be a case of intraperitoneal bladder injury.
  • The intrarenal collecting system and ureter are visualized because the patient had a contrast-enhanced CT done moments earlier.
  • Intraperitoneal Rupture (20%):
    • Blow, kick or fall on a fully distended bladder.
    • Apart from the classic triad suggestive of bladder rupture (Suprapubic pain and tenderness + Difficulty or inability to pass urine + Hematuria), patients develop peritonitis and abdominal distention.
    • Diagnosis is made by retrograde cystography or CT cystography.
    • Cystography demonstrates a typical sunburst appearance. Laparotomy with peritoneal lavage and bladder repair with Suprapubic catheterization (SPC) should be done.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Radical cystectomy has to be performed:

  • The patient has intraperitoneal bladder rupture, so radical cystectomy is not indicated in this case.
  • A radical cystectomy is done to treat cancer that has invaded muscle tissue of the bladder or recurrent noninvasive bladder cancer.

Option C - Simple catheter drainage + Broad-spectrum antibiotics as a precaution for peritonitis:

  • The patient discussed above has intraperitoneal rupture leading to peritonitis.
  • A simple catheter cannot drain it. However, broad-spectrum antibiotics should be given to treat the peritonitis.

Option D - Conservative management is enough, as the intra-abdominal fluid can be drained:

  • Peritonitis requires immediate drainage by doing laparotomy and giving broad-spectrum antibiotics.
  • Conservative management is not enough in this case.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man arrived at the surgical department with a complaint of swelling in his left testicle and groin area. The swelling increased in size during walking and standing, but disappeared while lying down. The patient reported feeling a small mass in the testicle. Upon examination, the doctor found a "bag of worms" in the left scrotum. A Doppler scan revealed abnormal dilatation of the internal spermatic venous system. Which statement is true about this condition?

choices.text: More common on the right side
The usual cause is the absence or incompetence of valves in the proximal testicular vein
Diagnosis can be made by histopathology.

questions.solution:
Option C: The usual cause is the absence or incompetence of valves in the proximal testicular vein

  • Painless swelling in the testes with the feel of a bag of worms suggests varicocele.
  • It is an abnormal dilatation of the pampiniform plexus.
  • Its main cause is the incompetence of valves in the testicular vein.
  • It can be asymptomatic or may present with a dragging sensation.
  • Often bilateral but if present unilateral evaluate for carcinoma
  • Most varicoceles are idiopathic; obstruction of the left testicular vein by a renal tumour or nephrectomy is a cause of varicocele in later life

Option A: Negative impulse on coughing

  • Varicocele cannot be palpated by lying down.
  • Cough impulse is usually positive in varicocele.

Option B: More common on the right side

  • The varicocele is less common on the right side.
  • It is common on the left side.

Option D: Diagnosis can be made by histopathology.

  • Histopathology cannot reveal the diagnosis of varicocele.
  • Diagnosis is made on ultrasound and Doppler scan

questions.text: What is the best initial investigation to confirm the diagnosis of pulmonary embolism?
questions.solution:
Correct Options C- Multi-detector CT (MDCT):

  • In patients with suspected pulmonary embolism, the most appropriate initial investigation to confirm the diagnosis is a Multi-Detector CT (MDCT) scan. MDCT provides detailed images of the pulmonary arteries and can help visualize any blood clots (emboli) that might be causing the symptoms. It's a non-invasive and efficient way to assess the pulmonary vasculature and diagnose or rule out pulmonary embolism. While other options, such as D-dimer assay and ECG, may contribute to the diagnostic process, MDCT is the primary imaging modality used for confirmation.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A, B & D are incorrect.

questions.text: A 34-year-old patient presented to the hospital. Ptosis of the upper and lower eyelid and anhidrosis of the same side could be seen. Later on, he was diagnosed with Horner syndrome. Which of the following could be the possible symptom of horner syndrome?
questions.solution:
Option A: Pin point pupil

  • Under normal circumstances, the pupils enlarge or contract to let in the appropriate amount of light. In low light, they expand or dilate to let in more light; in high light, they contract or close to keep out too much light
  • Although not an illness in and of themselves, pinpoint pupils may be a sign of another medical condition. Anyone who has pinpointed pupils without a known cause should consult a physician right away.
  • One of the three main signs is the pinhole pupil in one eye. On the affected side, the other two are drooping upper eyelids.
  • Miosis or myosis, which derives from the Greek word mū́ein, which means "to close the eyes," is the term used in medicine to describe pinpoint pupils.

Option B: Seizures

  • A seizure is an abrupt, uncontrolled electrical breakdown in the brain. Effects include modifications to feelings, states of awareness, and behaviours.
  • Epilepsy is typically defined as two or more seizures that occur more than 24 hours apart and are not caused by a clear reason.
  • They are a common presenting feature, especially in low-grade gliomas in the cortical hemispheres.
  • Simple partial seizures involving focal twitching or similar with preserved consciousness are the rule. However, the temporal location will commonly produce complex partial seizures, and any seizure may progress to a secondary generalised tonic colonic fit.

Option C: Headache

  • Often described as a throbbing, continuous, intense or mild pressure, a headache is a discomfort in the head or face.
  • Regarding pain type, intensity, location, and frequency, headaches can be very different. Most people will suffer from headaches at some point or another throughout their lives.
  • Headaches may be the result of a blow to the head or, very rarely, they are a sign of a more serious medical condition. 
  • Despair and emotional stress, drinking, skipping meals, altering sleep schedules, and overmedicating. Other factors include bad posture, which can strain the neck or back.

Option D: Focal neurological deficit

  • A problem with the nerve, spinal cord or brain function is a localised neurologic impairment. It just affects a certain area, like the tongue or the left side of the face. It can also affect the right arm. Problems with hearing, sight, or speech are also regarded as focused neurological impairments.
  • A focal deficit progressive over time, as opposed to the sudden onset of a vascular accident, is suspicious of the tumour.
  • Lesions generally produce characteristic deficits due to the local pressure effect and location.
  • Examples include:
    • Abnormal blood vessels (vascular malformation)
    • Brain tumour
    • Cerebral palsy

questions.text: A 56-year-old female presents with severe chest pain and breathlessness after coming back from cremation grounds due to the death of her husband. ECG shows S.T. elevation in the precordial leads, most noticeably in V2-V3. Troponin T and Brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) are mildly elevated. Invasive coronary angiography shows completely normal coronary arteries. A transthoracic echocardiogram demonstrates apical akinesis and a left ventricular ejection fraction of 40%. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Takotsubo cardiomyopathy

  • Takotsubo cardiomyopathy most commonly affects elderly women.
  • The condition is caused by an extremely stressful physical or emotional event.
  • Angiography is normal despite all findings of Myocardial Infarction (MI)
  • Apical Akinesia and low ejection fraction both pointing towards Takotsubo cardiomyopathy
  • It can cause cardiogenic shock, and death can occur
  • Treatment is an Intra-aortic balloon pump (IABP)

Option A: Anxiety

  • In the given cause, apical Akinesia and low ejection fraction point towards Takotsubo cardiomyopathy, so anxiety could not be the cause.

Option B: Septal myocardial infarction

  • In the above scenario, there is no obstruction of the coronary arteries, and the echocardiogram demonstrates findings significantly associated with Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

Option C: Coronary artery spasm

  • Coronary artery spasms would be self-resolving, and the echocardiographic findings are not seen in the cases of artery spasms.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female presents to the emergency department due to breathlessness and palpitations for 2 days. It is associated with fatigue. Her past medical history includes a history of rheumatic fever (RF) at the age of 15 years. She was prescribed penicillin at that time, but she had been non-compliant. She has no family history of heart disease. Her blood pressure is 123/82mmHg, her pulse is 63/min, and her BMI is 23kg/m2. Auscultation reveals a mid-systolic click followed by a late-systolic murmur at the cardiac apex. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Mitral valve prolapse

  • Mitral valve prolapse (MVP) is also called Floppy valve syndrome or Barlow syndrome.
  • Causes of MVP include:
  • Myxomatous degeneration of mitral valve apparatus
  •  Marfan syndrome
  •  Ehler Danlos syndrome
  • Osteogenesis imperfecta
  • Anteroposterior diameter decrease
  • Rheumatic fever
  • Ostium secondum atrial septal defect (ASD)​​​​​​​
  • The patients present with palpitations, lightheadedness, shortness of breath and fatigue.
  • The mitral valve presents with mid-systolic click and late systolic murmur.
  • The mid-systolic click occurs due to extra tension generated in the chordae tendineae during exercise.
  • The late systolic murmur occurs due to the leakage of blood into the left atrium.
  • Chest x-ray, echocardiograms, ECG, and cardiac catheterization are used to diagnose mitral valve prolapse.
  • Treatment includes using beta-blockers, diuretics, antiarrhythmics, anticoagulants and antibiotics.
  • Complications include mitral valve regurgitation and arrhythmias.
  • Mitral valve repair or replacement is required in cases of severe mitral regurgitation.

Option B: Hamman-rich syndrome

  • Hamman-rich syndrome is an idiopathic interstitial lung disease.
  • It progresses rapidly and may lead to ARDS and fulminant respiratory failure.

Option C: Rheumatic aortic regurgitation

  • Rheumatic aortic regurgitation causes an early diastolic murmur.
  • A mid-diastolic murmur will be heard in severe aortic regurgitation, called the Austin flint murmur.

Option D: Congenital mitral stenosis

  • The mitral valve controls blood flow from the left atrium to the left ventricle of the heart, and the narrowing of this valve is known as mitral stenosis.
  • Congenital mitral stenosis leads to mid-diastolic murmur with presystolic accentuation.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man presented to the physician's office complaining of sudden onset of palpitations. The patient was clinically normal on physical examination except for an irregular pulse. What does the ECG show?
questions.solution:
Option A: Ventricular Extra-systole

Ventricular extra-systole

  • The premature ventricular complex is a premature beat arising from an ectopic focus within the ventricles. These include ventricular extra-systoles.

  • It occurs due to single ventricular impulses from abnormal automation of the ventricular cells or the presence of re-entry circuits in the ventricle.
  • The patients are symptomatic (palpitations) or asymptomatic.
  • The ECG shows a heart rate of 100 beats/min with a normal axis.
  • P wave and PR interval are within normal limits.
  • Wide complex QRS is noted in the lead II, III indicating Ventricular extra-systoles or premature ventricular contractions (prematurely appearing QRS complex)
  • After an incorrect QRS complex, a compensatory pause is always observed.
  • ST segment and QT interval are within normal limits.
  • In young and asymptomatic individuals, extra-systoles do not indicate significant heart disease.

Option B: Complete heart block

  • Broad QRS complex
  • Prolonged PR interval
  • PP interval (Atrial Rate) is not matching the RR interval (Ventricular Rate).
  • Canon A waves in JVP

Option C: Sinus Tachycardia

  • ECG shows normal upright P wave in lead II after every QRS complex
  • Ventricular rate > 100 bpm

Option D: PSVT

  • ECG findings of PSVT
    1. Narrow QRS complex
    2. R-R interval decreased
    3. Hidden P waves due to the merging of P and the T waves
    4. ST segment depression: Because of the mismatch between the demand and supply of Oxygen, there will be some magnitude of ST segment depression

questions.text: A 50-year-old man suffered from central chest pain and collapsed while attending a conference. He was rushed to a nearby hospital, where his ECG was recorded in the emergency room. What is your diagnosis based on the ECG findings shown below?
questions.solution:
Option A: R on T phenomenon

  • ECG shows ST segment changes in lead II, III indicating inferior wall MI (BLUE ARROW)
  • Ventricular extra-systole after the first beat (RED MARK)

  • In the fourth beat, ventricular extra-systole (YELLOW) occurs when the T wave triggers a polymorphic ventricular tachycardia.
  • The "R-on-T phenomenon" is the superimposition of an ectopic beat on the T wave of a preceding beat which triggers Polymorphic VT.
  • Torsades de pointes is initiated when premature ventricular contractions (PVC) occur during the preceding T wave, known as the R on T phenomenon.
  • The onset of Torsades is often preceded by a sequence of short-long R-R intervals, so-called pause-dependent TDP.
  • In a pattern of ventricular bigeminy, there is a sinus rhythm with numerous premature ventricular contractions. Each PVC falls on the previous T wave, and the QT interval is noticeably prolonged (R on T phenomenon).

Option B: Macro-rentrant circuit

  • The macro-reentrant circuit is seen in the atrial tachycardias that occur in atrial fibrosis due to prior catheter ablation or post-atriotomy.
  • The hallmark of macro reentry is the ability to entrain tachycardia with fusion.​​​​​​​

Option C: Early after-depolarisation

  • It is the abnormality of the repolarisation process of an action potential which results in an interruption or retardation of normal repolarisation.
  • It is defined as the slowing or reversal of normal repolarisation during phase 2 or phase 3 of the action potential.
  • This results in torsades de pointes, tachycardia and other arrhythmias.

Option D: AV nodal reentry

  • The AV nodal reentry phenomenon is seen in paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardias.

​​​​​​​​​​​​

questions.text: A 45-years-old female presented to the emergency department with complaints of nausea, vomiting, and lethargy for the past 1 day. On a general physical examination, the woman looks dehydrated with a pulse of 110 beats/minute, blood pressure of 98/64 mmHg, temperature is 101°F, and oxygen saturation of 96% at room air. She has a history of diabetes mellitus type 1 with poor compliance with her insulin regime. Blood glucose level is high, and serum ketones are 3.2mmol/dl. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: 500ml of 0.9% Saline over 15 minutes and a fixed rate insulin infusion
500ml of 0.9% Saline over 15 minutes with potassium chloride and a fixed rate insulin infusion
500ml of 0.9% Saline over 30 minutes with potassium chloride and a rapid-acting subcutaneous insulin injection
500ml of 0.9% Saline over 30 minutes and a rapid-acting subcutaneous insulin injection

questions.solution:
Option B:  500ml of 0.9% Saline over 15 minutes with potassium chloride and a fixed-rate insulin infusion.

  • Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) is an acute complication of diabetes mellitus(more common in type 1 DM).
  • It is a life-threatening medical emergency.
  • It is caused by insulin deficiency and excess glucagon, leading to severe hyperglycemia and accelerated ketogenesis.
  • Severe hyperglycemia leads to osmotic diuresis, causing dehydration and volume depletion.
  • Elevated ketone bodies cause metabolic acidosis.
  • Elevated lipolysis leads to increased free fatty acids and more ketogenesis from free fatty acids producing ketone bodies (beta-hydroxybutyrate, acetoacetate, and acetone).
  • DKA  is precipitated by stress or illness such as infections, trauma, myocardial infarction, stroke, recent surgery, sepsis, gastrointestinal bleeding, or inadequate insulin administration.
  • Clinical presentation
    • Vomiting, Nausea, Fever.
    • Kussmaul breathing (rapid, deep breathing), fruity (acetone) breath odor,
    • Abdominal pain (may mimic acute abdomen with guarding and rigidity), dehydration, tachycardia, polydipsia, polyuria, weakness, and altered mental status (drowsiness, confusion, delirium, psychosis, and coma).
  • Laboratory values will show
    • Hyperglycemia (serum glucose >450 mg/dl and <850mg/dl),
    • Low serum pH (pH <7.3) and bicarbonate (<15mg/dl), and high anion gap metabolic acidosis(due to the production of acidic ketone bodies),
    • Leukocytosis, increased urine, and blood ketone levels (serum levels of acetone, acetoacetate, and beta-hydroxybutyrate are raised), leukocytosis, hyponatremia (sodium levels fall by 1.6mEq/l for every 100mg/dl rise in glucose levels),
    • Elevated serum amylase and increased serum potassium(due to acidosis, potassium is shifted from the intracellular to the extracellular compartment; however, total body potassium is low).
  • The management of diabetic ketoacidosis is as follows:
    • Intravenous(IV)/subcutaneous(SC) regular insulin: 500ml of 0.9% Saline over 15 minutes with potassium chloride and a fixed rate insulin infusion. Regular insulin is the only type of insulin that can be given intravenously and subcutaneously.
    • In emergencies such as DKA, hyperglycemic hyperosmolar state, and acute hyperkalemia, IV regular insulin is given. Subcutaneous regular insulin is given just as the diagnosis is made. A dose of regular insulin of 0.1 units/kg is given IV as the primary dose, followed by an infusion of regular insulin of 0.1 units/kg/hour in 0.9%saline. Continue the insulin until the anion gap is corrected. Give subcutaneous insulin when the patient starts eating again.
    • Fluid replacement is done with IV normal saline. 5% or 10% dextrose can be added when the blood glucose levels fall to 200mg/dl.
    • Potassium replacement is done prophylactically with IV fluids. Due to insulin deficiency, potassium efflux from the cells into extracellular space, and serum potassium levels are falsely elevated. Insulin infusion causes potassium to move back into the cells, causing hypokalemia, which is dangerous as it can cause arrhythmias. So KCl is added to IV fluids with insulin to avoid hypokalemia.
    • If serum potassium levels are <3.5 mmol/l, then insulin should be held, and 20-30mmol/l KCl is given until serum potassium is >3.5mmol/l.
    • If serum potassium levels are 3.5-5.2mmol/l, then KCl is given along with IV fluids to maintain serum potassium levels at 4-5mmol/l.
    • If serum potassium levels are >5.2 mmol/l, then there is no need to add KCl in saline infusion.
  • Complications of DKA include
    • Life-threatening mucormycosis, cerebral edema, cardiac arrhythmias, heart failure, respiratory fatigue and failure, and pulmonary edema.

Option A: 500ml of 0.9% Saline over 15 minutes and a fixed rate insulin infusion.

  • Insulin causes an influx of potassium ions into the cells leading to hypokalemia. So KCl should be added to the saline and insulin infusion while treating DKA.

Option C: 500ml of 0.9% Saline over 30 minutes with potassium chloride and a rapid-acting subcutaneous insulin injection

  • Regular insulin is the only preparation of insulin that can be given intravenously. In emergencies such as DKA, intravenous insulin treatment is preferred.

Option D: 500ml of 0.9% Saline over 30 minutes and rapid-acting subcutaneous insulin injection.

  • Rapid-acting insulin can not be given intravenously. In DKA, regular intravenous insulin is given.

questions.text: A 63-year-old female comes to the diabetic clinic for a routine checkup. She was diagnosed with diabetes mellitus type-2 and hypertension 12 years back. Her body mass index is 32kg/m2. Dietary and lifestyle modifications such as exercise failed to provide adequate glycemic control. She is currently on insulin and antihypertensive therapy. On examination, her face looks puffy, and her legs and feet show bilateral oedema. Estimated glomerular filtration rate is 26 ml/min/1.73m2, urine albumin to creatinine ratio is 270mg/g. She was diagnosed with chronic kidney disease stage G4A2 (CKD stage 4). Which of the following is the most appropriate insulin dose adjustment required in this patient with chronic kidney disease?
questions.solution:
Option B: Decrease insulin.

  • Diabetes mellitus (DM) is a disease of beta cells of the pancreas.
  • It is characterized by polydipsia, polyphagia, polyuria, fatigue, weight loss, blurred vision, fungal infections, numbness and tingling of hands and feet, diabetic ketoacidosis, and hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state.
  • This patient has diabetes mellitus and hypertension, which are the most common risk factors for developing chronic kidney disease.
  • Chronic kidney disease (CKD) :
    • It is defined as decreased kidney function (low glomerular filtration rate(GFR) <60ml/min) for at least 3 months. It is classified based on glomerular filtration rate, urine albumin to creatinine ratio, and the underlying pathology. 
  • The kidneys play an important role in insulin degradation and removal from circulation.
  • The plasma half-life of insulin can rise in patients with chronic kidney disease in both fasting and postprandial states.
    • Because of decreased renal degradation of plasma insulin, patients on insulin therapy may need a progressive reduction in their dose as their renal function decreases.
    • Oral hypoglycemics such as sulfonylureas and metformin are contraindicated when the glomerular filtration rate is less than normal. Others, such as DPP-4 inhibitors (sitagliptin), may require dose reduction in renal failure.
  • Glucose metabolism is impaired in CKD. However, fasting blood glucose is usually normal or only slightly elevated, and mild glucose intolerance does not require specific therapy.

Option A: Increase insulin.

  • In chronic kidney disease, insulin dosage should be reduced due to impaired clearance of insulin by the kidneys.

Option C: No adjustment.

  • Dose adjustment of insulin is required in patients with chronic kidney disease.

Option D: Add DPP-4 inhibitors.

  • The kidneys clear DPP-4 inhibitors such as sitagliptin, so they should not be used to treat a patient with chronic kidney disease.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents to the clinic with increased weight gain and fatigue. She delivered a baby five months ago with no prenatal complications. Initially, she considered it average postpartum weight gain, but her health continued to deteriorate with an increase in fatigue by every day. Physical examination shows swelling in the neck, dry skin, and brittle nails. Lab shows an increase in TSH and a decrease in T3 and T4. Which of the following statements is irrelevant to the diagnosis of this patient?

choices.text: Glucocorticoids are almost always helpful as a treatment option

questions.solution:
Option D: Glucocorticoids are almost always helpful as a treatment option

  • A female with complaints of weight gain, fatigue, brittle nails, dry skin and increased neck swelling after pregnancy mostly suffers from postpartum thyroiditis.
  • It is a self-limiting disease and resolves itself.
  • No steroid use is advised.

Option A: It is self limiting disease

  • A female with complaints of weight gain, fatigue, brittle nails, dry skin and increased neck swelling after pregnancy mainly suffers from postpartum thyroiditis.
  • The lab values are also consistent with the diagnosis.
  • The patient first develops thyrotoxicosis, followed by hypothyroidism and then resolution.
  • it is a self limiting disease

Option B: It is associated with thyrotoxicosis

  • Thyrotoxicosis means an increase in the number of circulating thyroid hormones (T3 and T4) in the body due to any condition.
  • In postpartum thyroiditis, initially, thyrotoxicosis occurs due to the preformed thyroid hormones during the breakdown of the thyroid gland, which causes hyperthyroidism in the body.
  • This clinical state is followed by hypothyroidism, leading to a euthyroid state.

Option C: It is associated with hypothyroidism

  • Hypothyroidism occurs due to the depletion of thyroid hormone in the body.
  • It is a brief state.
  • It eventually leads to a euthyroid state. ​​​​​​​

questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes to the clinic complaining of fatigue, muscle pain, tremors and heat intolerance. The patient has no child after seven years of marriage. Medical history shows weight loss and increased appetite problems since an early age. His blood pressure is 130/90 mmHg, and his pulse is 95 beats/min. Physical examination shows bulging eyes and sweat on hands. Lab shows an increase in T3 and T4 levels. He is suffering from thyrotoxicosis. Which of the following statement is most appropriate for thyrotoxicosis?

choices.text: Small firm thyroid is seen in Grave’s disease
High cardiac output state with low pulse pressure
Most common cardiac rhythm disorder seen is atrial fibrillation
Myxoedema is seen in both hypothyroidism and hyperthyroidism

questions.solution:
Option D: Myxoedema is seen in both hypothyroidism and hyperthyroidism

  • Pretibial Myxoedema is seen in Grave’s disease (hyperthyroidism).
  • It occurs due to the stimulation of fibroblasts by antibodies.
  • It results in the excess production of hyaluronic acid in the dermis and sub-cutis.
  • It presents as the induration and thickening of the skin over the shin.

  • Myxoedema is a generalised swelling involving vocal cords, skin, scalp and Achilles tendon and is a feature of hypothyroidism.

Option A: Small firm thyroid is seen in Grave’s disease

  • The thyroid gland is soft and enlarged in Grave’s disease.
  • It is a subtype of hyperthyroidism in which thyroid-stimulating antibodies act on TSH receptors, increasing thyroid hormone levels.
  • A diffusely enlarged thyroid gland can be seen on radioactive iodine uptake.

Option B: High cardiac output state with low pulse pressure

  • Excess thyroid hormones lead to tachycardia.
  • It is high cardiac output with wide pulse pressure.
  • Low pulse pressure is mainly seen in hypothyroidism

Option C: Most common cardiac rhythm disorder seen is atrial fibrillation

  • The most common cardiac rhythm disorder in thyrotoxicosis is sinus tachycardia.
  • Atrial fibrillation is more common in secondary thyrotoxicosis.

questions.text: A 47-year-old male with a history of sudden death in an adult member of his family presents with bilateral flank pain and hematuria, anorexia, and newly diagnosed hypertension and is undergoing an ultrasonogram of the abdomen and pelvis. Which of the following findings are most likely to be found in this patient?

choices.text: Multiple cysts in the renal cortex and medulla bilaterally with hepatic fibrosis and enlarged kidneys
Multiple cysts in the renal cortex and medulla bilaterally, benign hepatic cysts, and enlarged kidneys
Multiple cysts in renal cortex and medulla bilaterally, septated and calcified hepatic cysts, and enlarged kidneys
Multiple cysts in the renal cortex and medulla bilaterally, benign hepatic cysts, and shrunken kidneys

questions.solution:
Option B: Multiple cysts in the renal cortex and medulla bilaterally, benign hepatic cysts, and enlarged kidneys.

  • The given scenario is of ADPKD, with a family history of the sudden death of an adult member due to subarachnoid haemorrhage caused by spontaneous rupture of Berry aneurysm.
  • Newly diagnosed hypertension is because of chronic kidney disease. Similarly, Anorexia is because of uremia due to progressive renal failure.
  •  Along with other history, hematuria and bilateral flank pain also point to ADPKD.
  • On ultrasound abdomen, in ADPKD, the kidneys show multiple cysts in the renal cortex and medulla bilaterally, causing enlargement of the kidneys.
  • Multiple cysts in bilateral kidneys involving both medulla and cortex, with bilaterally enlarged kidneys and benign hepatic cysts, are the features of ADPKD on Ultrasonogram.

Option A: Multiple cysts in the renal cortex and medulla bilaterally with hepatic fibrosis and enlarged kidneys

  • Hepatic fibrosis is seen in ARPKD, not in ADPKD. In ADPKD, benign hepatic cysts are found.

Option C: Multiple cysts in renal cortex and medulla bilaterally, septated and calcified hepatic cysts, and enlarged kidneys

  • In ADPKD, only Benign hepatic cysts are found, and not those compound, septated or calcified cysts.

Option D: Multiple cysts in the renal cortex and medulla bilaterally, benign hepatic cysts, and shrunken kidneys

  • Shrunken kidneys are found in medullary cystic kidney disease, not in ADPKD.

questions.text: A 7-day-old male infant is brought in with a frequent history of apnea, each lasting 20–60 seconds, associated with bradycardia and alternating with hyperpnoea & abnormal eye movements. Physical examination & initial investigations are not significant. On further workup, an MRI of the brain shows characteristic molar tooth sign. Which of the following pathology is associated with the above syndrome?
questions.solution:
Option C: Nephronophthisis

  • The above clinical history & findings lead to the diagnosis of Joubert syndrome.

Joubert syndrome

  • Joubert syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder involving mutations in at least 10 different genes, including NPHP1, AHI1, and CEP290, and is a rare brain malformation characterized by the absence or underdevelopment of the cerebellar vermis as well as malformed brainstem.
  • The most common features of Joubert syndrome in infants include an abnormally rapid breathing pattern(hyperpnoea), abnormal eye movements, decreased muscle tone(hypotonia), intellectual disability, and inability to coordinate voluntary muscle movements(ataxia).
  • The most important radiologic finding in Joubert syndrome is the Molar tooth sign.
  • The molar tooth sign refers to the appearance of the midbrain in an axial section. Actually, there is an abnormally deep interpeduncular fossa; elongated, thick, and mal-oriented superior cerebellar peduncles; and absent or hypoplastic cerebellar vermis that together gives an appearance of a "molar tooth" or a wisdom tooth on the axial brain MRI through the junction of the midbrain and hindbrain (isthmus region).
  • Joubert syndrome is associated with Nephronophthisis, a ciliopathy(caused by a defect in primary cilium) characterized by tubular basement membrane disruption, interstitial nephritis, and cyst formation.
  • On ultrasonography, nephronophthisis is characterized by normal or shrunken kidneys, loss of corticomedullary differentiation, and corticomedullary cysts.

Option A: ADPKD

  • ADPKD cannot present itself in the neonatal period. It is also cystic kidney disease, but it does not have neurological manifestations. Also, in ADPKD, there are corticomedullary cysts as in nephronophthisis, but the kidney size is enlarged, whereas, in nephronophthisis, the kidney size is normal or decreased (shrunken) because of nephritis causing fibrosis.

Option B: Medullary cystic kidney disease

  • In Medullary cystic kidney disease, there are cysts in the medulla. In nephronophthisis, there are cysts in the cortex and medulla, along with neurological manifestation.

Option D: ARPKD

  • ARPKD doesn't have neurological manifestations. In ARPKD, there are cysts in collecting ducts. Moreover, the kidney size is increased in contrast to the nephronophthisis.

questions.text: A 10-month-old child is brought to the pediatric department with complaints of nausea and vomiting. The child is malnourished, along with mild to moderate dehydration. The child had a previous history of cerebral palsy at the 5th month of age. Serum electrolytes and ABGs are also abnormal. Barter syndrome has been diagnosed in the child. Which of the following are associated with bartter syndrome?

choices.text: Urinary calcium increased, and Mineralocorticoid antagonists can not be used
Metabolic acidosis is present, Mineralocorticoid antagonist cannot be used, and normal to low blood pressure
Urinary calcium increased, Hypokalemic alkalosis and normal to low blood pressure
Urinary calcium increased, Hypokalemic alkalosis, Mineralocorticoid antagonist can not be used and normal to low blood pressure

questions.solution:
Option C: Urinary calcium increased, Hypokalemic alkalosis, and normal to low blood pressure

  • Bartter syndrome is a renal tubular salt-wasting disorder in which the kidneys cannot reabsorb sodium and chloride in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle. This results in extracellular fluid volume depletion with low/normal blood pressure.
  • The defect in Barter syndrome in the thick ascending limb of Loop of Henle - increase urinary loss of calcium & nephrocalcinosis
  • The salt wasting and polyuria lead to dehydration - stimulating the R.A.A.S. - secondary hyperaldosteronism. This explains hypokalemia.
  • R.O.M.K. receptors in T.A.L. are affected, leading to urinary loss of potassium.
  • Increased intra-renal prostaglandins and hence indomethacin is prescribed.
  • Secondary aldosteronism explains the development of metabolic alkalosis

Option A: Urinary calcium increased, and Mineralocorticoid antagonist can not be used

  • Mineralocorticoid antagonists are used for the treatment
  • Other agents which are used for the treatment are NSAIDs and A.C.E.I.s/A.R.B.s

Option B: Metabolic acidosis is present, Mineralocorticoid antagonist cannot be used, and normal to low blood pressure

  • Mineralocorticoid antagonists are used for the treatment
  • Moreover, there is metabolic alkalosis, not acidosis.

Option D: Urinary calcium increased, Hypokalemic alkalosis, Mineralocorticoid antagonist can not be used and normal to low blood pressure

  • Mineralocorticoid antagonists such as spironolactone can be used to manage Barter syndrome.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presented to the clinic with chronic complaints of burning sensation and discomfort over the epigastrium. He has a duodenal ulcer and H. pylori infection on endoscopy and biopsy. He has been prescribed proton pump inhibitors (PPI) & advised to follow up. Which of the following is a side effect of prolonged intake of PPI?
questions.solution:
Option A: Decreasing the effect of clopidogrel

  • Clopidogrel, an inactive prodrug, is converted to a thiolactone intermediate and then to an active metabolite that binds irreversibly to ADP receptors on the platelet surface.

  • Multiple cytochrome (CYP) enzymes catalyze these two stages, with CYP2C19 playing an essential role in both.

  • As with most CYP enzymes, CYP2C19 activity can be altered by other medicines, and CYP2C19 inhibitors can theoretically reduce clopidogrel's antiplatelet efficacy by interfering with its bioactivation.

  • PPIs' competitive suppression of CYP2C19 is the theoretical basis for their interaction with clopidogrel.

Option B: Wrist fracture

  • The incidence of all fractures, severe osteoporotic fractures, hip fractures, vertebral fractures, and other fractures rose with PPI usage, but not the risk of wrist and humerus fractures.

  • The risk of any fractures, major osteoporotic fractures, and other fractures increased for PPI adherence when the proportion of days covered (PDC) was less than 0.80.

Option C: Eradication of Clostridium difficile infection

  • PPIs significantly reduce the amount of stomach acid produced, which promotes spores' growth and capacity to transform into a vegetative form of C. difficile.

  • PPIs also hinder leukocyte activity by preventing phagocytosis and acidifying the phagolysosome.

Option D: Decreased risk of community-acquired pneumonia

  • Proton pump inhibitors are associated with an increased, not decreased, risk of community-acquired pneumonia (CAP).

questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient presented to the emergency department with pain in the epigastrium and difficulty breathing for 6 hours. On examination, his heart rate was 56 beats per minute, and his blood pressure was 106/60 mmHg. Chest examination was normal. The patient has been taking omeprazole for gastroesophageal reflux for the last six months. What is the best initial investigation?
questions.solution:
Option A: An ECG

  • The patient has bradycardia and hypotension and is an older adult. A risk factor for coronary artery disease in this patient is age. Chest pain might be deceiving. The presence of bradycardia, hypotension and shortness of breath suggest myocardial infarction.
  • So an electrocardiogram (ECG) should be performed as part of the initial evaluation at the presentation.
  • In inferior wall myocardial infarction, a second-degree heart block (intermittent atrioventricular block) may manifest as a temporary anomaly.
  • Even though many patients within the first hour of myocardial infarction have normal blood pressure and pulse rates, up to one-half of patients with inferior infarction exhibit parasympathetic hyperactivity (bradycardia and hypotension) and about one-fourth of patients with anterior infarction do.

Option B: An upper GI endoscopy

  • An upper gastrointestinal endoscopy is a very invasive and expensive procedure. It can be performed after initial evaluation if a peptic ulcer, gastric cancer, or oesophageal pathology is suspected.
  • Endoscopy with biopsy is the investigation of choice for evaluating gastric ulcers.

Option C: Urgent ultrasound of the abdomen

  • Ultrasound of the abdomen is indicated if pancreatitis or cholecystitis is suspected.
  • In this patient, bradycardia and hypotension point towards a cardiac origin of epigastric pain.
  • Nonetheless, in patients with coronary disease risk factors, ECG should be prioritized over ultrasound.

Option D: An X-ray chest

  • An X-ray of the chest is indicated chest pain if spontaneous pneumothorax is suspected.
  • It is also the best initial investigation into the perforation of the gastrointestinal tract.
  • This patient has been complying with his regimen of proton-pump inhibitors, and signs of peritonitis, such as rebound tenderness and guarding, are absent in this patient.

questions.text: A 34-year-old female presents to the office with the complaint of diarrhoea for the past 3 months. Her stools are bloody. After a thorough assessment, a diagnosis of ulcerative colitis is made. Which of the following is associated with ulcerative colitis?

choices.text: Can involve any site of GIT

questions.solution:
Option B: Strictures are rarely seen

  • Ulcerative colitis is characterized by recurring episodes of inflammation limited to the mucosal and submucosal layers of the colon.
  • It commonly involves the rectum and may extend proximally and continuously to involve other parts of the colon. 
  • Patients with ulcerative colitis usually present with diarrhoea, which is frequently associated with blood.
  • Associated symptoms include colicky abdominal pain, urgency, and tenesmus.
  • Patients with mainly distal disease may have constipation accompanied by frequent discharge of blood and mucus.
  • Patients may also have a fever, fatigue, and weight loss.
  • Ulcerative colitis primarily involves the intestine but may be associated with several extraintestinal manifestations
  • Stricture formation is not seen and is more familiar with Crohn’s disease.

Option A: Can involve any site of GIT

  • Ulcerative colitis usually involves the colon.
  • The rectum is spared.
  • Crohn’s disease can involve any part of the GIT.

Option C: Histopathology shows non-caseating granulomas

  • Crohn's disease, rather than UC colitis, involves any part of the gut.
  • Moreover, Non-caseating granuloma is seen in CD, not in UC.

Option D: Inflammation is transmural

  • Only mucosa and submucosa are involved in UC.
  • Transmural inflammation is seen in CD.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents to the office with the complaint of diarrhoea for the past 3 months. Her stools are non-bloody. She also has a history of nephrolithiasis. After a thorough assessment, a diagnosis of Crohn's disease is made. Which of the following is not associated with Crohn's disease?

choices.text: Inflammation is limited to mucosa and submucosa
Toxic megacolon is rare compared to ulcerative colitis

questions.solution:
Option A: Inflammation is limited to mucosa and submucosa

Crohn’s disease:

  • CD can affect any part of the gastrointestinal (GI) tract from the mouth to the anus.
  • Some 30–40% of patients have small bowel disease alone, 40–55% have disease involving both the small and large intestines, and 15–25% have colitis alone.
  • In 75% of patients with small intestinal disease, the terminal ileum is involved in 90%.
  • Unlike UC, which almost always involves the rectum, the rectum is often spared in CD.
  • CD is segmental with skip areas in the midst of the diseased intestine.
  • Perirectal fistulas, fissures, abscesses, and anal stenosis are present in one-third of patients with CD, particularly those with colonic involvement.
  • Rarely, CD may also involve the liver and the pancreas.
  • Toxic megacolon is a rare complication.
  • Unlike UC, the CD is a transmural process. This can result in the formation of a fistula.
  • Endoscopically, aphthous or small superficial ulcerations characterize mild disease; in more active disease, stellate ulcerations fuse longitudinally and transversely to demarcate islands of mucosa that frequently are histologically normal.

Option B: Fistulas can be seen

  • CD is a transmural inflammation not just limited to mucosa and submucosa
  • This predisposes to the formation of fistulas.

Option C: Toxic megacolon is rare compared to ulcerative colitis

  • Toxic megacolon is rarely seen in CD as compared to UC.

Option D: Presents as skip lesions

  • The inflammation in the CD involves the layers of the intestine.
  • Moreover, skip lesions are seen in CD.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man is brought to the ED by an ambulance after being involved in a road traffic accident. He was an unrestrained passenger and sustained considerable trauma. The patient in ICU receives an emergency blood transfusion as part of the resuscitation efforts. 3 hours later, SpO2 is reduced to 75% with respiratory difficulty. CVP is 15cm water and PCWP is 25mm Hg. CXR is shown below. What should be the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Transfusion-associated circulatory overload

  • Transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO) is a frequently found transfusion reaction.
  • Pulmonary oedema develops initially due to excessive volume or circulatory overload.
  • Findings on an x-ray suggestive of pulmonary oedema include Kerley B lines or interlobular septa thickening.
  • The presence of respiratory distress after blood transfusion, along with elevated CVP and PCWP, points towards a diagnosis of transfusion-associated circulatory overload.
  • Management include:
    • Immediate stopping of transfusion and other steps for suspected transfusion reactions.
    • Placing the patient in an upright position.
    • Oxygen and diuretics can be needed in some patients.
    • Mechanical ventilation and treatment in the intensive care unit (ICU) may be required in serious cases.
  • Table showing the difference between findings of transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO) and transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI)
  TACO TRALI
Ejection Fraction < 40% > 40%
PCWP > 18 mm Hg ≤ 18 mm Hg
CXR CTR > 0.55 CTR < 0.55
Fluid Balance Positive Neutral
BNP > 1200 pg/mL < 250 pg/mL
BP ↑ ↓
Temperature Unchanged Febrile
WBC Unchanged Transient ↓

Option A: Tension pneumothorax

  • Symptoms include chest pain, rapid breathing, shortness of breath, and palpitation, followed by shock.
  • X-ray chest P/A view findings suggesting a tension pneumothorax include increased translucency in one hemithorax with increased intercostal space compared to the contralateral hemithorax and deviation of tracheal, oesophageal, and mediastinum away from the pneumothorax.

Option B: Transfusion-related acute lung injury.

  • The typical presentation of transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI) is the sudden development of shortness of breath, severe hypoxemia (O2 saturation <90% in room air), and hypotension.
  • Can also present with fever (develop within 6 hours after transfusion) typically resolve within 48 to 96 hours.
  • PCWP in TRALI is ≤ 18 mm Hg.

Option D: Mismatched blood transfusion

  • Fever, chills, urticaria (hives), and itching are commonly found in mismatched blood transfusions.
  • Some symptoms resolve with no or little treatment. However, high fever, respiratory distress, hypotension and red urine indicate a more serious reaction.

questions.text: You are a first-year medicine resident rotating in the department of haematology. A group of patients came for follow-up after having allogeneic bone marrow transplantation. Which of the following has the least 5-year survival rate following allogeneic bone marrow transplantation?
questions.solution:
Option C: Blast crisis in CML

  • Blast crisis in CML has the least five-year survival rate following allogeneic bone marrow transplantation.
  • The median survival time is <1.5 years.

Option A: Severe Combined Immunodeficiency syndrome

  • Severe Combined Immunodeficiency syndrome has a 90% five-year survival rate following allogeneic bone marrow transplantation.
  • Therefore, this option is incorrect.

Option B: Aplastic Anemia

  • Aplastic anaemia has a 90% five-year survival rate following allogeneic bone marrow transplantation.
  • Therefore, this option is incorrect.

Option D: Chronic lymphocytic leukaemia

  • Chronic lymphocytic leukaemia has a 50% five-year survival rate following allogeneic bone marrow transplantation.
  • Therefore, this option is incorrect.

questions.text: A 67-year-old male complained of generalized fatigue associated with difficulty breathing. On examination, pallor & gingival hypertrophy is noted. Initial investigations revealed hyperleukocytosis. Follow-up investigations showed leukostasis. This feature is most predominantly seen in which of the following disorders?
questions.solution:
Option B: Acute myeloid leukaemia (AML)

  • Leukostasis (also called symptomatic hyperleukocytosis) is a medical emergency most commonly seen in patients with acute myeloid leukaemia. 
  • It is characterized by an extremely elevated blast cell count and symptoms of decreased tissue perfusion.
  • The most common symptoms are dyspnea and hypoxia, usually accompanied by visual changes, headache, dizziness, confusion, somnolence and coma.
  • Hyperleukocytosis and leukostasis syndrome are commonly associated with a complication of acute leukaemia (particularly myeloid leukaemia).
  • It can occur when the peripheral blast cell count is >100,000/mL.
  • The frequency of hyperleukocytosis is 13% in acute myeloid leukaemia (AML); however, leukostasis is rare in lymphoid leukaemia.

Option A: Acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (ALL)

  • Leukostasis is seen primarily in myeloid leukaemia and is very rare in lymphoblastic leukaemia.
  • Clinical features:
    • Lymphoblast is proliferating so much → other lineages are suppressed
    • Anemia
      • Fatigue, Tiredness, and Pallor
    • Depletion in neutrophils, eosinophils, basophils, and monocytes causes Recurrent infections
    • Thrombocytopenia

Option C: Chronic myelocytic leukaemia (CML)

  • Leukostasis is seen very rarely in Chronic myeloid leukaemia
  • CML has three phases (Chronic, Accelerated and Blast Crisis).
  • Clinical features:
    • Dragging sensation in the abdomen.
    • Massive Splenomegaly (something pulling the abdomen down).

Option D: Chronic lymphocytic leukaemia (CLL)

  • Leukostasis is seen primarily in myeloid leukaemia and is very rare in lymphocytic leukaemia.
  • The earliest finding is a Fatigue.
    • Shows Lymphadenopathy (LAP)
    • Shows Hepatosplenomegaly (HSM)
    • Shows Organ involvement

questions.text: A 78-year-old male presents to the emergency department due to the abrupt onset of difficulty in speaking for 1 hour. He has had a history of hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus for 30 years and coronary artery disease for 10 years, treated with pravastatin, lisinopril, metformin and aspirin. His blood pressure is 165/90mmHg, his pulse is 76 beats/min, and temperature is 37.0°C. On physical examination, the patient speaks in short, simple sentences with difficulty repeating word sequences. He can follow simple instructions. A non-contrast CT scan of the brain shows. Which of the following is least likely to be associated with the patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Option D: Abulia

  • Abulia, also known as apathy, psychic akinesia, and athymia, refers to a lack of will, drive, or initiative for action, speech and ,thought is not associated with MCA infarction.
  • Abulia is associated with aging and other brain lesions.
  • The patient presents with clinical symptoms of a stroke.
  • The CT scan shows the involvement of the areas of the cerebral cortex supplied by the middle cerebral artery (MCA).
  • This results in Broca's aphasia (as in this patient) due to an MCA infraction.
  • The MCA is the largest cerebral artery and the vessel most commonly affected by cerebrovascular accidents.
  • Other findings associated with MCA infarction in the dominant lobe include the following:
    • Acalculia is a loss of the ability to perform simple calculations, typically resulting from disease or injury of the brain's parietal lobe.
    • Agraphia is an impairment or loss of a previous ability to write.
    • Finger agnosia is the inability to name, move, or touch specific fingers identified by the examiner.
    • Global aphasia is the ability to speak or comprehend language and severe communication difficulties.
  • Other features associated with MCA infarction in the non-dominant lobe include:
    • Anosognosia is a neurological condition in which the patient is unaware of their neurological deficit or psychiatric condition.
    • Constructional apraxia refers to the inability of patients to copy drawings or three-dimensional constructions accurately.
    • Neglect

Option A: Anosognosia

  • Anosognosia is a feature of MCA infarction in the non-dominant lobe.

Option B: Apraxia

  • Constructional apraxia is associated with MCA infarction.

Option C: Dysarthria

  • Dysarthria is associate with MCA infarction.

questions.text: What is the false regarding difference in between Upper motor neuron lesion and Lower motor neuron lesion?
questions.solution:
Option D: Paralysis is Flaccid in UMNL

  • This statement is incorrect
  • Paralysis is spastic in UMNL

Other options

​​​​​​​Option A: Tone is increased in UMNL

  • Tone is increased in UMNL is true

Option B: Babinski sign positive in UMNL

  • Babinski sign positive in UMNL is true

Option C: Clonus present in UMNL

  • Clonus present in UMNL is true

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents to the clinic, reporting that she is late for her period by one day. She has been married for 4 years and has 2 children. She has no significant gynecological history. She has had regular periods. Her urine pregnancy test is negative. She is advised to wait for another few days and gets her period the next day. Which mechanism is responsible for menstrual bleeding in the absence of pregnancy?

choices.text: The involution of the corpus luteum causes estradiol and progesterone levels to fall dramatically.
Estradiol levels are not involved in the LH surge phenomenon
Estradiol inhibits the induction of the progesterone receptor in the endometrium

questions.solution:
Option A: The involution of corpus luteum causes estradiol and progesterone levels to fall dramatically

  • The woman in question has had a normal period. The normal cycle length can vary from 21-35 days.

  • A corpus luteum is a mass of cells formed in an ovary. It leads to the production of progesterone during early pregnancy. The role of the corpus luteum varies whether or not fertilization occurs.
  • Without progesterone, the uterus lining does not undergo the changes supporting pregnancy. Instead, the lining would shed.
  • LH is the stimulus for the corpus luteum to continue its function of progesterone production. Apoptosis can occur by changes in hormone levels in the ovarian cycle. When there is no fertilization of the ovum, the endometrial cells die because LH production stops after the 10th day of its formation in the absence of pregnancy.
  • As the corpus luteum involutes, the levels of estrogen and progesterone fall and lead to a withdrawal bleed due to the absence of progesterone supporting the estrogen-primed endometrium.
  • Once pregnancy ensues, the hCG made from the syncytiotrophoblast is the stimulator for continuous corpus luteum function till around the 12th week of gestation, after which the placenta takes over the function of pregnancy maintenance.

Option B: LH levels rise after ovulation

  • LH levels fall after ovulation due to rising Progesterone which gives feedback inhibition to the production of LH from the pituitary.
  • So, it's a false statement.

Option C: Estradiol levels are not involved in the LH surge phenomenon

  • The rising estrogen from the developing follicle continues to increase through the proliferative phase and causes the production of LH, which in turn is responsible for ovulation. So, it's not a true statement regarding the question asked above.

Option D: Estradiol inhibits the induction of the progesterone receptor in the endometrium

  • Estrogen is responsible for the production of progesterone receptors in the endometrium. Progesterone is produced from the corpus luteum, acts on the endometrium, and causes secretory changes. So, it's not a true statement.

questions.text: A 26-year-old patient known case of PCOS who is being treated for infertility and was prescribed clomiphene citrate 20 days ago for ovulation induction has now presented with sudden onset of abdominal pain and distension with ascites reported on abdominal ultrasound. What is the most probable cause of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Option D: Ovarian Hyperstimulation syndrome

  • A woman with a history of ovulation induction with/ without ovulation trigger, presenting with complaints of pain abdomen and abdominal distension, must always raise suspicion of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS).
  • Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome is a medical complication that is completely iatrogenic and unique to stimulatory infertility treatment.
  • Its symptoms result from ovarian enlargement and fragility, extravascular fluid accumulation, and intravascular volume depletion.
  • Vascular endothelial growth factor, whose expression in granulosa cells and serum is augmented by hCG, and a variety of other inflammatory cytokines have been implicated in the pathogenesis of this disease.
  • This tends to be more severe with multiple gestations.
