  • Clinical features are abdominal distension, abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting.
  • Management is by monitoring input and output as it is a self-limiting condition and also by:
  • Intravascular fluid intake to replenish the volume
  • Symptomatic treatment, like the tapping of the ascites and pleural effusion in cases of severity.

Option A: Uterine rupture

  • Uterine rupture is a complication of late pregnancy where a previous uterine scar (previous cesarean section scar) ruptures as the patient goes into labour. It is unlikely here as the patient is only at around day 25 of her cycle.

Option B: Ruptured ectopic pregnancy

  • Abdominal pain and distension could be a presentation of ruptured ectopic pregnancy but occur only as early as 4-6 weeks of conception. Also a history of ovulation induction points more towards OHSS. However, ruptured ectopic or ovarian cyst remains to be the most important differential here.

Option C: Multifetal pregnancy causing uterine distension

  • A multifetal pregnancy does not cause pain or abdominal distension in early pregnancy.

questions.text: Which hormone is responsible for the mid-cycle rise in body temperature in females?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option D: Progesterone

  • Progesterone is responsible for the slight rise in body temperature experienced by a woman after ovulation. After ovulation, the ruptured follicle transforms into the corpus luteum, which produces progesterone. Progesterone causes a thermogenic effect, leading to a modest increase in basal body temperature. This temperature shift is used in fertility charting to help identify the timing of ovulation.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: FSH

  • FSH is responsible for the stimulation and growth of the ovarian follicle, and negative feedback from estrogen reduces FSH.
  • It has no action on body temperature.

Option B: LH

  • LH is responsible for the final maturation of the follicle and ovulation.
  • LH surge and peak are followed by ovulation.
  • It is not responsible for the change in body temperature.

Option C: Estradiol

  • Estradiol is responsible for making endometrium proliferative and making cervical mucous thin and slippery.
  • The change in body temperature is related to the progesterone hormone, not estradiol.

questions.text: A 37-year-old G2P2 woman presents to the gynecologist with pain in her lower abdomen and dysmenorrhea. On a pelvic scan, a complex ovarian cyst is 4 x 5 cm in size with a ground glass appearance. She is a chronic smoker, using combined contraceptive pills, and menstrual cycles coming at intervals of 20 days since menarche. A cystectomy is done, and histology reveals endometrial glands and hemorrhage. Which of the following in the patient's history is a risk factor for her condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option D: Shorter menstrual cycle length

  • History of congestive dysmenorrhea, ovarian cyst, and histopathological examination of endometrial glands is suggestive of endometriosis.
  • A shorter menstrual cycle length implies more menstrual cycles, which means more menstruation and, therefore, more severe endometriosis.
  • Protective factors against the development of endometriosis include:
    • Multiparity
    • Late menarche
    • OCPs
    • Smoking
    • Lactation
  • Risk factors for endometriosis:
    • Infertility
    • Early age at menarche
    • Shorter menstrual cycle length
    • Nulliparity
    • High estrogen exposure
    • Mullerian anomalies
    • Low BMI
    • Family history

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Multiparity

  • Multiparity is protective for endometriosis as pregnancy and lactation imply the absence of periods for the associated period of amenorrhea.

Option B: OCPs use

  • OCPs are not risk factors for endometriosis as they reduce the net amount of estrogen in the body. Since endometriosis is a hyperestrogenic condition, it is not increased with the use of OCPs.

Option C: Smoking

  • Smoking inhibits the aromatase enzyme ( responsible for converting androgens to estrogen in the periphery), thus reducing estrogen and not increasing the risk of endometriosis.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman presents to Gynecology OPD with complaints of abdominal distention and pain over the previous 3 months. Her physical examination reveals an abdominal mass without shifting dullness and bilateral adnexal masses. Her digital rectal examination reveals the presence of induration in the rectal pouch. Her breast examination and recent mammogram are normal. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Option A: Serous cystadenocarcinomas of both ovaries

  • The patient is a 68-year-old woman with abdominal distention, pain with bilateral adnexal masses, and induration in the rectal pouch. Bilateral adnexal masses in postmenopausal must raise suspicion of epithelial ovarian cancers. Most common of which are serous cystadenomas/ carcinomas. Induration in the rectal pouch suggests locally advanced disease and favors a malignancy.
  • The picture below shows the Serous cystadenocarcinoma.

  • Serous cystadenocarcinomas are the most common malignant tumors of ovaries and the most common tumors associated with a bilateral origin.
  • The peak incidence of invasive epithelial ovarian cancer is about 60. About 30% of ovarian neoplasms in postmenopausal women are malignant.
  • Mostly unilocular
  • Bilateral in >50%
  • Mostly malignant
  • Surface growth present
  • Psammoma Bodies are present in 40-45%

​​​​​​​

Option B: Krukenberg’s tumors of the ovaries

  • Krukenberg’s tumors are also bilateral but are associated with another primary malignancy (most commonly gastric carcinoma) and are less common than epithelial tumors.
  • Hence, it is not the correct option.

Option C: Malignant ascites

  • It is ruled out as there is no shifting dullness. Please note that serous cystadenocarcinomas do present with ascites quite commonly.
  • So, it is a false statement.

Option D: Meig's syndrome

  • Meig's syndrome is ascites and pleural effusion associated with fibroma of the ovary, which is again ruled out due to the absence of ascites.
  • So, it is not a true option.

questions.text: Which blood test would be most helpful in establishing a diagnosis for a 20-year-old girl presenting with rapidly developing hirsutism, amenorrhea, voice changes, abdominal pain, and a single ovarian mass detected on ultrasound?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option C: Testosterone

  • Rapidly progressing hirsutism points to developing androgen-secreting tumors. Also, there is an ovarian mass, which points towards an androgen-secreting tumor, most likely a Leydig Sertoli tumor of the ovary.
  • For which estimation of androgens, specifically serum testosterone, should be an initial investigation.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: 17-OH progesterone

  • 17-OH progesterone is typically measured to evaluate congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH). While CAH can present with symptoms like hirsutism, it's not the first-line test in this scenario, and other hormones, such as testosterone, may be more directly related to the symptoms described.

Option B: Cortisol

  • Cortisol levels are crucial for assessing adrenal function. While adrenal disorders can contribute to hirsutism, the symptoms described are more indicative of PCOS (excessive androgen), and serum testosterone is a more specific marker in this context.

Option D: LH: FSH estimation

  • The LH: FSH ratio is often used to assess reproductive disorders. In the context of the symptoms described, an elevated LH: FSH ratio may suggest polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). While relevant, testosterone would be a more direct marker for androgen excess in this case.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents to the gynaecologist for counselling regarding cervical cancer screening. She has no family history of any gynaecological cancer. She is married and is not planning to conceive. The patient is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examinations are unremarkable. Which of the following is the most appropriate advice for this patient?

choices.text: She must have cervical cytology now and follow after 3 years
She must have cervical cytology with HPV testing now and follow up after 3 years
She must wait for 2 years, after which cervical cytology must be done
She does not need cervical cancer screening.

questions.solution:
Option A: She must have cervical cytology now and follow after 3 years

  • Screening for cervical cancer at 25 years of age is recommended as 3 yearly paps/ cervical cytology (without HPV), irrespective of any high-risk factor.
  • The most effective preventive strategy for cervical cancer is screening for precancerous lesions and early treatment, which is possible due to the natural progression of the disease from pre-invasive lesions to invasive lesions over several years.

Risk factors for cervical cancer

  • Young age at first intercourse (<16 years)
  • Multiple sexual partners (increases risk of HPV transmission)
  • Smoking
  • High parity
  • Low socio-economic status
  • Immunosuppression, HIV
  • Association with OCP use is debatable.

 

The initiating event in cervical dysplasia and carcinogenesis is infection with HPV. Cervical dysplasia follows a course from CIN1 to invasive carcinoma over time, providing a window for screening and treatment.

Screening is recommended as

  • <21 years: no screening
  • 21-29 years: cervical cytology (paps smear) 3 yearly
  • 30-65 years: 3 yearly cervical cytology or 5 yearly co-testing (cytology+HPV)
  • 65 years: stop screening if all prior tests were negative
  • Women with DES exposure, immunocompromised should continue to be screened
  • Women with HIV should be screened with cytology twice in their first year after diagnosis and yearly after that.

Option B: She must have cervical cytology with HPV testing now and follow up after 3 years

  • The patient at 25 years of age is only recommended for cytology and follow-up after 3 years.
  • Co-testing of cytology and HPV is recommended between the age of 30 to 65.

Option C: She must wait for 2 years, after which cervical cytology must be done

  • The patient at 25 years of age must undergo cervical cancer screening with cytology

Option D: She does not need cervical cancer screening

  • Every woman after age of 21 years needs cervical cancer screening

questions.text: An obese 49-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes and hypertension complained of heavy menstrual bleeding and delayed and irregular cycles for the last 6 months. She is advised by TVS. Which of these is the most important cause that should be ruled out in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Carcinoma of the endometrium

  • The risk factors for endometrial carcinoma are well established.
  • Factors that increase the risk of endometrial carcinoma are;
  1. Obesity
  2. Diabetes
  3. Nulliparity
  4. Late menopause > 52 years and early menarche
  5. Unopposed estrogen therapy
  6. Tamoxifen therapy
  7. Family history of endometrial and colorectal carcinoma.
  • Abnormal bleeding is the most common presenting complaint, which can be heavy, irregular, or intermenstrual bleeding.
  • Since the patient is 49 years old and has other comorbidities such as obesity, hypertension, and diabetes, endometrial carcinoma should be ruled out.

Option A: Cancer cervix

  • Cervical cancer is caused by persistent high-risk HPV infection. Women who are immunocompromised, for example, those with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) and transplant recipients on long-term immunosuppressive therapy, are particularly at risk of premalignant and malignant disease of the cervix.
  • Cervical cancer remains to be the most common cause of postmenopausal bleeding in our country. But it typically presents with other symptoms such as postcoital bleeding, vaginal discharge, and pelvic pain
  • However, given a history of obesity and diabetes, cervical cancer is less common compared to endometrial cancer.

Option C: Fibroid uterus

  • A fibroid is a benign estrogen-dependent uterine smooth muscle tumor known as leiomyoma.
  • Fibroids could very well be the cause of her symptoms, however, the question asks the most important cause that needs to be ruled out, that is endometrial cancer, for which an endometrial biopsy becomes mandatory. Also, risk factors of obesity and diabetes make endometrial cancer more likely.

Option D: Polycystic ovaries

  • Polycystic ovary syndrome is a syndrome of ovarian dysfunction and cardinal features of hyperandrogenism and polycystic ovary morphology.
  • Clinical manifestations include menstrual irregularities, signs of androgen excess (hirsutism and acne), obesity, elevated serum LH levels, biochemical evidence of hyperandrogenism, and insulin resistance.
  • It mostly affects 5% to 10% of women of reproductive age and is less common in women proceeding with menopause. Since the patient is 49 years of age, this diagnosis is less likely.

questions.text: Review the following hysterosalpingogram and provide the appropriate diagnosis.
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option B: Unicornuate uterus

  • A unicornuate uterus is a rare disorder that causes a female to have only half a uterus accounting for only 10% of all Mullerian anomalies.
  • Unicornuate uterus (Class II).
    • It appears banana-shaped without the rounded fundus and triangular-shaped uterine cavity. If present, the rudimentary horn presents as a soft tissue mass with similar myometrial echogenicity. Obstruction in the rudimentary horn is presented as hematometra on one side.
    • A unicornuate uterus with a non-communicating rudimentary horn is linked with several complications like infertility, endometriosis, hematometra, urinary tract anomalies, abortions, and preterm deliveries. Treatment involves surgical removal of the unicornuate uterus.

Congenital Müllerian anomalies (American Fertility Society Classification System)

  • Class I (agenesis, hypoplasia). Uterus is absent in total agenesis. Partial agenesis is identified as unicornuate uterus. In hypoplasia, the endometrial cavity is small with reduced intercornual distance of less than 2 cm.
  • Class II (unicornuate uterus) appears banana-shaped without the rounded fundus and triangular-shaped uterine cavity. If present, rudimentary horn presents as a soft tissue mass with similar myometrial echogenicity. Obstruction in the rudimentary horn is recognized as haematometra on one side.
  • Class III (uterus didelphys). The two horns are widely separated, with no vaginal septum.
  • Class IV (bicornuate uterus) shows two uterine cavities, with concave fundus, with fundal cleft greater than 1 cm, and this differentiates between the bicornuate and the septate uterus. The intercornual distance is more than 4 cm.
  • Class V (septate uterus) shows a convex or flattened fundus. The intercornual distance is normal (<4 cm) and each cavity is small.
  • Class VI (arcuate uterus) with no fundal indentation is of no clinical importance.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Normal uterus

  • The HSG shown above reveals a unicornuate uterus, not a normal one.
  • A normal uterus shows a triangular cavity with tubes on both sides.

Option C: Bicornuate uterus

  • The HSG shown above reveals a unicornuate uterus, as a bicornuate uterus appears heart-shaped, having two sides instead of a single hollow cavity.

Option D: Arcuate Uterus

  • As shown above, it is a unicornuate uterus because an arcuate uterus appears as an upside-down pear with the top of the uterus indented

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents to gynecology OPD in an anxious state, reporting early pregnancy loss 1 day back. She reports spontaneous abortion in the 5th week of her pregnancy. She has been married for 5 months. Her HSG reveals two separate cavities of the uterus, cervix and vagina. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option A: Uterus didelphys

  • Uterus didelphys is a complete failure of fusion of Mullerian duct resulting in two uteri, cervix, and vagina.
  • It can lead to pregnancy complications and dysmenorrhea. Few patients may have surgery to treat uterus didelphys, but most cases don't require it.

 

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Bicornuate uterus

  • It is described as a heart-shaped uterus, having two sides instead of one hollow cavity.
  • The cervix and vagina are single

Option C: Subseptate uterus

  • It is a mild form of congenital anomaly in which a half septum is present within the uterus, not infringing on the cervix.

Option D: Unicornuate Uterus

  • A unicornuate uterus is a rare disorder that causes a female to have only half a uterus.

questions.text: A radiologist performing an obstetric ultrasound visualizes the placenta and calls it Grade III. Placental grading on ultrasound is based on following criteria:-
questions.solution:
Option D : Placental grading (Grannum classification)refers to an ultrasound grading system of the placenta based on its maturity. It primarily affects the extent of calcifications.

Factors evaluated include placental calcium deposits and chorionic plate undulations.

GRADE FEATURES
Grade 0

<18 weeks

uniform echogenicity

smooth chorionic plate
Grade I

18-29 weeks

Scattered echogenicities and subtle chorionic plate undulations
Grade II

30-38 weeks

Echogenic stippling at the basal plate
Grade III

≥ 39 weeks

Echogenic indentations extending from the chorionic plate to the basal plate which resemble cotyledons.

 

Option A : Placental location is described as fundal, low lying or previa.

Option B : Placental dimension is not routinely measured, may measured in some cases of placentomegaly (width > 4cm).

Option C : Amniotic fluid is measured as amniotic fluid index.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, G2P2, presents to the emergency department with intense, sudden onset pelvic pain and profuse bleeding after giving birth at home. Examination reveals a tender, mass protruding from the vagina. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B

Uterine inversion 

  • Uterine inversion occurs when the uterus turns inside out. This typically presents as intense pelvic pain, profuse bleeding, and a palpable mass. Fundus of the uterus will be absent on abdominal palpation. 

Causes:

  • Mismanaged 3rd stage of labor (m/c cause)
  • Fundal implantation of placenta
  • Sudden cord traction

Management:

  • Rapid infusion of fluids
  • Reposition as soon as possible
    • Manual Reposition: 
      • Johnson maneuver: Manually applying pressure to the top of the uterus through the vaginal wall towards the umbilicus.
    • Hydrostatic Reposition
    • Surgical Methods
      • Huntington's Method →Atraumatic clamps
      • Haultian Method →Resection of the constricting Bands

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Uterine rupture 

  • Uterine rupture involves a tear in the uterine wall, typically during labor. This can result in severe abdominal pain, changes in fetal heart rate, and signs of shock.

Option C: Placental abruption

  • Placental abruption involves the separation of the placenta from the uterine wall before delivery. This can lead to severe abdominal pain and bleeding.

Option D:

  • Cervical lacerations involve tears in the cervix, and they can cause bleeding.

questions.text: An Rh-negative woman at 23 weeks pregnancy presents with a history of abdominal trauma associated with vaginal bleeding. Ultrasound shows only a minor retroplacental bleed. The fetal heart and movements are good. The treating doctor, however, plans to give her an Anti-D injection and wishes to calculate the dose required, for which there is a need to know the amount of fetal RBCs that have crossed into the maternal circulation, if any. The detection ability of this test is based on which of the following concepts?

choices.text: Adult erythrocytes are larger than those of the fetus
HbA has a higher oxygen affinity than HbF
HbF is more resistant to acid than HbA
HbA takes up erythrosin stain less than HbF

questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option C: HbF is more resistant to acid than HbA

  • The most commonly used quantitative test for fetal red cells in the maternal circulation is the acid elution or Kleihauer Betke test.
  • Fetal erythrocytes contain HbF, which is more resistant to acid elution than HbA.

KLEIHAUER BETKE TEST or ACID ELUTION TEST

  • Measures the amount of fetomaternal hemorrhage usually in an Rh-negative mother to calculate the dose of anti-D required
  • This method is based on the fact that an acid solution (citric acid phosphate buffer, pH 3.5) elutes the adult but not the fetal hemoglobin from the red cells;
  • Can detect as little as 0.2 ml of fetal blood diluted in 5 L maternal blood.
  • More accurate tests are immunofluorescence and flow cytometry.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Adult erythrocytes are larger than those of the fetus

  • This is not the basis for the detection by this test.

Option B: HbA has a higher oxygen affinity than HbF

  • The affinity of HbF is higher for oxygen than HbA.
  • Moreover, this statement is not correct itself and also it is unrelated with the acid elution test.

Option D: HbA takes up erythrosin stain less than HbF

  • HbF stains densely with erythrosin B.
  • However, it has no link with the acid elution test.

questions.text: A pregnant woman with Rh negative blood group had a history of fall at home. Although there was no pain or bleeding per vaginum following it, she is anxious about the effects on her baby. Which of the following findings is NOT suggestive of fetal affection in this patient?

choices.text: Decrease in middle cerebral artery peak systolic velocity
Doppler flow velocity waveforms in the umbilical artery

questions.solution:
Explanation:
Option B: Decrease in middle cerebral artery peak systolic velocity

  • Fetal affection in Rh incompatibility implies fetal RBC destruction and subsequent anaemia.

Fetal anaemia, its severity and progression can be diagnosed by:

  • Increasing ICT tires
  • Increase in middle cerebral artery peak systolic velocity- predicts moderate to severe fetal anaemia
  • Doppler flow velocity waveforms in an umbilical artery- used to detect fetal anaemia & acidosis
  • Lilley's graph & Queenan's chart- to determine the extent of hemolysis by doing spectrometry of amniotic fluid & plotting on these charts
  • Hydrops fetalis on USG

Option A: Increasing OD 450 on Lilley's graph

  • Lilley's graph determines the degree of hemolysis in the fetus.
  • Higher the OD 450, higher the degree of hemolysis

Option C: Hydrops fetalis on USG

  • This is one of the features of fetal anaemia.
  • So, hydrops fetalis on USG indicates severe anaemia in the fetus.

Option D: Doppler flow velocity waveforms in the umbilical artery

  • Doppler waveform in the umblical artery indicates fetal anaemia.

questions.text: A 26-year-old pregnant woman at 13 weeks gestation has abdomen larger than expected at 13 weeks on physical examination. An ultrasound reveals multiple gestations. Which of the following is the type of twin pregnancy shown in the ultrasound image?
questions.solution:
Option C : In the above given image, there is single amnion and chorion, with no intervening membrane, thus, it is a Monoamniotic monochorionic twin.

Option A : Diamniotic Dichorionic twins, the image shows two amnion and chorion with lambda sign (twin peak sign)

Option B : Monochorionic diamniotic shows one chorion and two amniotic sacs.

Option D : Dichorionic monoamniotic is a misnomer.

questions.text: In a 33 year old woman who conceived with IVF, an USG at 12 weeks shows a single developing fetus. The previous USG at 6 weeks showed a twin pregnancy. The patient has unremarkable medical history, takes only vitamins. Vital signs and physical examination are normal. What should be the next appropriate step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Advice medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) as the second twin is at increased risk of aborting
Continue pregnancy like a normal singleton pregnancy
Watch for coagulation defects in the mother

questions.solution:
Correct Option B:

  • The patient presented with clinical features of vanishing twin syndrome.
  • The ultrasound at 12 weeks reveals a single developing live fetus. In cases of the vanishing twin phenomenon, where one twin is no longer detectable, and the remaining singleton is viable, continuing the pregnancy is often appropriate.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Advice medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) as the second twin is at increased risk of aborting

  • The chances of the demise of the second twin when the first one dies at such early gestation, are minimal.
  •  Medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) must not be advised.

Option C: Watch for coagulation defects in the mother

  • Coagulation defects are seen after fetal demise at later gestation when thromboplastin is released from the dead fetal tissue if left for a prolonged duration in utero.

Option D: Chorionic villous sampling

  • Chorionic villous sampling is not indicated here.
  • It will only increase the chances of abortion of the second fetus.

questions.text: 32-year-old pregnant woman at 11 weeks of gestational age has high blood pressure reading of 150/100 mm Hg, repeat BP is 160/90 mm Hg, and urinalysis is negative for protein. What's the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B: Chronic hypertension

  • This patient with a history of hypertension at the 11th week of gestation, no headache or visual changes, and negative urinalysis most likely has chronic hypertension.
  • Chronic hypertension is defined as BP >140/90 mmHg before pregnancy or diagnosed before 20 weeks of gestation, or hypertension first diagnosed after 20 weeks of gestation and persistent after 12 weeks postpartum.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Pre-eclampsia

  • Preeclampsia occurs when blood pressure increases to 140/90 mm Hg after 20 weeks of gestation, proteinuria (0.3g/L in 24 h or ≥1+ protein on urine dipstick), and signs of end-organ damage.
  • This patient has no visual changes, nausea, or headache. Her urinalysis is also negative for protein.

Option C: Eclampsia

  • It is present when seizures develop in a patient suffering from pre-eclampsia. This patient does not have seizures or pre-eclampsia.

Option D: Gestational hypertension

  • Gestational hypertension occurs when maternal blood pressure reaches 140/90 mm Hg or greater for the first time during pregnancy, after 20 weeks, and resolves within 12 weeks of delivery, proteinuria is not present.
  • The given patient has developed hypertension before 20 weeks of gestation..

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida presents to the antenatal clinic at 27 weeks of gestation with a complaint of headache. Her blood pressure is 170/100mmHg. Urinary dipstick test shows urine albumin 2+. Which of the following does not correlate with the severity of the patient’s disease?
questions.solution:
Option D: Thrombocytosis

  • This patient presenting with headache, high BP and proteinuria most likely suffer from preeclampsia.
  • Thrombocytopenia indicates increased severity of this disease, not thrombocytosis.
  • Thrombocytopenia is seen in HELLP syndrome, a known complication of preeclampsia.

Option A: Increased BP

  • High blood pressure is a marker of the severity of preeclampsia. It leads to the progression of the disease to eclampsia.

Option B: Visual disturbances

  • These occur due to high BP. This is an important clinical manifestation of the severity of the disease.

Option C: Oliguria

  • It is a clinical marker of renal dysfunction in preeclampsia. It is an important indicator of the severity of the disease.

questions.text: A female, gravida 2 para 1 living 1, presents at full term with labour pains for 4 hours. On examination, uterine contractions are present, and the cervix is 4 cm dilated and well effaced. The fetal head is at a -2 station with a sagittal suture in the midline so that occiput is placed posteriorly in the pelvis. Which of the following is the most common association with such presentation of the fetal head?
questions.solution:
Option B: Android pelvis

  • In this case, the fetus's position is occiput-posterior (OP).
    • Vertex presentation with the fetal back (occiput) is directed posteriorly.
    • Incidence is 10% at the onset of labour
    • Anthropoid and android pelvis is most commonly associated with it.
  • Causes of OP position  of fetal head are:
    • Anterior placenta
    • Anthropoid and android pelvis; the most common cause of OP position of the fetal head
    • Gross pendulous abdomen
    • Maternal kyphosis: The foetal back's convexity fits with the lumbar kyphosis's concavity.
    • Multiple pregnancies
    • Pelvic tumours
    • Placenta praevia
    • Polyhydramnios
  • Left occipito-posterior (LOP) is less frequent than right occipito-posterior (ROP).
  • An oval inlet characterises the anthropoid pelvis (although the anteroposterior diameter is greater than the transverse), diverging pelvic side walls, and a posteriorly inclined sacrum. Due to the foetal head's inability to rotate anteriorly to an occiput-anterior position and the delivery method of face to pubis, it is consequently associated with persistent occiput posterior presentation.
  • The android pelvis (male-like) has a wedge-shaped inlet, converging pelvic sidewalls, prominent ischial spines, a small subpubic arch, and an anteriorly tilted sacrum in the lower third. Deep, transverse arrest dystocia is likely linked to it.

 

Option A: Deflexed head

  • The deflexed head indicates that the head is not being applied to the cervix properly.
  • If the baby's head is not properly positioned against the cervix, the cervical dilatation and descent are slowed, the contractions are less effective, and the labour is prolonged.
  • Additionally, internal anterior rotation is more difficult to occur because of these circumstances.
  • In this case, uterine contractions are present, the cervix is dilated 4 cm and well effaced, and the fetal head is at -2 station, so a deflexed head is highly unlikely.

 

Option C: Gynecoid pelvis

  • It is the most prevalent kind of female pelvis and is typically thought to be the typical female pelvis.
  • It has a round, shallow, and open overall shape.
  • The gynoid pelvic inlet's transverse diameter appears slightly larger than the anterior-posterior diameter, giving it an oval appearance.
  • The gynaecoid pelvis is considered the best pelvis type for a vaginal birth. It is due to the baby having lots of room during birth due to the wide, open shape.
  • Therefore, the OP position is least likely to occur in a gynaecoid pelvis.

 

Option D: Multiparity

  • Multiparity is not a risk factor for the OP position.

questions.text: A second gravida presents at 34 weeks for a routine check up. On examination, the doctor finds a ballotable hard fetal part in the fundus of the uterus and a smaller softer part in the pelvic grip. The most common risk factor for such presentation is:
questions.solution:
Option A : Presence of a ballotable hard fetal part in the fundus of the uterus and a smaller softer part in the pelvic grip is suggestive of breech presentation.

Risk factors for Breech presentation -

  • Prematurity (Most common Risk factor)
  • Increased amniotic fluid volume
  • Multifetal gestation
  • Hydrocephaly
  • Anencephaly
  • Uterine anomalies
  • Placenta previa
  • Fundal placental implantation
  • Pelvic tumors
  • High parity with uterine relaxation
  • Prior breech delivery

Option B : Post maturity is not a risk factor for breech presentation.

Option C : Diabetes is not a risk factor for breech per se, but if associated with polyhydramnios, may be related to breech.

Option D : Osteomalacia is not associated with breech presentation

questions.text: A case-control study is a type of observational study in which two existing groups differing in outcome are identified and compared on the basis of some supposed causal attribute. Case-control study method has the following three distinct features, Which of the following is the inappropriate one?

choices.text: Both exposure and outcome occurred before the start of the study
The unit of study is a group rather than individual
The study proceeds backward from effect to cause
It uses a control or comparison group to support or refute an interference

questions.solution:
ANSWER Option B: The unit of study is a group rather than individual-Incorrect Statement

  • In case-control studies, the unit is individual rather than a group.
  • A case-control study is a type of observational study in which two existing groups differing in outcome are identified and compared on the basis of some supposed causal attribute.

Option A: Both exposure and outcome occurred before the start of the study

  • In case-control studies, both the exposure and outcome occurred before the start of the study.

Option C: The study proceeds backward from effect to cause

  • The case-control study proceeds backward from effect to cause.
  • The case-control study is often called a retrospective study.

Option D: It uses a control or comparison group to support or refute an interference

  • The case-control study uses a control or comparison group to support or refute an interference.

questions.text: A 9-month-old baby was brought to the rural PHC for her Vitamin A dose according to the national immunization schedule. Vitamin A prophylaxis belongs to which category?
questions.solution:
Option A: Specific protection

  • Vitamin A Prophylaxis is given before the disease has occurred in children at risk. So, it is primary prevention.
  • Since it is specific to the prevention of Vitamin A deficiency blindness, it is specific protection.
  • All vaccines and prophylaxis come under primary prevention i.e., specific protection of the disease.

Option B: Health promotion

  • Health promotion is a general example of primary prevention which aims at the prevention of disease by improving lifestyle and reducing risk factors.

Option C: Secondary prevention

  • Secondary prevention aims at disease reduction through early diagnosis and treatment.

Option D: Primordial prevention

  • Primordial prevention is the prevention at grass root level which aims to prevent exposure to risk factors by improving lifestyle at very initial periods.

questions.text: The eight-month-old child had a history of unusual crying and convulsions following previous vaccination after BCG, DPT & OPV (first dose), and Hepatitis B. Now parents have brought the child for the next doses of vaccination. Which vaccine is contraindicated in this situation?
questions.solution:
Option B: DPT

  • Unusual crying following DPT is most likely to be Persistent Inconsolable Screaming.
  • Similarly, convulsions are most likely to be due to DPT.
  • Hence, DPT should not be given subsequently.
  • It can be replaced by DT.

Option A: Measles

  • The adverse effects of the measles vaccine include febrile seizure, Toxic shock syndrome.
  • It is a Live attenuated vaccine that is administered via a subcutaneous route.
  • The vaccination Schedule consists of 2 doses, 1st dose at 9 months and 2nd dose at 16-24 months.
  • Site: Right arm, subcutaneous route
  • Vaccine: Edmonston Zagreb strain.

Option C: Hepatitis B

  • The adverse effect of the Hep B vaccine includes shock and hypersensitivity.
  • Dosage: 0.5ml administered intramuscularly. 

Option D: Killed influenza vaccine 

  • The adverse effect of this vaccine is Gullian-Barrie Syndrome.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male presented to the physician complaining of polyuria, polydipsia, polyphagia, and weight loss. The physician suspected diabetes and a screening test was done. What will happen if the cut-off point for blood glucose is lowered to detect Diabetes (say less than 120 mg percent)?

choices.text: Sensitivity of the test is increased
Specificity of the test is increased
Predictive accuracy of the test is decreased

questions.solution:
Option A: Sensitivity of the test is increased

  • The sensitivity of the test (true positive) is increased as we lower the cut-off.
  • The number of false positives will also increase.
  • This increase in sensitivity occurs at expense of specificity. i.e., Specificity will decrease (As sensitivity and specificity are inversely related to each other so if Sensitivity Increases → Specificity Decreases and Vice Versa).

Option B: Specificity of the test is increased

  • If we lower the cut-off value of the test, the false positives will be increased.
  • Therefore, the specificity of the test will decrease.

Option C: Predictive accuracy of the test is decreased

  • The predictive value of the test is not affected by sensitivity and specificity.
  • The predictive value is dependent on the prevalence of the disease.
  • If the prevalence of the disease is high, then the positive predictive value will be increased and vice versa.

Option D: None of the above

  • If we lower the cut-off value then sensitivity will increase, therefore this is an incorrect choice.

questions.text: A community medicine student was asked to calculate the gross reproduction rate (GRR). What is the gross reproduction rate (GRR) if the total fertility rate (TFR) in a population is given as 4?
questions.solution:
Option A: 2

Gross Reproduction Rate (GRR)

  • Gross Reproduction Rate is defined as the average number of girls that would be born to a woman if she experiences the current fertility pattern throughout her reproductive span, assuming no mortality.

Total Fertility Rate (TFR)

  • The total Fertility rate is defined as the average number of children a woman would have if she were to pass through her reproductive years bearing children at the same rates as the women now in each age group.
  • Gross Reproduction Rate (GRR) = 1/2 x Total Fertility Rate
  • In the given question, the Total Fertility rate is 4; hence GRR is half of 4 = 2

questions.text: A married couple visited the OPD to gain knowledge regarding contraceptive methods and family planning. Which of the following determines the failure rate of the contraceptive methods?
questions.solution:
Option B: Pearl’s Index

  • Measures the failure rate/ efficiency of contraception.
  • PI = Total number of accidental gestations/ Total months of exposure x 1200
  • It is expressed per Hundred Women Years (HWY).

Other options

Option A: Couple protection rate (CPR)

  • CPR = Total protected couple/ total eligible couple x 100

Option C: Total fertility rate

  • It is the total number of children born to a woman in an entire life span.

Option D: Net reproductive rate

  • It is the total number of girl children born to a woman in an entire reproductive life span,

questions.text: A community medicine intern during his viva was asked about the criteria of At Risk infants. All of the following are the criteria for identifying ‘At Risk’ infants, except?
questions.solution:
Option A: Birth weight less than 2.8 kg

  • The number of infants (and children 1- 5 years of age) in a community, or attending a child health clinic, maybe so large that it may not be possible to give sufficient time and attention to all of them.
  • It is, therefore, necessary to identify those "at-risk" and give them special intensive care, because these " at-risk" babies contribute so mainly to perinatal, neonatal, and infant mortality.
    Birth weight less than 2.5 kg is a criterion for At-risk infants.

Option B: Birth order 5 or more

  • Birth order 5 or more is a criterion for At-risk infants.

Option C: Protein-energy malnutrition

  • Malnutrition is a broad term that encompasses undernutrition (protein energy malnutrition), overnutrition (obesity), and specific nutrient deficiencies.
  • Protein-energy malnutrition shows an iceberg phenomenon.
  • Only the severe form of protein energy malnutrition (kwashiorkor and marasmus) comes to medical attention.
  • Significantly more, mild to moderate cases of protein energy malnutrition remains undiagnosed (below the iceberg).

Option D: Working mother

  • Children of working moms are prone to develop disruptive behavioral issues.
  • Before their first birthday, children of moms who worked part-time experienced fewer disruptive behavioral issues than children of mothers who worked full-time. At age three and during first grade, there was a noticeable increase in the likelihood of behavioral issues.

questions.text: Vitamin A is a fat-soluble vitamin important for the growth, vision, and maintenance of the immune system. Which of the following is the First clinical sign of Vitamin-A deficiency?
questions.solution:
Option B: Conjunctival xerosis

  • ‘First clinical sign’ of Vitamin A deficiency: conjunctival xerosis.
  • The conjunctiva becomes dry and non-wettable. Instead of looking smooth and shiny, it appears muddy and wrinkled.
  • It has been well described as "emerging like sand banks at receding tide" when the child ceases to cry.

Other options

Option A: Night blindness

  • ‘First clinical symptom’ of Vitamin A deficiency: Night blindness.

Option C: Bitot’s spots

  • ‘Bitot’s Spots’ are triangular, pearly-white or yellowish, foamy spots on the bulbar conjunctiva, on either side of the cornea.

Option D: Keratomalacia

  • Keratomalacia or liquefaction of the cornea is a grave medical emergency, The cornea (a part or the whole) may become soft and may burst open.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male living in the hostel is adopting the values of others and making them a part of his own. Which of the following correctly defines this situation?
questions.solution:
Option B: Internalization

  • Internalization is defined as the adoption of the values of others and making them a part of yours.

Option A: Acculturation

  • Acculturation is ‘cultural contact’ or the mixing of two cultures.
  • Occurs by:
    • Marriage
    • Education
    • Trade & commerce
    • Conquest

Option C: Culture

  • Culture is the learned behavior that is socially acquired and not present at birth.

Option D: Customs

  • Customs are the established patterns of behavior that can be objectively verified within a particular social setting.

questions.text: A 25 years old female recently delivered a healthy baby in your hospital. You were the assistant doctor with your senior for the delivery. After the successful delivery of the baby, your senior asks you what is the ‘first immunization’ of the baby?

choices.text: Handing over the baby to mother

questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Colostrum

  • It is the most suitable food immediately after the birth of the baby; Regular milk comes 3-6 days after birth.
  • It is also known as ‘Beestings’, ‘First milk’, or ‘Immune Milk’.
  • Colostrum is high in carbohydrates, proteins, and antibodies, and low in fat.
  • It contains all five immunoglobulins found in all mammals, IgA (highest), IgD, IgE, IgG & IgM.
  • It is known as the ‘first immunization’ of newborns.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A: OPV

  • Oral Polio Vaccine / SABIN is a Bivalent vaccine (P1, P3 strain).
  • Dosage:
    • 1st dose is given immediately at birth or as soon as possible, then at 6 weeks followed by 10 and 14 weeks.
    • 1st booster: 16-24 months.
    • Another dose at 5 y along with DPT booster.

Option B: Handing over the baby to the mother

  • Handing over the baby to the mother is not the first immunization.

Option D: DPT + BCG

  • 1st dose of DPT is given 6 weeks after birth and 1st dose of BCG is given at the time of birth or as early as possible till one year of age.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presented to the OPD with complaints of fever, itchy blisters all over the body, loss of appetite, and headache. Which of the following is the period of infectivity for the given condition?

choices.text: 5 days prior to appearance of rash till 4 days afterwards
4 days prior to appearance of rash till 5 days afterwards
4 days prior to appearance of rash till 1 day afterwards
1 day prior to appearance of rash till 4 days afterwards

questions.solution:
Option D: 1 day prior to appearance of rash till 4 days afterward

  • The symptoms mentioned above point toward the diagnosis of Chickenpox. The period of communicability/infectivity of chicken pox is 1-2 days before the appearance of the rash till 4 days afterward.
  • Therefore, all other options (A, B, and C) are incorrect.

questions.text: A 23-year-old sexual worker female presented to the hospital with rapid weight loss, fever, night sweats, sore throat and swollen lymph nodes. Blood reports confirmed the patient to be HIV positive. Which of the following is the most common opportunistic infection in AIDS worldwide?
questions.solution:
Option D: Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia

  • The most common opportunistic infection in AIDS Worldwide is Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia (PCP).

Option A: Tuberculosis

  • The most common opportunistic infection in AIDS in India is Tuberculosis (up to 40% co-infection).

Option B: Candida

  • Opportunistic infection in AIDS in India is Tuberculosis > Candida >PCP.

Option C: Histoplasmosis

  • Histoplasmosis is a type of lung infection.
  • It is caused by inhaling Histoplasma capsulatum fungal spores. These spores are found in the soil and in the droppings of bats and birds.

questions.text: A screening test is performed as a preventative measure to detect a potential health problem or disease in someone that doesn't yet have signs or symptoms. Which of the following is the method of choice for tuberculosis detection in mass screening?

choices.text: Sputum smear examination by direct microscopy

questions.solution:
Option C: Sputum smear examination by direct microscopy

  • The method of choice for tuberculosis detection in mass screening is Sputum smear examination by direct microscopy.

Other options

Option A: Tuberculin test

  • The tuberculin test is the ‘only way of estimating the prevalence of infection in a population.
  • The tuberculin test has lost its sensitivity as an indicator of the true prevalence of infection, in countries with high coverage of BCG.
  • Tuberculin Test and Mantoux Test (Pirquet Test or PPD Test):
    • Tool for detecting TB infection
    • +ve reaction: Past or present infection by Mycobacterium TB
    • 1 Tuberculin Unit (TU) in 0.1 ml

Option B: Mass miniature radiography (MMR)

  • Mass Miniature Radiography is not used now as a case-finding tool.
  • Only useful:
    • As an additional criterion for diagnosis of Pulmonary TB, when no sputum smear is positive out of two.
    • To exclude bronchiectasis/aspergilloma in frequent/severe positive sputum smear cases.
    • In suspected complications in a breathless patient needing specific treatment (e.g., pneumothorax, pericardial effusion, pleural effusion).

Option D: Sputum culture

  • Sputum smear examination (Z-N Staining) by direct microscopy is the ‘method of choice as a case-finding tool for tuberculosis.
  • Sputum culture examination is offered as a centralized service at district and regional chest clinic laboratories.
    • Only meant for chest symptomatic who are smear-negative.
    • Useful for carrying out sensitivity tests and monitoring drug treatment.

questions.text: The Planning Commission is set up by the Government of India in 1950. The 3 major divisions of the planning commission are all of the following, except?
questions.solution:
Option A: Executive division

  • The executive division is not included in the divisions of the Planning Commission.
  • The three divisions of the Planning Commission are General Secretariat, Technical Divisions, and Program Advisors.

Option B: General secretariat

 

  • General Secretariat is one of the major divisions of the planning commission.
  • The General Secretariat is the organization that manages all of our administrative and policing activities.
  • It has four branches, namely- Plan Co-ordination Branch, Administrative Branch, Information and Publicity Branch, and General Co-ordination Branch.

Option C: Technical divisions

 

  • Technical division is also a major divisions of the planning commission.
  • The technical divisions are in charge of reviewing and analysing the various schemes and projects that will be included in the plan; conducting technical studies and research regarding the plan's projects and programmes; creating study materials and reports on the plan; and monitoring the plan's projects, among other things.

Option D: Programme advisors

  • Programme advisor is a major divisions of the planning commission. 
  • Four senior officers with the status of former Additional Secretaries to the Government of India have been designated as advisors. They support the Commission's members in areas involving field research, observation of various initiatives and programmes, and tracking the development of those projects. The advisers also pay close attention to the administration, public collaboration, and financial issues related to the plans' implementation.

questions.text: A patient with complaints of stomach pain, bloody vomiting, fever, and confusion wants to seek medical attention. Which of the following is the First referral unit (FRU)?
questions.solution:
Option C: CHC

  • The community health center is the secondary level of health care in India, it is also known as the first referral level of care.

Option A:  Sub-centre

  • Most peripheral units are for direct contact between the population and the health system of our country.
  • It is also referred to as sub-health centers,

Option B: PHC

  • A PHC is included in the primary level of health care in India.
  • The first level of contact between the population and the health care system.

Option D: Medical college and hospital

  • It is the second referral level of health care in India.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most important single function of the organization given in the image below?

choices.text: Prevention and control of specific diseases
Promote and support national health policy development

questions.solution:
Option B: Promote and support national health policy development

  • WHO's most important single function is to promote and support national health policy development and the development of comprehensive national health programs.

WHO (World Health Organization)

  • Established in 1945.
  • Constitution came into force on 7th April 1948.
  • Hence, the 7th of April is WORLD HEALTH DAY.
  • The headquarters is located in GENEVA.
  • WHD 2018,2019 Theme is Universal health coverage.
  • WHO's most important single function is to promote and support national health policy development and the development of comprehensive national health programs.

Other Works of WHO:

  • Prevention and control of specific diseases
  • Family health, Environment health
  • Health statistics
  • Health literature & Information
  • Biomedical research
  • Cooperation with other organizations.

Other options

Option A: Prevention and control of specific diseases

  • Controlling and preventing specific diseases is also a function of the world health organization.

Option C: Health Literature & Information

  • Health literature & information is also a function of the world health organization.

Option D: Biomedical research

  • Biomedical research is also a function of the WHO but the single most important function of the WHO is to promote and support national health policy development and the development of comprehensive national health programmes.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman who had missed periods and been feeling tired went to the hospital. UPT testing revealed that she was positive. The woman does not want to continue her pregnancy. The Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Act allows abortion only up to how many weeks of pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Option A: 20 weeks

  • The Indian Law (MTP Act, 2021) allows abortion only up to 24 weeks of pregnancy.
  • The Act provides safeguards to the mother by authorizing only a Registered Medical Practitioner having experience in gynecology and obstetrics to perform an abortion where the length of pregnancy does not exceed 12 weeks. However, where the pregnancy exceeds 12 weeks and is not more than 24 weeks, the opinion of two Registered Medical Practitioners is necessary to terminate the pregnancy.

MTP ACT

  • Passed in 1971
  • Implemented in 1972
  • Revised in 1975
  • Amendment 2021 - Can now be done till 24 weeks, the reason for MTP must be approved by the board.

Indications:

  • Maternal risk such as NYHA grade III, IV.
  • Fetal risks such as anencephaly.
  • Humanitarian cause: Pregnancy caused by rape.
  • Contraceptive failure.

questions.text: A nominal variable is a type of variable that is used to name, label, or categorize particular attributes that are being measured. Which of the following is an example of a Nominal variable?
questions.solution:
Option B: Black hair color

  • Black hair color is an identity in the class ; Hence it is an example of a nominal variable.

Other options

Option A: Temperature

  • Ratio scale (Presence of absolute zero; thus ratios are possible).
  • Examples: Weight, Height, Blood glucose, Hemoglobin level, Serum cholesterol, Mid-arm circumference, Blood pressure, Pulse rate, and Kelvin temperature scale.

Option C: TNM staging

  • Ordinal scale: Based on ORD (order); grading into categories.
  • Examples: TNM staging (cancers), Severity of disease, Social classes.

Option D: Mid-arm circumference

  • Ratio scale (Presence of absolute zero; thus ratios are possible).
  • Examples: Weight, Height, Blood glucose, Hemoglobin level, Serum cholesterol, Mid-arm circumference, Blood pressure, Pulse rate, Kelvin temperature scale.

questions.text: The Factories Act, of 1948 is a social legislation that has been enacted for the occupational safety, health, and welfare of workers at workplaces. What is the maximum number of work hours/ week without including extra working hours prescribed under the Factories Act?
questions.solution:
Option B: 48 hours/week

  • The Factories Act of 1948 is social legislation that has been enacted for the occupational safety, health, and welfare of workers at workplaces.
  • Hours of work:
    • A maximum of 4½ hours of work per day for adolescents.
    • 48 hours per week (9 hrs per day).
    • Maximum 60 hours per week (including overtime).
    • 60 hours/week - then paid extra.

Other options 

Options A: 42 hours/week - This option is incorrect.
Option C: 54 hours/week- This option is incorrect.
Option D: 60 hours/week - Maximum 60 hours per week (including overtime). 60 hours/week - then paid extra.

questions.text: The mental health act is an act to provide mental health care and services for persons with mental illness. Provisions of the Mental Health Act 2017 based WHO Mental Action Gap Action Program (MHAGP) are all of the following, except?
questions.solution:
Option C: Screening family members

  • Provisions of the Mental Health Act 2017 based WHO Mental Action Gap Action Program (MHAGP) does not include Screening family members.

Option A: Human rights

  • Human rights, which are usually protected by both domestic and international law, are moral principles or rules for particular standards of human behaviour.
  • Human rights are included in the provisions of the Mental Health Act 2017 based WHO Mental Action Gap Action Program (MHAGP).

Option B: Communication regarding care and career

  • Communication regarding care and career are included in the provisions of the Mental Health Act 2017 based WHO Mental Action Gap Action Program (MHAGP).

Option D: Social support

  • Social support is the belief and experience that one is taken care of, that help is available from others, and, most commonly, that one is a part of a social network that is supportive. These comforting resources can be material or intangible, emotional or informative, or companionship.
  • Social support is included in the provisions of the Mental Health Act 2017 based WHO Mental Action Gap Action Program (MHAGP).
